I ordered my typical spicy tuna and eel/cucumber with the  sesame seared tuna appetizer. The fish was fresh as expected but the sushi unfortunately was loosely wrapped. The tuna app tasted mainly like sesame.

 I'm sure this place has more to offer and would try again if I were in town but definitely didn't win me over this time around.
author: Laurel K.

description:
Amazing sushi! Cant get in without reservations! I sat at the bar and mostly got sashimi...it was all tasty and super fresh. Loved the salmon, highly recommend the uni as well very fresh and the salmon roe nigiri...
The place is really small so a reservation is highly encouraged! I went on wed night at 8pm and could not gef in! The staff is really nice and the prices are very reasonable! 
Recommemded!
author: Galina M.

description:
Their menu lists their fish from Japan and their fish from the US. They serve kohoda, which is one our favorite fish and difficult to find outside Japan and LA (Torrance is a suburb of Tokyo). Every bite we had was lovely. 

Sakana is open until 1 pm on Fridays and Saturdays - one of the few restaurants with top quality food in SF that stays open late.
author: Vena V.

description: Fast, friendly and clean. Stopped by on a work trip. Totally worth the short walk from the hilton.
author: Sonja F.

description: Remarkably crowded for a sub-par place. I'm guessing it's people who, like us, were deterred by the large line formed at Ryoko's. The servers were kind enough, but seemed overworked and food took awhile with apps coming after the rolls. That being said, it wasn't too expensive and the rolls were decent.
author: Brooke D.

description:
NOT BAD WILL RETURN

Had a basic sushi dinner.  I had a bento, my wife had an unagi bowl, and Sara had her usual tamago, kapamaki and tobiko.

We ate everything with no complaints...but no interjections of elated joy either.
author: Randy S.

description:
Stopped here while on a business trip to SF.  It just happened to be close to the hotel where I was staying.  This place is pretty authentic, which is sometimes hard to find among all the trendy places popping up.  They know how to do omakase and they will actually do tsumami style if you ask the chef.

They had some unique fish on the daily menu.  I'm told that it changes daily depending on what's available at the market.  If I were living in the area, I would not hesitate to go back.
author: Mark N.

description: Probably the worst sushi I've ever had. If you love grocery store sushi you're in luck. It made me very sad. Don't be sad like me...skip this place.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Appears to be a traditional Japanese sushi bar with no time wasted on frills or bombastic interpretations.  Located nearby JW Marriott Union Square and opened until midnight on weekdays which was fortunate since we were hungry arriving late into town.  

Service was attentive and friendly paying particular attention to keeping our glasses filled consistently with water.  Chefs however are quiet and skilled as compared to the extravagant ones in LA.  Overall, service, quality of food, and reasonable prices made me a fan!
author: Eddie C.

description:
Another good sushi joint around the Tenderloin/Union Square area.

This is one of my go-to places anytime my parents want some good Japanese food close to home (don't even get me started with the food in Japantown...disgusting).

Anyhow, as I was saying. Good japanese food here. Fish are surprisingly fresh (given the location) and the price is reasonable. 

Service is not too shabby but at times the waiter seems to be a bit lost and overwhelmed. But he does have a good memory if you tip him well enough to make him happy...
author: Dave L.

description: Chill atmosphere, nice service, fresh sushi. Got the sushi omakase for $25 and it was delicious. Everything melted in my mouth from the sushi to the sea urchin.
author: Dustin G.

description: What a terrible place. Waited about 15 minutes to be seated and then about 15 more for a glass of water. Ordered hamachi nigiri, spicy tuna roll, eel roll, seaweed salad and tempura udon. Both rolls were terrible. Convenience store sushi is better. The tempura udon was fine, on par with ramen from a packet. The seaweed salad was terrible. Rehydrated seaweed with cucumber. I can make better at home. Can't believe I waited for a table here. Possibly worst sushi and service I've had in my life.
author: Josh Y.

description: Small place, quite ok but nothing spectacular. The sushi was ok, fatty tuna not living up to its price, not as fresh as it should be... Had better service.
author: G I.

description: Enjoyable little place. Feels hidden away for the more local, intimate groups. Brightly lit, small space, small tables. Loud in volume. Gotta speak up if you want to be heard. When it's packed, it's loud but it did not take anything away from our experience. If anything, it kept the energy and vibe of the place up overall. It was a nice spot to come upon.
author: Cynthia S.

description: Food was ok.  Service was terrible.  Slow and inattentive.  Male server was rude wwith major additude.
author: Jason K.

description:
I can't review the food, because we didn't stay.  We walked in last night for the first time.  We were greeted with a terse command to put our name on the list, which we did (no greeting, no eye-contact, and the list was not in an obvious place).  There was one name ahead of us, and two tables empty, waiting to be cleared and re-set, so we waited by the door.  After a minute, the same waiter that told us to sign in passed by and asked us if we had.  We said yes, and he rudely ordered us to wait outside.  It was not busy, we were not in the way and we weren't given a chance to be anything but polite.  We left and had a pleasant meal around the corner.  Sakana was half empty when we walked by on our way back to the car.

If you enjoy paying for someone to be incredibly rude to you, this might be your sushi place.  I don't need much hand-holding myself, but I refuse to patronize restaurants that can't even master the basics of polite human interaction.
author: Lisa R.

description:
I love sushi, I can't get enough of it. So much so, that I enthusiastically agreed to sushi for dinner while I was enjoying sushi for lunch.

When my co-worker and I arrived at Sakana, all of the tables were full and the wait was 30 minutes. Since there's nowhere to wait, the server/host didn't mind us heading next door to Owl Tree for a drink while we waited. When we returned at the appointed time, our table was waiting.

My colleague went with a sampling of nigiri, a few selections at the recommendation of our server. One, I forget the name, was something we never heard of. I went with the hamachi nigiri, tuna bomb maki, saba gari maki, and spicy salmon maki. Everything was well made and fresh, not laden with rice nor skimpy on the fish. My favorite roll was the tuna bomb, I loved the slow heat from the chunks of deep fried jalapeno in the roll.

As others have said, Sakana is not trendy or sleek looking and the lighting is kind of unflattering; true to their words on the website - it is a bit of a hole-in-the-wall. Don't let that deter you, wander in and get some grub. One caveat, if you gravitate toward fusion rolls, you may find yourself disappointed.
author: Mary T.

description:
Start with ankimo or grilled silver cod.  Then, indulge in the chef's omakase sushi ($25) with no rolls and request it to be interesting.  it's a plate with at least a dozen pieces of fish or more.  End with fried bananas and scoops of green tea and mango ice cream.  I didn't try the green tea flan, but I'll be back with more opportunities to do so.

Service is friendly and attentive with lots of refills on water and tea, but it can take awhile.  The decor and ambiance is that of a small, quaint sushi joint without much frills except what is on their special menu.  Parking is tough on the street, but there are some nearby garages.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Sakana is my kind of place. Great food, good service, unpretentious.

It's high-class food, without high-class snobbery and high-class prices.

I had a group of 8 last minute during a very busy weekend in SF, and they were happy to accomodate us, told us we could hang out next door while we waited and they even came to get us. Obviously, with any waiting - we were hungry by the time we were seated. The food came fast, it was delicious - every single one of us loved our meal. And honestly, I'm writing this over a month later and I'm STILL thinking of my delicious dish at Sakana!

What's one word that describes you're beyond impressed? 
Visualize that as my review of Sakana.
author: CM P.

description: The food was pretty good, but the service was sooooooo bad. The host/waiters were really brusque and rude and kinda sketchy too. We went there on a Saturdat night, and we felt like we weren't welcome and we were being rushed out of there. It's a small to medium sized place, pretty loud inside. They didn't bring us water until the second time I asked for it. The prices were pretty low, $15 minimum to use card. Honestly, idk if it's worth going there again, because the food is good, but you have to factor in if you want to be ignored and disrespected or not.
author: Kat D.

description: As good as it gets... is it rude to say I was the only white person in there?
author: Bobby S.

description:
I literally laughed at the portions for the rolls I ordered. They are arguably the size of those mega M&M's they sell at supermarkets now. Nothing special about the rolls either.

In all fairness though, I only had the rolls. I did not have the nigiri (but if they can't get rolls right, what makes you think they can get nigiri right?)

The only good was service. The waiter was prompt and patient.
author: Justin L.

description:
I have now found the sushi bar standard by which other sushi bars I go to will be compared to. Sakana, a small, clean sushi bar in the heart of San Francisco near Union Square.

I eat lots and lots of sushi, and Sakana has sushi that will just melt in your mouth. The prices are also extremely reasonable.

One surprise, a friend of mine who has been here recommended the California Roll to me. It was fantasitc! I rarely if ever order a California Roll, but this is totally different than your garden variety. It is so tasty I really don't know what they do to take a usually bland, 'safe' for non-sushi aficionados roll and turn it into this delectable bite of heaven. 

I will come back to Sakana every time I find myself in the Bay area, it is simply outstanding. Highly recommend!
author: Paula P.

description:
Beyond horrible. Uni was spoiled and when we tried to send it back, the manager claimed that we didn't know what uni tasted like. Also ordered agadashi tofu and when the waiter failed to bring it out near the end of the meal, he replied "you may or may not have ordered it." 

If you're in the area, I recommend ryoko or sanraku. There's a clear reason why those restaurants have waits and this one does not.
author: Jenny Q.

description: Worst customer service! Please stay away from this sushi place.  I didn't even try their sushi, I had to walk out.
author: Mary P.

description: I'm a big fan of Sakana.  I think they're one of the better casual sushi restaurants in the Tender Nob.  If you like both traditional nigiri and American rolls, you'll enjoy this restaurant as they offer both.  On a week day at around 8pm, the restaurant wasn't very busy which made for great service.  I started off with the burdock in sesame oil (which I quite enjoyed), and followed it up with an order of tamago, the crispy roll, and a California roll.  All of their sushi tasted great.  The crispy roll, which is asparagus and tempura shrimp with tempura flakes on the outside was a big winner in my book, but even the simple California roll was just a very enjoyable roll.  Will definitely come back again.  All this for only $26 incl. tip - very reasonable.
author: Zach S.

description:
I love sushi.

I ordered take-out on a Thursday evening at 7pm over the phone and was quoted that it would be ready within ten minutes. It was.

When I arrived, there were only a few guests seated. It's a small place with, if I recall correctly, only about six tables. I was greeted immediately by a man and a waitress. The man informed me that their website has their menu available, and that it's continuously updated with the latest menu items.

From memory, I had ordered:
- Rainbow cut roll
- Tuna Bomb roll
- A salmon/cucumber hand roll
- Uni sushi
- Yellowtail sushi
- Salmon sashimi (5pc)
- Eel sushi
- Bacon-wrapped scallops on skewers

I enjoyed every single item. The sushi was fresh and delicious! I'd love to go back again and try dining in.

(EDIT: photo of the take-out order: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=cclWtqnzqE2613etqbUNqA)
author: Michael Y.

description: Delicious rolls and sashimi. My only complain is that the ikura nigiris were ridiculously small. Other than that, good service and very delicious rolls. I specially liked the rainbow roll  yum
author: Sara C.

description:
Very welcoming ambience/good service when you walk in. 
Sat at the bar w/ my two SF comrades and ordered:

1. Maguro Goma Tataki (Seared Ahi Tuna) = Delicious, the ahi tuna is perfectly cooked and comes with a nice side of seaweed salad and mayo sirircha sauce for dipping.  

2. Miso soup = delicious, who can go wrong w/ miso soup? Hope I NEVER find out.

3. Salmon Sashimi = Dammit why did I opt to share this? It MELTED in my mouth and was perfect! 

4. Specialty rolls = we ordered the crunchy roll, spicy roll, scallop roll and 49'er roll (california roll w/ salmon sashimi and lemon on top) The rolls were good, but nothing special to note but the 49'er Roll was my favorite! First of all I love salmon sashimi (refer to #3) and this roll is generally my go to in most sushi places, but the add on of the lemon slice gives it a nice sour kick at the end. Delicious!! 

In conclusion - this sushi place is a fairly priced, satisfying sushi place that I would recommend if you wanted to grab a quick bite w/ a comfortable atmosphere, good service and kind staff! Satisfied my sushi needs for sure.
author: Christina N.

description: The second time I go, the flavor and taste has changed a lot, especially the monkfish liver, delicious the first time but very disappointed the second time. The waiter is always in a rush...definitely not the best service
author: Tingxiao Z.

description:
As others have stated here, the fish is fresh and nicely prepared.  The rice, sadly, is not up to par - it was at best a little wet, at worst a little mushy.  I sat at the sushi bar early on a Sunday night and had the following:

MISO SOUP - delicious but lukewarm; nice scallion flavor but not overwhelming

KANPACHI - velvety, very fresh and delicious, maybe cut a bit too thick but still quite enjoyable 

SPICY SCALLOP HAND ROLL - very fresh and sweet scallops, maybe could have used a bit more heat

SALMON SKIN HAND ROLL - this was OK - the skin could have used a bit more time under the broiler for crunch

IKURA SUSHI - very fresh and briny salmon roe - loved the ikura but the rice was a little wet

UNI SUSHI - very sweet sea urchin (could be dessert!) - $7.50 for two pieces is very fair price 

HAMACHI KAMA - one of the best broiled yellowtail collars I have eaten.  Simply prepared, with nice crunchy bits.  A few squeezes of lemon and this was perfect.

As for service, it is efficient and polite, if not overly friendly (especially the guys working behind the sushi bar).  At that hour, service was brisk.  I was in and out of there within 45 minutes.

Overall, though, the rice did not ruin my meal.  The fish was so good it made up for it.
author: Steven H.

description:
Awesome fresh sushi. Plan on making reservations as the place is very small and popular.  Sat at the sushi bar with a friend and enjoyed Chefs Hiroshi and Kenji selections for almost 3 hrs.

Some of the fish was flown in from Japan.  I highly recommend the Fatty Tuna, Sea Urchin,  and Mackerel. 
Without a doubt my sushi spot in San Francisco
author: Jimmy H.

description: The sushi is okay, have taken out from here twice.  It is fresh and the rolls are good but nothing solid.  I always find the service a little arrogant and less friendly than other comparable restaurants, costing it a star.
author: Lloyd M.

description: We stopped in for dinner on a Saturday about 830 at night. There was a short wait and you have to wait outside on the street. The food was good but I definitely have had better sushi at other places. The restaurant is very loud and it was difficult conversations during the meal due to other people talking.
author: Jenna B.

description: I was a bit worried about service after reading the yelp reviews.  Actually had a great time.  We weren't in a hurry so we didn't care so much but we were in and out within 45 minutes.  Everyone was super nice and the sushi was good.  I did order fatty tuna that ebbed up being a bit more fatty than I've been used to in the past but still good
author: Rena A.

description: This place is right near my sister's place so we decided to grab dinner here before I left for the airport.  The waitress was very nice & accommodating since we had my 1 yr.old nephew with us.  The food is fresh but just ok.  Their menu is not too extensive and serving size very small.    Not sure if I'm a fan.
author: Judy S.

description:
It's a small neighborhood gem.  We tried to visit before but always catch them when they are closed.  The trick to get a table without reservation is to get in early when they first open.  

Our most recent visit, we had:
hot sake - $3.75
seaweed salad - $4.5
hotate carpaccio - $12
beef tataki - $8
mirugai kushi - $5.5
tempura - $7
houbou - $5
shiro maguro - $5
arakabu - $5
chikame kintoki - $5
ama ebi - $7
uni - $7
some special nigiri - $5
author: Gloria H.

description: First impressions. What is this place?? Once I had their sushi. Oh my gosh awesome!!! Fish is super fresh and you won't want to miss it!!!
author: Amanda M.

description: Nice little spot next to the JW.  Fresh fish and good sake.  Imports from Japan and also local varieties.  This place seems to focus more on traditional nigiri and shashimi.  If you like Americanized sushi rolls this is not the place for you. The price was less expensive than I expected.
author: Felix B.

description:
I like sushi.  And I'm not the type of guy who walks into a sushi bar and orders a bunch of rolls - I mostly just like the raw fish.  That said, I'm not an expert: as a full disclaimer, most of my sushi experience has occured at home in Arizona, which, for those who are not geography whizzes, does not actually border an ocean.  So my standards may be a little off when I say this is as good as any sushi I've ever had.

It was a good sign when the restaurant was full when we arrived.  No worries, they put us down for a 30-40 minute wait, which gave us some time to walk around the Union Square area and find a remedy for my friend's magnanimous chafing problem.

What I was really excited about was the seasonal menu.  They had fish I haven't seen at any of the other sushi places I've visited, and even fish I hadn't even *heard* of!  I mean, what the hell is a "bream?"  I ordered one, though, and it was delicious.

The fish I was most concerned about?  Gizzard shad.  Isn't shad a baitfish?  I actually liked it, though.  Maybe I would enjoy life as a striped bass.

Also, the uni was tasty.  Another thing: apparently "California Roll" means something different here... It actually has *actual* crab in it, instead of imitation crab meat.  It took the dragon roll or rainbow roll or whatever we ordered to a whole new level.

At the end of the night, we had spent over $60 each on sushi.  And the next day my friend mused about how we should've doubled our order.
author: Jeremy P.

description: Sushi here is amazing and the Service is Spectacular! Came in with a friend for dinner before going to Theatre and ordered Lots of Sushi & it was entirely Delicious! The presentation was also beautiful. I loved everything about this Restaurant! I was also looking at other people's food and everything looked enticing! From Sushi to Sashimi to items off the Grill, even Bento all looked great! I had a lovely time here!
author: Julian I.

description: The food is amazing! I wound have given this place 5 stars if I were to only compare it to the food alone, but service is also a factor. The waiter was curt.... No he was flat out rude.  The food made him tolerable!
author: Reya B.

description: the worst sushi i have had in last 10 years. I travel a lot because of my work, so I have had really good to really rally bad sushi. I never spit out food at a restaurant before, and I did here. The chef actually saw me spitting out, and he did not seemed surprised. I had omakase dinner for $25. This place definitely uses really bad bad fish, rice, and the cooks don't put any afford making them.  I am married to a Japanese, and I have lived in LA for about a dozen years and been to Japan about 15 times. Trust me, don't eat there. I am shocked they have 4 stars here.
author: Noh Jin P.

description:
Great quality and not over priced!

Pros
-very fresh fish
-now feature toro nigiri again (after months w/o it)
-fairly intimate seating considering how small the restaurant is
-was seated w/in 10 min on new years eve
-not too expensive

Cons
-larger groups had much longer wait (close to 1 hr)-- make reservations!
-no area to wait indoors
author: Brooke L.

description:
Woah.  My fiance and I loved our visit to Sakana.  We ordered the 49er Roll (Cali Roll w real crab & salmon lemon slice atop), Spicy Tuna w/ Tempura Jalapeno Roll and the Chicken Teriyaki.  We absolutely LOVED our rolls!  I've always liked sushi and upon learning Sakana uses real crab meat for their Cali Rolls was was sold on the 49er.  

I highly recommend the 49er Roll if you like salmon; the thin slice of lemon was a perfect complement to the rich salmon and crab salad.  What was more amazing when we dined at Sakana was the fact that it made my fiance less scared and oppose to raw fish.  I'm truly indebted to Sakana for the Japlapeno Roll.  Now I can drag him to more sushi/sashimi (i.e. seafood) dinners.  My days of only meat and potatoes may soon be over.  Whee!  Good waiter and food service; host was a bit gruff.  Best to make reservations or come before or after dinner rush.
author: Angela N.

description: Sushi here is decent and tasty.  Prices were also very reasonable and the staff was nice.
author: Audrey C.

description: The best and most reasonably priced sushi in SF for sure.  Sit at the bar, get everything the sushi chef tells you to get and you won't be disappointed.  Such a hidden gem!
author: Diana C.

description:
The sushi is ok , but small. I'd recommend the caterpillar roll over the crispy roll. 
The service is really fast and friendly.
author: Santos C.

description: When you don't want to wait in the long line at Ryoku, this place is a good alternative. It's really close and the sushi is just as good, if not, a little better than Ryoku. Plus, you get to sit down and relax a little bit more instead of feeling rushed (which is how I've felt dining at Ryoku the last couple of times). It's not as lively, but I kinda like it that way because I can actually talk to whoever I'm with instead of yelling over people.
author: HM N.

description: 3.5 rounded up!  I went for dinner with a couple little ladies from my building, and we were able to grab a nice table by the window.  I was super hungry so I got the saba, tempura and sashimi dinner combination, which comes with miso soup and rice.  My miso soup was gone in seconds!  The sashimi was really fresh - totally enjoyed that.  The batter on the tempura was just slightly heavier than I like, but there was a nice variety of shrimp, squash, carrots, broccoli.  My saba was just slightly overcooked - I like it soft and fall-off-the-fork cooked, but the flavor was wonderful.  One of the ladies ordered the saba shioyaki, and there were quite a few bones that she had to pick out - not sure, if they meant it to be like that, but she was a little irritated.  I wouldn't mind, but my saba didn't have any bones in it.  Our tea and waters were filled frequently and service was friendly.  If Ryoko is too crowded, head over to Sakana!
author: Maile N.

description: I haven't had many sushi experiences, but my time at Sakana was the best one I've had so far. I was seated promptly at the bar even though it was 9pm on a Saturday night and ordered my food right away. I got a combination plate and I devoured that and the miso soup.
author: Gloria A.

description:
(See pics)

Still on my popular list of sushi joints I love. Always fresh and delicate. Lots of import fish but not expensive.

Their list of sushi is very much delicate and very delicious. This time I had madai, kikori-dai, chikame kintoki. mejina, kohada, ankimo and uni. And an Asahi. Every piece was soft and tender to the taste.
author: T L.

description:
Sakana, so fresh and so clean clean.

I'm very picky about my sushi and love ordering takeout from here when I lived a block away.  They're awesome!
author: Mia F.

description:
Came here today with my boyfriend. Our other Japanese/ sushi Resturant  wasn't available so we decided to give this one a try. Our female server was pretty nice and friendly.  Got seated right away on a Saturday night. Compared to other type of Japanese food , you would expect sushi to be more pricey.  So we expected to be paying more. 

Decided to get a dragon roll and spider roll for myself while my boyfriend got a spicy tuna roll and some other roll I forgot.

When we got sushi , the portion were kind of small, at least for my boyfriend. Mine was as expected for a normal dragon/spider roll.

The dragon roll was decent , but it wasn't anything super special about it. It was just avocado and bbq eel on top, not much special topping unlike some of other sushi Resturant .  Spider roll was kind of bland. Tasted like a shrimp tempura sushi but no sauce or anything in it. Kind of disappointed since other places made it more unique and tasty with their other sauce and topping.

Boyfriend was really unsatisfied. No offense, it looked more like something you can easily make at home given the same seafood. Plus the portion were small.

Not a bad place since server we got was friendly but considering price for the sushi , kinda expected something more with it compared to other sushi Resturant  with similar prices.  Food wasn't terrible but it wasn't great either.  Maybe the other items were better ?

I can see why people didn't like the male server. As we walked out the door , the female one said thank you and good bye. The male one just opened the door so he can let other customer in without saying a single word and gave a long stern face at us. Guess people might considered it mean and rude to some of other people.
author: Alice L.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped in for dinner and we were starving so we wanted something more substantial than sushi. He had the chicken teriyaki and I had the beef teriyaki. Our entrées came with salad, rice, and miso. We also got the assorted tempura and crunch roll. My beef teriyaki was a beautiful piece of steak, cooked very rare as requested, served with the most flavorful teriyaki sauce I've ever had. My boyfriend's chicken was amazing also, and I'm not even the biggest fan of chicken. Also... The salad dressing was ridiculous!

As for the appetizers, I'd say the tempura was just alright. The batter was a bit thick for my liking. However, I highly recommend the crunch roll. It has tempura asparagus, shrimp, tempura flakes and is topped with sweet soy. Not health food but ridiculously tasty.

Great service, nice, relaxed atmosphere, and generally a wonderful dining experience. My favorite Japanese in the area by far!
author: Meredith S.

description:
Here's a TIP for this place: 

Overpriced; I've had better quality sushi for less in San Francisco. I don't have food poisoning, but I felt worse after I left. 

When I got my rolls, I could tell right away just by looking at the food that it wasn't going to be good. Seeing that this place has a 4.2 rating, I was really disappointed. The rolls were served on this DIRTY red platter; there were marks that didn't come from the sushi. Seriously? Make sure your platters are clean before you serve them, that's disgusting. I couldn't trust that my plate was clean the whole time I ate.

The presentation alone deserves a 1/5--it was clumped together and very basic. I have never seen sushi rolls made so sloppy and messy, it was appalling to me. I payed double as much to have half as much rice and fish as I usually do at other places, which is one of the reasons I will not be returning.

The rice wasn't the ordinary round, fluffy sushi rice, which is the core of great sushi; this is what they lacked when they served regular Chinese food quality rice. I am picky about my rice because that is 50% of the sushi. The fish was average, again I've still had fresher, chewier, raw fish for less in SF--also, they give very little portions that is was embarrassing. Although I ordered two rolls, which would usually leave me full, I was not at all satisfied when I left.

This place sucks. Sakana definitely does not deserve my return. Lastly, the customer service was awkward. The waiter, this tall white guy, who seems to be the owner, never said "Hi" and "Thank you". Shouldn't you know better if you're the owner? He would be monotone, not at all energetic and answered either 'yes' or 'no'. He never came back to check on me. 

The waiter only cares about getting your money and making sure you paid your meal. 

Take your money somewhere else. I recommend Sushi Zen in the Sunset district; Kabuto in the Richmond district; Sushi Zone in the Hayes Valley neighborhood; Ebisu on Irving Street,
author: Natalie Charlotte W.

description:
You better like your Sushi with an attitude because that is what this tiny hole in the wall restaurant will give you.  I live in the neighborhood and go in once in a while.  Because the place is small, singles are usually seated at the sushi bar.  Tonight I was seated in a corner of the bar that I couldn't physically fit in.  While there were two open seats next to me where I could have at least elbow room, I was not allowed to adjust my seat to add any room.   I felt like I was in the third grade.  I left without ordering.

Some restaurants cram as many seats and tables as they can.  This restaurant is one of them.
author: Marc P.

description: Good sushi. Could use a little redoing of the interior and the staff could use smile training. Reservations recommended!
author: Connie B.

description: Got the Omakase nigiri (6 pieces and a roll, chef's choice) and thoroughly enjoyed it. Often times with these combos you get a few "filler" items - ebi, tamago, etc.  This was all solid - ikura, amaebi, sea bream, etc. The menu was extensive, including fish from Japan, and all the sushi was fresh and delicious. We also split a tempura udon, and it arrived in two bowls - props for that. Service was friendly and fast. Only thing I didn't like was my hot sake - it tasted a bit vinegary.
author: N. S.

description: I seem to always find myself here. This is a small-ish restaurant and maybe not the fanciest digs in town. But, sit at the bar. Order your sashimi and sushi and enjoy the lovely unadulterated fishy awesomeness.
author: Rich B.

description: my fav sushi spot in SF-known the Ogawa family for about 9 years and theyre awesome.  Food is authentic and not over-the top in a Nobu or Katsuya kind of way while still being classy. Recommend it for date night as it's great sushi that isn't gonna break the bank
author: Jon O.

description:
This place truly gets it. Fresh fish daily, great location, and great food.
Always come here for lunch lately and the service is fast and the quality is always consistent.  Great japanese staff and classically trained. Kudos to sakana to delivering fresh goodness to union square area. Portions could be a bit bigger for the price but overall not bad value.  Add any ramen dishes in the future? 4.5/5 judochops in my book.
author: Dustin G.

description: Good tender-nob sushi spot just a few blocks from union square. Simple menu done right. I got their toro nigiri, spicy tuna, miso, and tempura. It was all served quickly and tasted great. Love that they have Kirin just wish it wasn't only Kirin Light.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Got the eggplant nigiri, crispy roll, ankimo, and unakyu roll. Everything was good and fresh tasting. I enjoyed the crispy roll the most. The eggplant nigiri is delightful as well; I don't see this often on sushi menus. The ankimo was a bit bland compared to what I've tasted elsewhere, but still good. Service is good, and it's a short walk to Union Square. 
Not the most memorable meal I've had, but it is decent Japanese food for the price in this area.
author: Anna C.

description:
Simple and delicious - in my opinion, as good as it gets for an understated sushi restaurant. My girlfriend and I mostly ordered nigiri (I recommend checking their menu of seasonal options for fresh and interesting choices). The standouts were the hamachi (beautiful to look at, even better to eat) and of course the toro (melted in my mouth before I knew it). The fried banana dessert with vanilla ice cream was a perfect ending. 

Two details I appreciated a lot: I ordered chilled unfiltered sake, which was served overflowing (a new experience for me), and complementary green tea at the end of the meal. I know those might seem insignificant to many people, but small gestures of generosity and appreciation go a long way for me. 

Overall, the ideal place to stop by for a tasty late-night sushi stop.
author: Alexander C.

description:
Ummmmm.... yummmmmm... possibly the best sushi ever. This may be the alcohol talking... But so what.

Highest possible recommendation.
author: Julie B.

description:
I love sushi! 

My boyfriend and I came here after reading good reviews about their fried banana. However, before desserts we ordered a spicy scallop roll, 49ers roll, hamachi negi roll, young yellowtail, pickled vegetables, and otokayama (alcohol that we ordered two round of). Yes, we love sushi that much and we finished everything =)

I absolutely loved all the rolls we ordered, especially the yellowtail, which consists of only two. It was the freshest thing I have ever tasted (I could eat it everyday). The pickled vegetables were only so-so, but everything else we loved. The Otokayama came in a cute sugar cane container and it was just as smooth, if not smoother than a Patron shot. I enjoyed it very much. 

As for desserts, the server we got was very, very nice. We couldn't decide if we wanted the green tea ice-cream, or the mango ice-cream so he gave us both flavors for no extra charge. I loved the fried bananas (maybe cause I love bananas to begin with) so just the banana itself was already good without the ice-cream. As for the ice-cream, as our server put it, "The green tea tastes very Asian and the mango if very American-tasting." Hahaha.. true that!

I would definitely come back here!
author: Jorgess M.

description:
Service - exceptional! 

Husband ordered chirashi and ice tea and I ordered spider roll and the mountain potato with spicy roe.

Husband said chirashi bowl with "egg omelet" not impressive and it's $20.  Had better elsewhere with more serving of fish.

Mountain potato with spicy roe - it's listed as one of their popular appetizers.  My husband and I are not a fan of ground raw fish, but we both gave it a shot anyway.  Won't be ordering it again from anywhere else either.

Spider roll - it was ok and decently priced.

No sugar ice tea - seems diluted. 

In conclusion, we will not be coming back.
author: Amber V.

description: Surly service, wilting fish, and lazy rice.  With a half-dozen much better sushi spots in spitting distance, it's amazing this place is still in business.
author: Warren J.

description: Second japanese restaurant i tried in SF. Reasonable price, lower than sanraku, friendly staff. I don't like rolls as i believe it's not a traditional japanese dish. A lot of non-roll selections here. Like in china, i ordered ama ebi sashimi and told the staff to fry shrimp heads, it's good no extra charges although not to hot. Like burdock as well.
author: Joyce L.

description: We got seated at the bar right away which was nice. But just as we sat down the waiter came and rushed us and almost pushed us to squeeze closer. Five minutes later he hit me with his elbow quite hard but did not even stop to apologize. The food was also rushed and the rolls were falling apart. The food was served by the cook who casually handed a plate with all four rolls to us, without an explanation of the different items. I wouldn't go back and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
author: Ditte K.

description:
Sakana is named "fish" for a reason!

There are a number of Japanese restaurants that have great izakaya / non-sushi menus in SF that I have found, but not a place with sushi that met the bar besides Sushi Ran in Sausalito. So I was very pleasantly surprised that Sakana, in the heart of the Tenderloin, had not only a great izakaya menu but also fantastic fresh sushi! 

- Salmon skin salad - usually the salmon skin has to be crispy to be edible, but they did a great job grilling the skin with some flesh left, with picked carrot and greens. Loved it
- Ankimo - you can tell when monkfish liver is not super fresh. Sakana's was great quality and more volume than expected, so delicious
- Gindara glazed w miso - so tender and delicate and delicious. Two smaller fillets but sooo good
- Yamaimo mentaiko ae - spicy cod roe with the mountain yam (kind of slimy like okura but has texture of jicama and lighter delicate taste), really yummy.

- Sushi - we asked what was good today and they suggested the chikame-kintoki (which I cannot figure out English name... it sounded like an italian name if that helps). Very fresh. We also had the kanpachi (amber jack) and ama-ebi (sweet shrimp) which also comes out with the delicious fried head. Blanking on another sushi that was equally good.
- Roll - my friend ordered the 49ers roll which is California roll with salmon and lemon on top, surprisingly delicious

As others have mentioned, it is a small place, and we took the last two seats at the bar as walk ins at 6:45. They seem to take reservations, and many people who tried to walk in were turned away on a Tues night.

Service is great, both in and outside the bar. Friendly and helpful.

For two people eating above plus sake and tax and tip, came out to about $50 per person, great value.
author: Aki N.

description:
Excellent!  All the sushi fish was high quality and flavorful.  We ordered a sushi omakase (chefs choice of 8 pieces) and 2 california rolls.  We were quite pleased.  We ha a waitress who was very nice.
Plus this place is a steal!!

Notes to the owner: this place obviously makes a lot of money.  Put some of it back into the business.  A little sprucing up, both in the dining room and the bathroom will make you back 3x or more in business. Trust me on that.
author: Jason K.

description:
I thought this spot was excellent! We called to see if getting a table would be a problem. Assured they could take care of us, we drove on over. We were surprised when they asked if I was the one who called; they had reserved their best table for us! We each ordered the sashimi combo, and it was excellent.

So, the service and the food are as good as one will get anywhere! I highly recommend them.
author: Nick N.

description: We got right in on a Saturday night around 8pm which was a pleasant surprise. The interior is not super chic, but the rolls are good, reasonably priced, and quickly served.
author: Ryan C.

description: Three is a compromise. I say 4 and my wife says 2. I thought soft shell crab tempura and dragon roll were very good. Tuna roll was just ok because fish lacked texture. I'd go back, but I'll be in my own.
author: Dan L.

description:
Great sushi place, although REALLY pricey. Then again, sushi are expensive, I suppose. I came here with my sister on a Saturday afternoon. It was very quiet, only about 2 tables there. A middle age woman was our server and she was a really nice and accomodating person. Our tea cups are constantly filled and the wait wasn't long at all. 

On to the food:
We came here to eat sushi and we did. We ordered about 9 servings of sushi and the bill came out to be $64 for two people in the end. We left really full. 

Our orders: 
- Spicy tuna roll ($5.50 for 6 pieces): really fresh and really good. 
- Salmon Skin Roll ($5.50 - $6 for 6 pieces): This roll was okay. It's a bit charred, so you can taste the burned taste. I also didn't taste a lot of the salmon skin flavor. 
- Sake roll ($5.50 - $6 for 6 pieces, salmon & cucumber): This is amazing. Salmon is really fresh and it's just super good. It was my sister's favorite. 
- Rock n' roll (($5.50 - $6 for 6 pieces, bbq eel + avocado): This is also amazing if you love eel. I love eel and I wasn't disappointed. Definitely very good. 
- Spider Roll ($9 for 5 pieces, soft shell crab roll). This one is definitely very pricey. But it has that amazing fried taste. I wouldn't order this again though because of the price. 
- Tempura Roll ($5.50 - $6 for 6 pieces, basically fried shrimp tempura wrapped in a roll): This one's pretty good too if you like tempura. 

I like this place and I would definitely come back. But expect to spend at least $20 - $30 a person if you want to leave here full. The other items on the menu are rather pricey too. But their food are fresh. I would definitely all sushi lovers to come here and give it a try at least once. 

It does get pretty crowded during dinner time though.
author: Erni L.

description: I love the sashimi platter. The slices are not too thin or too thick. Also ordered the dragon which was amazing!
author: Qianqi L.

description:
As you duck under the drapes to find the entrance to this sushi bar, what you find is a small but clean sushi joint.  The host/server quickly greeted us at the entrance and sat us at the bar at our request.

The rolls seemed reasonably priced and the wifey and I enjoyed some hot tea and miso soup, both of which were quite good.  It took a while for the sushi chef to look up and ask us if we were ready to order.  He definitely is not the friendliest chef around.  But what he lacks in sociableness he more than makes up for in speed.

The 4 rolls we ordered came out quickly, I was slightly disappointed at the size of the rolls but the fish quality was excellent which is of course the most important thing.  

Over all we happy but are still in search of our favorite SF sushi joint.

In summary-

Pros: quality of fish, speed of staff, price of rolls

Cons: chef friendliness, size of rolls
author: Joshua S.

description: Great little late night sushi spot. Decently priced and great combo specials. Nothing more
author: Elena C.

description: Food 4 stars. Service 2.5 stars. Dining room 2 stars. The food was very good: salty edamame, rich ankimo, smooth ika, crunchy and salt watery mirugai, succulent hamachi kama, asking for a glass of water 3-4 times is not acceptable. Very cramped sushi bar. I'll go again for the food.
author: Dining D.

description:
I visited this place from out of town.  The sushi was really fresh.  The waitress was very kind, as our nieces and nephews were all gluten free and were allergic to sesame seeds, so she kindly gave us gluten free soy sauce and put in our order for rolls without sesame seeds.  

The sake came in a very cool bamboo looking carafe and the sake was quite tasty.  The food was not too expensive for sushi.  It's a very small place and can get crowded, so I would not recommend large groups. The atmosphere is comfortable and relaxing.
author: Allyson T.

description:
I had a sushi sashimi combination at the balcony, which was a perfect light meal before going out at night.
It was a simple japanese dish yet well made for a fair price, the misso soup reminded me of my mother's.
author: Marcos E.

description: Let's be honest here.  Most of us stop in on Sakana because Ryoko's was packed and the wait was outrageous when you're hungry.  But... that doesn't diminish the fact that their sushi is excellent and the fish fresh.  I had the omakase (chef's choice) and the uni nigiri.  Fresh, fresh, fresh is all I have to say about it.  The server was attentive, but not over bearing.  I'd definitely go back again.
author: Diana A.

description:
Good sushi, fast service, relaxed atmosphere. 
This place was a block away from my hotel so I gave it a try. Sushi was good, not the best I've ever had but certainly not the worst. Service was quick, but I didn't feel as if they were rushing me out at all. Prices were more than reasonable. And the the place had a very relaxed vibe.
I would go back if I was within walking distance. Zero complaints.
author: Jennifer B.

description: I just came from here. Terrible food. Terrible service. The chicken Karaage was 90 percent fat. Server was not attentive and was rushing me
author: Leslie M.

description: We stopped in for a quick bite before going to the Masonic to see a show. Our waitress was very welcoming & gracious, as well as knowledgable about the menu. Our food was fresh & expertly prepared. We had reservations so our table was waiting for us when we got there, although there were plenty of available tables when we arrived, it filled up quickly while we were there so I'm glad we had them. I would definitely return.
author: Katie R.

description: Fairly solid sushi, reasonable prices. Very nice staff.
author: Rob K.

description:
We came here for dinner our first night in town.  After walking 8 miles up and down the mountains of San Francisco - we're from Atlanta, we only have hills really - we decided it was best not to travel too far from the hotel. (We stayed at the Hilton Union Square; a review on this one to come) 

It's small and quaint.  They have their sushi bar and about six tables around the outside.  We only ate sushi, so I can't tell you anything about the entrees. We ordered a philly roll, spicy tuna roll, a shrimp tempura roll, and something called a dragon roll - tuna with jalapeño. 

The first three rolls were delicious.  The dragon roll wasn't so awesome.  I think the jalapeño overpowered the tuna and it was just ... 

Thankfully it was close to the hotel and it satisfied our hunger. 


OAN their miso soup was standard but quite good.
author: Stephanie R.

description: Enjoy this place. Teka don and salmon nigiri. Both were tasty. Salmon was really buttery delicious!
author: Ryan S.

description: This place is small but the fish is fresh and delicious! I had to wait 25 minutes to sit at 8 pm on a Wednesday night, but I did because of the good reviews and it was worth it!
author: Kat M.

description:
This is a small place, but packs a delicious punch!  It was my first meal ever in San Francisco, and it certainly left a good taste in my mouth.

My boyfriend had a rainbow roll (it had ahi, albacore, yellow tail, eel, shrimp, and salmon) and a yellow tail sushi.  I had a dragon roll and salmon sushi. The fish was SO fresh, it melted in our mouths. The eel wasn't greasy like it can be, but tasted fresh and sweet. Very high quality food!

My only tip... The gentleman that took our order made sure to repeat the Japanese names for us.  I know the Japanese names, but I'm so used to ignorant waitstaff at home, I don't bother - so I guess just know that you can feel free to demonstrate your sushi knowledge.
author: Jackie W.

description:
The wait was only about ten minutes for a corner table in this packed little place, at 6:30 on a Wednesday night.  Service is quick and pleasant.  We ordered three rolls and an appetizer, the seared tuna with ponzu vinaigrette.  We could have just eaten the tuna appetizer all night; it was delicious, and the tuna melt-in-your-mouth tender.  The rolls were compact but flavorful and fresh; the hamachi with scallions and seared eel with avocado were particular favorites.  Although we're not vegetarians, I thought they featured an impressive selection of vegetarian rolls; we ordered an asparagus roll, and enjoyed it very much.

This doesn't seem to be one of those places that serves showy, large, mayo-covered novelty "sushi" rolls.  The food is simple; it seems to be fairly traditionally Japanese, and the rolls are satisfying, but not imaginative.  Not that we found anything wrong with that.
author: Girl D.

description:
My new fave sushi house!

Food = 4.5:  Very fresh fish and very good selection.  Check the specials board and ask what's fresh.  Sakana also served fried squid tails - the kind you usually only find at an izakaya.  

Service = 4.0:  Our Japanese server was really sweet and the food came out fast and fresh.  Did I mention fresh?

Atmosphere = 3.5: Totally minimalist.  Just go for the fresh fish!!!
author: Eddie L.

description: After returning from a two week vacation in Indonesia (where food service was amazing and food just as amazing), I was spoiled but still wanted some sushi. I went to this place in my neighborhood and called ahead. The guy is usually always rude when answering the phone but I deal with it because it's so close and the sushi is good. I thought maybe they were super busy when I called, but when I arrived it was dead. He was just sitting there with his hands crossed. I paid for my food, walked out, said thank you once. Said it again louder, and finally got a response from the sushi chef.  I used to come here once a week, but enough is enough. There are three equally great sushi restaurants literally blocks away, you need to raise the bar to stay in the game. I'll be referring my colleagues elsewhere when they come into town. So many great hard working restaurants that deserve my money.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Sakana is my favorite sushi place near Union Square. I work a block away and eat here at least 1-2 times a week :-) The service is great, they just start my rolls as soon as I walk thru the door which is awesome! The fish is so fresh, the rolls are fat (how I like 'em) and the beer is ICE cold. It's a cool atomosphere, and the staff knows the menu extremely well.. the sushi chefs are very friendly, helpful guys too! ...

 Talk about going above and beyond. I brought my girlfriend in one night for dinner, and the she was telling the sushi chef how she was looking for an apartment in the city that takes dogs.. the next time we went to Sakana, he had printed up 3 pages of dog friendly apartments!! It was very sweet (he may have thought she was cute too) .. but anyway! Great Fish!

 I'd recommend the Dragon Roll, Spicy Scallop, & Hamachi Negi :-)
author: Jessica C.

description:
THE FRESHEST SUSHI I HAVE EVER HAD! 
god, so so good!!!!!
our service was good... place was half full. 
god, so so fresh!!!!
author: Bec A.

description: Favorite sushi place in the city! Delicious sashimi at a reasonable price. I get take out there all the time. Nice sized cuts of sashimi, fresh and yummy : ) the waiter is nice and to the point there as well. It's never packed which I cannot believe. Other places are just way too overrated!
author: Michelle G.

description:
Don't let Sakana's plain appearance deter you from dropping in. Though it's tiny, far from fancy and they don't do Americanized 'designer' maki, Sakana serves up some of San Francisco's best sushi. How do I know? I can thank my concierge friend at the Westin St. Francis for the hot tip.

To try:
Hamachi kama (grilled yellowtail collar - beautiful presentation!)
Maguro goma tataki (seared ahi tuna with spicy sauce - d-friggin'-licious!)
Spicy scallop roll (fresh, mild flavor)
Spicy tuna roll (you can really taste the freshness of the tuna!)

Our bill for two came to about $60 including edamame, nigiri, the aforementioned and a couple beers. Really, a steal for sushi this excellent. We were escorted to a table immediately on a Thursday evening and our server was efficient and unobtrusive. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
Rating really 3.5
Very good Japanese cuisine. Minus points are ambiance and the Nigori Sake is far too sweet for my taste
author: Andreas C.

description: Sakana has beautiful fresh fish both local and flown in from Japan daily. It is cozy place with a great staff. Their prices are the best in Union Square. They should be charging a lot more but I am very happy they don't. Sakana is definitely for traditional-style sushi lovers
author: Concierge J.

description:
While on vacation in San Fran I was craving sushi. So I polled my yelp friends to find the best spot in the downtown San Fran area. Sakana Sushi & Grill came up in my search with rave reviews. My sister, her husbad & I decided to check it out. 

Well let's just say I was very disappointed. We walked in and were seated immediately which was great but after that the whole experience went downhill. We waited for like 15/20 minutes for a waiter to come by and take our drink order which was pretty frustrating. The restaurant was very loud and it really felt like the couple sitting next to us were actually sitting with us. I mean I heard everything that they talked about on their first date. Finally we placed our order and waited for our sushi to arrive with extreme anticipation. The food prep took a bit longer than expected but once it arrived we began to grub. Unfortunately the sushi quality was lacking there is nothing I hate more than eating warm sushi and that is what was served. I didn't even eat anything I ordered it just grossed me out :( 

I was so embarressed because yelp let me down and I claimed I knew the best place to go and that's why we went and then it was just so bad.
author: Danielle G.

description: Good service, Ok Sushi!
author: Chanell S.

description:
The uni was piled on layer upon layer! OMG! I was soooo happy. Uni makes me happy...as I take the nigiri apart and slurp it up slice by slice, sucking it between my teeth, rolling it across the roof of my mouth, savoring each bite!

Everything else was good too, but nothing stood out as spectacular. The spot is small, but cute. The prices are average. I'd definitely go back.
author: Helen L.

description: Amazing sushi.  A rice snob so I just wanted to say that the rice was delicious!!!! Best place ever and the cost is more than fair
author: Diane C.

description:
Sushi was average at best. We ordered an ahi tuna appetizer with 5 pieces. My boyfriend and I ate two pieces and noticed that they were burnt. We sent it back and the waiter said he could take off 10% off of the bill since we "ate half of it". I'm sorry, what? 

Waiter was rude. Will not be coming back.
author: Michelle V.

description:
Walked here for a quick dinner before heading out on the town....

Prices are decent
Service was decent
More than a few Veg options
Not crowded on a Wed at 645pm

Food:
Futo Maki - tasty, large and in charge
Vegetarian Roll - great combo of flavors
Yamaimo Ume-Ae - not at all what I expected. This may be an acquired taste or even an acquired sight, but seeing slime on your starchy veg is unsettling to me
Wasabi- can this lose its potency over time? I was eating this like candy with lil effect

My bf had lacking taste buds due to an allergy attack from our dusty hotel room

Location:
When you leave this place be sure you know what direction to head. The green tea after dinner gave me the energy to practically run and we still got swooped on by someone I assume was on crack, dispensing love advice for a small fee....

We could not hail a cab fast enough!
author: Leticia G.

description:
Pretty good sushi. Service is ok. Ambiance is ok. Prices were great.

I didn't see anything really special to order here so I stuck to the usual: spicy tuna roll, California roll, and salmon sushi. I thought that the California roll was the best. The others were good. Fish tasted fresh so that's good!
author: Cindy B.

description: Great fresh sushi.  Omakase was a great value.  Service was lacking a bit as they were understaffed but will definitely be back a lot.
author: Jay H.

description: Great place to get your sushi fix. We had the omakase, which was the perfect assortment of sushi to share. The uni (sea urchin) is a must-try. Salmon roe with a quail egg was also quite excellent, though they didn't quite separate the whites from the yolk too well. I also enjoyed their hamachi negi roll - they don't skimp on the hamachi!
author: Jamie C.

description:
Very fresh and great atmosphere.

Small place, less then 20 tables. 

check hours of operation before heading over, sometimes they are not open when you are really craving. 

HIGHLY recommended.
author: Donny K.

description: This place was pretty great. We had a party of 4 who got say fairly quick. It was busy for a Tuesday night, so that was a good sign. We had the bacon wrapped scallops, seared tuna, Cali roll, 49roll, and a crunch roll. It was all delicious, and served quickly. The two main chefs up front were quick, and fun to watch. If you have a large group I suggest making a reservation as the seating area is small.
author: Kayla R.

description: Great value and super fresh fish. I really liked the grilled yellow tail collar, salmon sashimi (I'm not even a huge fan of salmon in general), and agadashi tofu. I enjoyed the rolls a bit less than the other dishes.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Reasonable price with good quality of fish and service are excellent.  I recommend order import fish from japan they are very fresh.
author: Naruethep R.

description:
Fresh and delicious sushi and appetizers served at this cozy joint.
Spicy scallop roll, spider roll, tuna bomb roll, fried squid legs, deep fried oysters (damn good), and any of their grilled fish including mackerel and cod. Go grub.
author: Hyuk L.

description:
Had the dragon, spicy scallops, and rainbow rolls, the uni and hamachi nigiri, and seaweed salad. The rolls were pretty standard. Spicy scallop roll did live up to its name though - pretty spicy. The uni was not fresh and had this peroxide-like after taste (sad face), but the hamachi was good - buttery and sweet.

Overall, the service was pretty good, but the food unspectacular. Don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Alice W.

description: Excellent service, delicious sushi and nice environment. Can't really fault this establishment, hence 5 stars.
author: Dave T.

description:
Smaller menu with all the classics.  All the food was delicious and priced well.  The tempura is done perfectly.  There is also a limited selection of non-sushi items.  Service was good and prompt.  
The dining room is on the smaller side, so it's great for a date or close quarters interaction - not a great spot for larger groups though.
author: Rome B.

description:
Long story short: not a bad place, fish was fresh at moderate prices

Long story long:

We decided to have dinner here because we wanted to get sushi, and we originally tried a place that was on the next block over, but the wait there was long wait, plus this place was on the quieter side, which after a long day, ended up being better for all of us.

Simple layout with simple but your typical decor for what you'd expect from a sushi house.  They had a sushi bar in the corner and tables spread throughout.

We started off with green tea.  After a couple of minutes, we ordered and I got a chirashi bowl and a shrimp tempura roll.

Our food arrived and everything looked very good.  The fish on my chirashi bowl was fresh and adequately sized.  I can't stand places that charge you a similar price for small cuts of fish.  It's annoying and a ripoff.  My shrimp tempura roll was good too.  The shrimp was cooked just right and the tempura batter was nice and crunchy and not too thick or oily.  That's another pet peeve... Places that put a ton of batter on the tempura.

Our server was nice and was attentive with the water.  You all know how much of a stickler I am with that.

I would probably come back here.
author: Austin S.

description: We read the reviews. We walked by the restaurant. We sat at the bar. We ordered the sashimi omakase for two. We also had hamachi kama. We added a Natto Handroll and one order each of Toro and Salmon. We did not have any issues with service even though all three staff that we saw appeared to be Japanese men with longish hair. We ate. We enjoyed. We will be back.
author: Dexter D.

description:
I probably eat at Sakana's once a week. Their Sushi is always fresh and the service is consistently friendly.
An unpretentious little spot!
author: Bogee B.

description:
Would not come here again.

I ordered chicken terryaki--chicken breast was dry--tasted like wooden chopsticks, and I can't tell if it was actually grilled.  Terryaki sauce was kind of thrown on.  This dinner came with a side salad and miso dressing, miso soup, and rice, all of which were fine. This cost $10.50 (as opposed to $5 or $6) and was totally not worth it.
author: Sandra C.

description: So we love this place for the sashimi. One of my huge pet peeves with sushi restaurants is when they choose to serve paper thin slices of "sashimi" and call it good. It is such a waste because for many of my favorite fishes without a decent chuck you do not get the flavor at all. This place has a wonderful approach and even though the plates are typically chefs choice they are always accommodating when you let the know if you don't like specific fish. The place is small however and reservation do fill it up so plan ahead if your going to com here during peak times.
author: Meg N.

description: The food was actually pretty good, unfortunately the service was horrible. Slow, inattentive, and rude.  They struggled to sit us because we had a larger party and threw us some dirty looks. No one smiled or greeted us. They constantly seemed to be in a rush and never made eye contact. They auto tip on parties of 5 or more.
author: Vay V.

description:
Quick, easy and delicious. That's how I would describe my experience with Sakana.

Popped in here a few nights ago to grab some sushi and they were happy to oblige. The Owl Tree next door was so fun that I didn't want to tear myself away from it. Unfortunately, my grumbly tummy had other ideas for me. So, after obtaining permission from our kind bartender, I ran over to Sakana to check out their menu.

Went for the Spider Roll, as San Fran offers much fresher crab than we usually get in St. Louis. This roll was no exception! Within 10 minutes, I had a nice sized roll packed in a to go box, complete with ginger, wasabi and soy sauce. Done!

Polished off the Spider Roll at the bar in no time flat, which gave me the energy to continue to bop my head and shake my shoulders to the awesome tunes back at Owl Tree. Snaps to both!
author: Abby S.

description: The fish was fresh all right, but was served on sushi rice that wasn't cooked. I never had sushi rice that tasted this bad before. Upon letting the staff know, they simply apologized and said it was because they were so busy today that they rushed the rice out without cooking it thoroughly. That shouldn't be an excuse! They didn't offer us any compensation, but said if we want to order additional sushi, they'd serve us the nigiri with a side of rice, which was properly cooked, instead. Wow. I'll just take my business to Ryoko's next time, thanks.
author: Pantry B.

description:
Wow - really...great...sushi!! Even for vegetarians!

Came here on a Saturday night with 5 others based on yelp reviews and we were not disappointed!

Two of us are vegetarian and we loved the Futo Maki and Veggie Rolls. I also loved the burdock salad which is a favorite of mine and I order every time I find it on a menu.

Everyone else loved the spicy tuna rolls so much that they all ordered another round - each! Same for the Tuna Bomb Roll which also had a second round!

So glad we came and that I have a new favorite place to enjoy dinner downtown!
author: Ennis O.

description: So I was slightly skeptical when I stepped into this place, because it's so casual and bright. I was looking for the dimly lit upscale sushi experience.  But I was so wrong.  First of all, service fantastic and welcoming, which is so appreciated on vacation.  Secondly, my husband and I ate a lot - all of which was delicious, but nothing compares to the 49ers roll.  You must order it.  You are insane if you step foot in this place and do not order this roll.  It's been a week and I'm still dreaming about it.  It's all about the lemon wedge they place on top of the salmon.
author: Courtney B.

description: Great sushi and we know sushi. Fresh and affordable with quick service no frills just sushi and food. Good selection of cold saki
author: Mike K.

description:
My experience at this establishment was great! The atmosphere is very quaint and chill. The service was impressive in that they stayed on top of my beverage and order without crowding me. The sushi was visually appealing and tasted perfect! It was absolutely fantastic!!!

Bottom line: it's my new favorite sushi joint.

:)
author: Jason B.

description: Traveling solo and I tried to get into a sushi place up the street that was jam packed. Spotted an empty seat in here and decided to go in. Quick service and tasty sushi rolls. Casual with no frills but great for a quick meal!
author: Emily W.

description: Very small .. Kind of dark and dingy-ish .. The sushi and service was ok. The rolls and nigiri were good. Kind of sloppily name. Kind of skimped on the fish .. We had to order more just to be satisfied. We sat at the sushi bar and anytime the door opened, the sushi chef would grunt an indeterminable one syllable greeting without looking up for more than a flick. Meh. Not terrible but definitely nothing special.
author: stefanie v.

description: This place is phenomenal! Place has great vibes and people are so friendly. There are a lot of sushi restaurants in the neighborhood but this one is the best one by far. Must go if you love real Japanese Food!
author: Luke O.

description:
Yea, this place is good! You can eat OMAKASE(chef's special) sushi only for $25 and I couldn't believe when I went to this place at first time!(Even thogh sushi place(Japanese owner) in Harlem,NY cost $55 for OMAKASE)

For sure, I've tried. 
- The NETA(fish part called like this) is very fresh and flavorful but not smells fishy(means fresh). Only sea urchin was a bit bitter by alum(dont worry its natural food grade alum must be used, and for all of sea urchin) but you still can taste sweetness of sea urchin afterwards. 

- SHARI(rice part) was ok. shapes were not so even(Its important when you bring sushi in your mouth, it makes quite difference in texture) and SHARI was grabbed a bit too tight(its also important, SHARI should be not break when you hold but once you bring sushi in your mouth, shari should be like melt in your mouth).

but, why not! I definitely recommend this place for you! You can eat good sushi(even though there are so many places called sushi restaurant but they do not serve real sushi. Thats like rice ball with piece of fish) only for $25! Isn't it amazing!? 

P.s. you must order Deep fried oysters too:)
author: Oso S.

description:
Get in early because it is a small place. I got the hamachi Kama, spinach goma-ae, and chefs choice sashimi. 
Let's start with he spinach- flavorful, hearty and delicious (I am going to say that a lot)
Chefs choice is always a craps shoot but they didn't disappoint  with a good good cross section of fish that was very fresh and simple 
I love hamachi Kama!! And sometimes it's hard to find a good one well Sakana makes a perfect one ( the kind you don't need sauce to drown the bad taste of the fish) it was light and cooked to perfection. 
I highly recommend you try Sakana whenever possible. I think I might come again tomorrow!
author: Patrick M.

description: Favorite sushi in SF. Always a must do when we're in town. Fast and friendly service, and delicious food. An unexpected surprise: amazing crab cakes. Try them!
author: J P.

description: This is my go to place for authentic Japanese sushi.  It's usually crowded, and it's really Japanese.  High quality, reasonably priced, and fresh.   If you like crappy Korean or Chinese sushi, you will not appreciate this place.  True sushi lovers will know what I mean.  Atmosphere is no frills but very clean.  Arigatou!
author: Kyle K.

description:
Although this place is pretty decent, I have to give it 3 stars because the waiter was quite rude to us.

My friend and I walked into the restaurant.. it was empty. We asked to sit at a table that seated 4 people and he said NO.

I chuckled a little bit and asked him if he was serious (thinking he wasn't) and he said that he was serious.

So he sat us at a two person table and walked away. I was not feeling this guy at all from the get-go and this confirmed that he was a major douche.

The rest of the experience was so so... but I would not go out of my way to eat here again due to his rudeness!

Aside from that the food was standard, I can't complain about that.
author: C C.

description: Amazing fresh sushi for an affordable price. Downside is that it's small, not very good for groups, and the server was rather rude.
author: Prasetyo S.

description: Service was really good. We like the was wasabi roll the best and also spicy crunch and Cajun roll. Great wine!
author: Debbie G.

description:
Fresh fish. Delicious Scallop roll. Mushy rice. Indifferent waitstaff. Spicy bomb roll NOT spicy. Vegetable tempura sauce so good - but sadly the vegetables piddly. 

With the options in this city not returning...
author: Walrus C.

description:
I should have known when I walked in and didnt see any Asian people. Jk... maybe. Well maybe more that it was a Saturday at 6:00 and the restaurant was only a quarter full. 

Ordered the sushi combo and a couple extra rolls. Nothing memorable. The sushi pieces were small. 

Pros: clean, fast, attentive staff
Cons: small pieces, stingy tempera breading on the crunchy roll

On another note, there is a fine line between being an attentive waiter and making me feel uncomfortable because I'm being watched my whole meal.... 

Nothing I would come back for.
author: Elaine L.

description: Huge and thick pieces of fresh fish cut by a chef in a Guns N Roses teeshirt. Need I say more?
author: Tanya B.

description: Great late night stop.  Very friendly service.  I'm not a connoisseur, but I like what I had.
author: Neal W.

description:
Fresh fish, great cuts and prices that don't bleed you dry. The quality's consistent, and we love coming here. I hardly ever encounter a wait (can't say the same about Cocobang across the street), and it's also open late on Fridays and Saturdays.

One slight drawback is the tuna. I would prefer to eat actual cuts of it, but it comes in the style of spicy tuna (minced, typically tuna trimmings). Minus that, this is a great sushi joint in the Tenderloin.
author: M S.

description: Loved it. We stopped in here starving after a concert and we were not disappointed. We had seared tuna as an appetizer and I think the spider and dragon rolls. Everything was delicious. Seating is limited and service is just ok, but for the price you are more than getting your money's worth.
author: Marie D.

description: Very nice place. Not very expensive, sushi rolls flavorful and quick to come. We sat at the bar and enjoyed a few rolls and some miso soup and a quick, delicious and healthy meal. We will come back.
author: Anne M.

description:
Came to Sakana after reading the good reviews  - but left hungry and disappointed.  We were seated promptly as we had reservations; however, had to wait forever before we were waited on.  Ordered the wakame salad, spicy tuna, and a few nigiris to start off (toro, ebi, yellow tail, grouper...) - the wakame salad was eh, spicy tuna was decent but i've had much better, the nigiris were the biggest disappointment (lacked that fresh taste and the rice was soggy and fell apart). I actually spat out the toro as it tasted weird - felt worse after looking at the check - did i really spit out $5????
We were still hungry but decided not to risk any further let down.  Sakana will not be a repeat visit -  service is lacking and there is nothing spectacular about their food either. I'd recommend walking over to Ryoko's (a bit of a wait for obvious reasons), Sanraku, or Sushi Rika.
author: Bhavnak K.

description: This is reasonably priced and just what the doctor ordered!!! Rainbow roll caterpillar roll vegetable tempura very good!
author: Niah N.

description:
Another reason I love yelp. Exhausted post-christmas, hanging around the hotel with my girlfriend's brothers and sister, and someone asks, "are there any good sushi places within walking distance?" 

Thank you to previous yelp reviewers. I opted for sashimi and it was fresh with huge portions, especially considering the location (union square tourist hell).
author: Mike V.

description:
I'm not quite sure what I can say about Sakana to express how much I love it. The atmosphere is wonderful, the service is impeccable, and the sushi is out-of-this-world and the price is right. 

They have the best spicy tuna roll I have ever had, and I recommend the spicy tuna roll with jalapeno.
author: Cody R.

description: Excellent sushi place! Walking distance from our hotel. Prompt service sushi was very fresh and tasty! Miso soup was great! I would definitely visit here more often if I lived in the area.
author: Tyler Q.

description: Fish was fresh and rice was actually soft unlike other sushi restaurants I've been to.
author: Tina W.

description:
I'm torn since I LOVE Ryoko (which is right around the corner) however Ryoko is not open for lunch and often has a ridiculous wait even at 8pm or 9pm.

So I was a little sad when I tried to go to Ryoko but my dining partner was starving and didn't want to endure the wait so we ended up at Sakana. It was the third time I had eaten here, with the other two times being for lunch when I work on-site for my marketing client.

Their list of rolls of rolls is fairly simple but all of the ones I've tried have been tasty and utilized very fresh fish. The sake is also good.

I've always had great service here. With the only exception being having to ask for more water rather than having it refilled automatically, but otherwise friendly and attentive even during a bustling lunch hour or a somewhat busy dinner service.
author: Dani D.

description:
Friend was running late so I sat there by myself for about half an hour. The wait staff was beyond accommodating. They never rushed me and made sure my water was full at all times. One of the waiters even asked me if I am at the right place, since there are several sushi restaurants around that area... what a sweetie. 

We ordered the sashimi and 49er roll. Both were very good! Thumbs up to the thin slice of lemon on top of the 49er roll! 

It's a nice casual place for sushi/japanese food.
author: Emily T.

description: Fantastic service but the food, though good, isn't anything special. Pretty standard menu, portions are on the small side but prices are decent for SF.
author: Erin O.

description: Came back here after a long hiatus. We actually brought my inlaws here and the fish was so buttery and fresh. It's not a budget sushi place but on the same token they execute really well. My inlaws love a place that I will not mention in the Peninsula that is well known for their portions it really puts things in perspective on how good the quality is here for the sashimi and nigiri. I love that they also have the specials that we were able to try such as long neck clams and abalone. The best thing we ordered was the Sashimi combo which every piece of sashimi was buttery and delicious.
author: Hyung L.

description: Fantastic sushi.  I would have given it 5 stars if the waiter guy learned how to smile.  Not letting you sit at a table because you are alone does help either.
author: Boris G.

description:
I have no idea if the food is good BUT I am extremely disappointed that this restaurant's hours are CLEARLY listed as serving lunch on weekdays.  One featured review here specifically mentions the great lunch specials!

I arranged for a centrally located business meeting over lunch today (Wednesday) and picked Sakana based on Yelp info.  Luckily I arrived 5 min early the place but the place was CLOSED and the hours on a little sign hanging in the window had NO LUNCH HOURS AT ALL.  

I scrambled to find another place nearby (mediocre btw) and call the 4 people coming separately with a new address.  Made me stressed before a meeting and to look uninformed ... this is not what I expect of a restaurant OR from Yelp.
author: M P.

description: Visited Sakana for the first time and had great, fresh sushi. The service was quick and attentive. I recommends Sakana for a quality sushi meal.
author: Leron B.

description: The food was great and the service was exquisite. My girlfriend forgot her credit card and the waiter tracked us down and gave it back to her.
author: Even H.

description:
Now please bear with me as I am from Cleveland and have not experienced more than 10 sushi restaurants locally. I am by no means an expert on sushi. I must say that Sakana was some of the best tasting sushi I have ever had!

While on our trip to California last week my wife and I made the choice to head to this nice quaint place about 400 feet from our hotel (Serrano) and boy did we luck out. We had a short wait for Friday evening and were seated at the bar. Fortunately, we are very adventurous and tried a mixure of sashimi and rolls. The chef had a great sense of humor and made us one of his specialties that was out of this world.

The price and quality of both the food and service were great. I highly recommend this to anyone in the area as it is now our favorite spot. We plan to visit more often partly because we had so much fun and ate very well here.
author: Damien C.

description:
Pros:
- Beef tataki (yum!)
- Got seated right away (on a Monday night)
- Good rolls
- Decent price, although some of the appetizers are on the smaller side

Cons:
- Karaage (Japanese style fried chicken), that is NOT what karaage should taste like. It was very disappointing. 
- Too quiet. granted we went on a monday night, but it was just a little too silent for us

Thought I'd be blown away by the small dishes here based on the yelp reviews.. Maybe I'll have to try more of the sashimi and nigiri next time.
author: Akiko E.

description:
And this is why I love Yelp. During our recent stay in SF, I used my handy dandy Yelp app to find a Japanese restaurant in the area and stumbled upon all the great reviews of Sakana. The restaurant is pretty small so make reservations if you're going during peak times, especially on the weekend. We were lucky that they were able to accommodate our party of five (not just a 90's TV show) on a Saturday night since I saw they had to turn away a couple walk-ins because the restaurant was full.

We started off with a bunch of appetizers but my favorite was the tempura soft-shell crab...pieces of soft-shell crab battered and deep fried. You cannot go wrong.
