The sushi was also fresh and fairly inexpensive for a city. For dinner, I chose the unagi don and it was perfect for a cold night  - hot rice and three pieces of saucy unagi. Mmmmm...! I definitely recommend coming here to get your Japanese fix!
author: Kawena K.

description:
0 stars!!!
Poor service & fish not fresh...they have the nerve to add the gratitude themselves.
DO NOT GO THERE UNLESS U WANT TO BE MIS-TREATED and paying for it!!!
author: Cons T.

description: Saldana sushi is absolutely amazing. The first sushi place I hit while on vacation here and I don't think I could have picked a better location. The prices were a bit up there, but also I have to take into location. But it was easily worth it. The food was delicious and the people serving were super nice. You can't go wrong with this place.
author: Kyle G.

description: Great sushi everywhere in union square but the ramen is also great here and a good variety of options.   Not too fancy but not too casual or loud either.  They don't take Amex.
author: Mike P.

description: Great & fresh sushi. I sat at the sushi bar by myself and ordered the Japan flown in fish. Chef recommended sashimi style and it was great. The spicy scallop roll is highly recommended. But good food comes with a higher price. If you order off the regular menu you can get away with $$ but Japan flown in fish brings you to $$$ not including alcohol.
author: Ed Y.

description: The food was good. I liked the menu, and the chef seemed to have good sanitary skills with the fish. We waited about 45 minutes for a table. It is not a place for the ambiance or environment for date night, but good food.
author: Tyler C.

description:
WORST PLACE EVERRRRR !!
staff is so rude. specially the guy
sushi chews more than a bubble gum chicken is PLASTIC THE RICE IS LIKE A SOUP !! 
the smell is owful even their water and  the cocacola !!
author: Abdulrahman A.

description:
Amazing sushi. Hands down. Hiro is a genius :)!
I mostly order take out from here since I go to school/work in the neighborhood. the spicy tuna roll combo is out of this world. I also love the variety of veggies they have for tempura. Usually it's your regular carrot, onion, zuccini and maybe green beans but they use at least 5-6 different veggies. 

Is this place the top best sushi place in san francisco? probably not. But this place is always consistent. The service is great and the prices are fair considering you're eating out in union square. 

I highly recommend this place. If you're a sushi snob or looking for a nice, intimate place to eat in the heart of downtown san francisco, check sanaku out.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Miammm...well deserved sushi after a long day of school.

The freshness of their uni really surprised us!!!

They have a lot of different kind of fish imported from Japan. The service was good and the restaurant was really clean!

We had a good time there!

We will be back :)
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Very pleased to happen upon this hole in the wall when the hotel we chose for our SF trip was a block away. 
We ordered one of everything off the sushi special catch of the season menu and all of the fish was super fresh and tasty. 
This is the kind of place you want to find if you are particular about fish, not rolls, and order some fish you've never tried before! 
Butterfish, black porgy, sea bream and the list goes on.
Delicious!!
author: joshua h.

description:
Thank you, Yelp, for helping us find this wonderful neighborhood sushi place during our last 24 hour trip to SFO.  We checked in (without a reservation) to the Westin around 10:00pm and I quickly consulted my phone app for sushi after dropping the bags.  I had a good feeling when Sakana came up.  It was close by, but maybe an extra half block than some others but the high ratings, name, and reviews resonated with my inner pescaterian.  My out dated iPhone and my ancient lust for sushi guided us to this cozy , unpretentious, but somehow hip and very inviting sushi bar.   The sushi was phenomenal!  The service was very warm and friendly.  The rolls arrived quickly.  The home made green tea flan that we split as a desert was delightful as well.  
As we ate the place started to fill up.  It's open till 1 AM.  Thanks yelp for helping us find THE place to go for late night sushi on Post during our last whimsical 24 hour stay in SFO!
author: Jon W.

description: Great little hidden place. Good service and quality food. Better than the other sushi places in the area.
author: K B.

description: The sushi rolls were so fresh and tasty!  We were visiting the area and just happened to walk up on this place.  We sat at the bar and placed our order for sushi.  The place is really small and stays busy and packed.  Our sushi came out really quick.  I ordered the roll with eel, shrimp and avocado.  Yummy!!!
author: Yolanda C.

description:
DELICIOUS UDON!

Jimmy R. & I were craving ramen at the end of a long day and decided to hit up Katana-Ya. Unfortunately there was a gigantic wait time so we began wandering the area (with the help of Yelp) to find another place to eat. After another 15 minutes or so of wandering, we were both getting hungry and every place seemed to have an extremely long wait, so whilst standing on the corner of Post and Taylor trying to search for yet another place to eat, we saw Sakana Sushi and decided to try our luck. The wait was only 10 minutes so we were sold.

We both had the tempura udon and split an order of amaebi (sweet shrimp) nigiri.

Tempura Udon was amazing. The tempura was perfectly fried and the combination of the noodles, broth, and tempura was just absolutely scrumptious.

The amaebi was tasty, too. Sweet and delectable. And the head was fried to perfection, making another nice fried addition to my tempura.

Friendly service, affordable prices, & clean bathrooms are lovely bonuses.

Try the udon!
author: Claire L.

description: This restaurant has a very cozy, intimate setting. It's also small, and when it's busy, don't expect service to be really fast, but they do try their best to get to you as quickly as possible. My friend and I ordered 2 appetizers (agedashi tofu and karaage), 1 maki (spicy tuna), and 2 special roll (spider and 49ers). They were all good, but honestly nothing struck me as particularly excellent. You can watch the chef make the sushi behind the counter, so that's something special there.
author: Angus C.

description: Good tasting sushi at a very reasonable price. I know it's a "beginner" roll but had the best California roll I've ever had. All 4 rolls tried were at least decent. My only knock is the tables are very tightly spaced. Hope the table next to you isn't obnoxious because you'll hear their whole convo. I'd probably sit at the bar if I went back. Decent service.
author: Jude W.

description:
I've been here four or five times and everything was great each time I went. The set up inside is a little dull, but I go out to eat good food not stare at interior decor so that's not an issue for me. Service comes when you need it to and food is made relatively quickly. The food is great. I've never had a bad experience when it came to quality. Fish is always super fresh and the sushi chefs seem to be pretty good (I've been to places where they add too much wasabi, have lower quality sushi rice, slice the fish too thin/thick, etc - didn't have those problems here). I've met one of the sushi chefs, Kenji, when he came to the Japanese place I worked at and he's a nice dude inside the workplace and out. The prices are pretty standard, not too different than the competition (cheap sushi boat places and the like are NOT competition, by the way). They always have a table for me as well even when Sanraku and Ryoko's have a line forming outside. 

Overall, I've never exactly been wowed, but I really have no complaints. Great sushi spot.
author: Steven I.

description:
I come here regularly and often get takeout. Their Philly Roll is delicious! I always find that their nigiri sushi come with too little rice, so I usually just go with the rolls.

I love the staff! One of the main waiters is consistently grumpy, but his frown grows on you. I wouldn't want it any other way.

Gets very busy around dinner time.
author: Tizia B.

description: nothing impressive from the outside, and even less impressive on the inside, but it's a solid sushi bar offering the standard rolls and individual pieces you'd expect, along with a selection of the normal hot menu options.  Seating is really tight, so this place is best for popping in for a quick bite white walking by.  If there's no seating, it's not worth waiting for a table, but if you're in the mood for a solid plate of sushi, you could do a lot worse than grabbing a free seat here.
author: Ron H.

description:
This is my neighborhood restaurant (within 1 block) I go often.  Their food is not spectacular but not bad either...
There are few things I like...

1. The restaurant look and feel like a modern restaurant in Japan.
2. The waitress asks me when I want Miso soup.  I guess when they found out I'm Japanese, they started to ask me the question.  We Japanese do not eat soup first before the main dish come.  (I can write an essay on orders of food served in Japanese cuisine) 
3. They use clean oil to frying Agedashidofu, Karaage, Tenpura, Katsu, etc..
4. They have Shochu by bottle!
5. Good selection of appetizers.
6. Their sushi rice is good (good acidity level)
7. Their Katsudon has soft cooked eggs with light broth.  Not too sweet like Dojimaan ( http://www.yelp.com/biz/dojima-ann-san-francisco#hrid:2s432seNrQsRD1x-9VjUnA ).

There are a few things I don't like about Sakana

1. Tenpura include American sweet potato not Japanese sweet potato.  Big difference...
2. Daikon on Chirashizushi.  To take up the space?  I never saw that in Japan...
3. Sashimi and Chirashizushi's fish is sliced not nicely.  Look like leftover pieces... I guess I cannot complain at this price... but the way you cut/slice fish is VERY VERY VERY important.  Fish taste different depend on how they are sliced (cutting into the muscle fiber? Etc). Also bigger piece you chew longer, vs smaller pieces you chew less... and fish tastes different depends on how long you chew it.  I can write another essay on this subject as well.
4. Their Donburi dishes do not come with Oshinko/Tsukemono (pickled vegetable) on the side.

Overall I'll give Sakana 3.64 stars

Oh, unrelated to Sakana but I have a question.... Why so many Americans drink Nigori sake with sushi?????
author: Chie J.

description: We aren't sushi experts or anything but we sort of ended here the other night because we didn't feel like waiting for the Italian place across the street or a steakhouse around the corner.  Thank goodness we stumbled into this tiny place.  We waited for about ten minutes for seats but it was the whole time we were there.  Wife loved the warm sake.  I enjoyed the miso.  She said it was the best sushi she's had and I was brave enough to try some rolls I've never been brave enough to try back home.  I guess I trusted that SF has better quality ingredients than AZ.  Go figure.  Anyways, we loved it so much that we seriously considered dinner again the next night in spite of only having three dinner nights in San Francisco to sample what was there on our vacation.  If we're back in SF, we will definitely be back to Sakana!
author: Paul S.

description: Sushi quality is pretty good.  Not very creative.  And not much for ambiance.  This is not an experience.  But the sushi was good and seemed pretty fresh (and we are pretty picky).  But this isn't an impressive date night place.  More like a neighborhood joint to get a sushi fix.  It's really a 3.5 but I can only give 3 or 4 stars.
author: Aimee F.

description:
The quality is good, but the service is 'eh," and the prices for dinner are just too high for the portion size.

I ordered the deluxe nigiri here a few weeks ago, and it was pretty good, other than everything being tiny and the set being on the pricey side. It may be on the good side for SF sushi, but I really miss the quality and value in the Japanese areas of Silicon Valley and Los Angeles. :(
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
Stopped in during a work trip this past week as I do each time I'm in San Francisco for business. I can confirm that this is a small no frills location to eat, but I'm there for the food first. Don't go with a big party (5 or more) and don't expect candlelight.

I also would defend the service. I've never had anyone be rude to me. In fact, this trip I happened to glance toward the restaurant and the waiter came over with edamame and apologized for the wait, which he did again when served me. I will continue to return, and it's OK with me if this spot stays hidden to locals and a few in the know.
author: Mike D.

description: Favorite sushi place in SF. I highly recommend calling ahead to grab a seat, even if you're only a couple people and on your way. The best matcha green tea I've had in a restaurant that wasn't a specialty item. Fish is usually very fresh, good varied specials, friendly staff, reasonable pricing. They have a great selection of very basic veggie rolls too, which I love - oshinko (pickled daikon), ume (pickled plum), gobo (burdock), kampyo (gourd). The Saba Gari (mackerel and pickedl ginger) is great and they have really tasty futomaki and inari. The ankimo (monkfish liver) is usually very good as well.
author: Green T.

description:
Always good sushi keeps me coming back to Sakana.

This tiny sushi bar serves all types- from the tourists that have wandered over from nearby Union Square, to locals, to Japanese business men.

UPDATE 4/2006:
The fried squid here is VERY good. Don't miss it. Also the goma-ae.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Wowzers! Fantastic sushi! And fantastic prices! I personally ordered:

Tamago Nigiri-awesome, the egg was freshly cooked and yummy as hell. just sweet enough without being too crazy.

Ebi Tempura Roll - The shrimp was awesome, fried perfectly.

Ume Maki - Ok, I had to try a "sour plum paste" roll. I dont think there are many people that could resist. This thing doesnt look like much when it comes out but it is like a flavor explosion when you bite into it. It tastes exactly like sour plums. very interesting and im very glad I tried it, but I dont think I will order it again. I do suggest everyone atleast try it!

I also tried the eel roll and a hand wrapped spicy tuna roll. Both were amazing. And dont forget to have some Miso soup! Way better than any other miso I have tried!

I look forward to coming back!
author: Nelson S.

description: Great, fresh fish with cool sushi chefs.  Sat at the bar & felt right at home.  Will be back soon.
author: Christopher E.

description: Fast service and the fish seemed fresh. Could have been trimmed a little better (got a few tough end bits) which is the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars.
author: Steve M.

description:
Maybe we just happened to be unlucky, but the waiter was rude.  He grabbed my jacket and bag abruptly to move them without asking beforehand and my DSLR (Nikon D700 + glass), which was wrapped in the jacket, almost dropped to the floor.  If I hadn't reacted quickly, it would have been a costly incident.  He realized what could have happened but didn't apologize.

Later on my friend clearly *pointed* out one of the dishes on the menu, but he kept rudely asking for more and more clarification.  He was paranoid about bringing the wrong dish and let us know it over and over again.

We really wanted to leave at a few points during our meal, but realized that other restaurant staff were okay.  The sushi bar guy seemed nice, for example.  I think I'm going back with my husband (who's Japanese American and can speak a little bit), to see if there's any rhyme or reason to his behavior.
author: Shan L.

description:
I walked into this place on accident but it was so good and I will definitely be back. I only ordered nigiri but noticed the prices were pretty good for the rolls. I didn't wAnt to fill up on rolls. Nigiri was about five dollars for two pieces and they had some fresh fish imported from Japan that were more expensive from $5-$10 for two pieces. I had salmon, yellowtail, tuna, sweet shrimp, bonito, inari and green tea flan for dessert. Everything was fresh and delicious. For the sweet shrimp they save the heads and deep fry it in addition to the nigiri. Interesting but I didn't try the heads. 

The place itself is small and clean, in addition to the bar there was probably about 10 tables. I sat at the bar, chefs weren't too talkative which I actually like, but were helpful when you ask for recommendations.
author: lisa w.

description:
Neighbor hot spot fantastic sashimi 
The Bomb roll with jalapenos
nigori sake
 I will be bk when I am back in the bay area!
author: Brandy L.

description: Forget the decor, simply the best sushi...thanks two chefs...and the service is up there! Will be back, I hope:)
author: Bo P.

description:
0 stars for this place. My gf and I have been here a couple of times because it's close to our apt and honestly the rolls are pretty decent. The one thing that always sucks about this place though is the wait staff, they're always incredibly rude and abrupt but whatever, I don't go to restaurants to interact with waiters. Between the two of us we always spend about $80-100 on a dinner here for a few rolls and some sashimi. 

Anyways, tonight we walk in looking for a couple of quick rolls and they won't seat us because they say that we don't tip them enough! They made us leave! I've never been treated this way and will never go back (even if I could). Stay away from this place, the staff is beyond rude and judgmental.
author: Cody W.

description:
I wasn't too impressed with this place. The hamachi nigiri was good but the maguro wasn't. I hate it when the fish can't be cut in half with a simple bite or with your chopstick because there is some stringy tendon muscle action in the fish. This is what happened with my piece of maguro. 

Also, I tried the fried squid since other Yelp reviewers raved about it. Sorry but I was really disappointed. The squid was way too crunchy for me and there were way too many tentacles. I think if they cut the squid into smaller pieces and if the texture was more chewy then I might like it.
author: Helen Y.

description: Wasn't looking for anything fancy, just fresh tasty fish with good sake.  My crew and I had a very nice experience with both.  Stuck mostly to the sashimi, and mixed in some rolls and nigiri.  Not a place I would take clients to impress with atmosphere and over the top service but for a small neighborhood sushi stop it was perfect!
author: G M.

description:
The sushi here tastes ok, but is surprisingly boring. I got the sushi & sashimi combo and was disappointed by the fish selection-- many were repeated in both the sushi and sashimi, so I only got to try maybe 5 kinds of fish. Also, the fish itself was not as flavorful as other places I've been. 

There's nothing wrong with the restaurant, but given the prices and previous reviews, I was disappointed.
author: Ivana J.

description:
I swear I reviewed this place and now that I see that I haven't I feel terrible.  Love this place!


When I was working in SF this was my go to sushi joint.  I'd come here at least once a week for sushi, udon, or katsu-don.  Their combos are more than filling, especially the mini udon and katsu-don.  So much food for only $10.

Service is great and my tea cup is never empty.  =)
author: Jessica C.

description: Awesome, authentic, and flavorful food - along with great prices. Nice little gem close to union square.
author: Ally L.

description:
Had Chirashi and Toro (sushi) there.
Was not totally satisfied with Toro, but Chirashi was good.
author: Sandi W.

description: They don't even deserve 1star. They deserve 0! The Service was more than horrible. It was just worst ever!!!! These guys shouldn't do business like that. I came with my friend. We were the only patrons so far in the restaurant; yet, we still waited 10 minute before: enter the server, a Japanese guy, who came to our table to take our order. This would have been a pleasant surprise if not for his completely unprofessional manners. While most servers will wait pen and pad on hand for the order, he actually sat his ass down on the table next to us, peering down without a sound waiting for us to accommodate him  with our order. So, my friend began to order. Stop. Done with their order. Now, on to me! Stop. Where is he going? At this point, the server completely forgot (good God I assume forgot) to take my order. Maybe the server this day was new and untrained and completely not ready for the floor. Or, maybe he was being spiteful and wanted to simply piss us off. Either way, no establishment should affect any of such reactions out of their patrons. We ended up walking out before we were even served. I suggest avoiding this mess altogether and by not ever even walking in.
author: Iris C.

description:
looking forward to a great sushi dinner here...but..sadly..i was pretty disappointed...."the goods"...miso soup was oh so miso good...seaweed salad and spinach in peanut sauce was a tasty start....(but a tad too sweet).....the fried oysters were fried to perfection...but the donkatsu sauce was a bit too overwhelming....did not find it the best combination....the fried squid legs were actually very tasty....the deep fried softshell crab was a treat and the radish/soysauce mixture was the perfect dip (should have used this dip for the fried oysters).....nigiri sushi is done right here.....the sashimi is perfectly cut into a bite size morsel...with just a small perfectly shaped clump of rice...with a smear of wasabi...in between...perfection

"the bad".....maybe it was the no a/c or lack of ventilation in the place that made the perfectly crafted nigiri sushi not as tasteful....if you have read my other reviews...my pet peeve is eating sushi in a sauna....now the rolls...we ordered all the special rolls on the menu...these were the most disappointing sorry excuse for rolls i have ever seen....(only good about them were the fact that they were relatively cheap...$7+ and enormously long)....the rolls were probably the worst i've seen and tasted...

the service...hmm...okay..i can understand that they were busy...but it was difficult to flag the waitress just to get a glass of water....and forgot two of our orders...which they charged on our bill..which i politely pointed out ....they did remove it off our bill...damage...$35 per person w/o drinks...$42 per person w/drinks (beer and sake).....i would give 2 stars..but the chef's sushi crafting art was still perfection...gave 3 stars...
author: Hen A.

description:
It's so hard finding a good sushi place and one with great service. Everyone here was so sweet, I was in awe. 

Prices are cheap and the sushi is the best I've had in the area. Great place, this is my new go to sushi place and I will be recommending it to all my friends.
author: Dori B.

description: So delicious. This is the sushi I long for when I'm in my oakland neighborhood. Delicious, prompt and on point. I had nagiri and a yellow tail scallion roll. All was excellent. Beer was only $4!
author: New Biker B.

description: Neighborhood favorite. This place is consistently delicious - the fish is always fresh and amazing. Never had a bad meal here, highly recommended.
author: Lauren B.

description:
The sushi was amazing. Their spicy salmon and tuna melted in my mouth. What concerns me is that I could smell raw fish throughout the place. I know that fresh sushi shouldn't smell. Perhaps this is only because the place is nice and small and cozy. 

Their edamame is too salty though. Their salad was pretty decent for 3 bucks!

After eating here, for the first time ever, I could taste a sushi "aftertaste" in my mouth for the entire night. Again, I don't know if that is a good sign.

I will go here again.. but I will also get screened for tapeworms one of these days.. *just in case*
author: Kathy S.

description: Sushi was fresh and good.  Ambiance was ok.  I was there around 8 or 9pm on a Saturday and suprisingly there were a number of open tables.
author: Tom K.

description:
First night back in SF and I'm staying on Union Square.  San Fran = Sushi and Yelp pointed me to Sakana.  It's a small modest venue.  Looks like a great local meet up spot for a quick and reliable sushi fix.  I was promptly seated comfortably at the bar.  The menu is simple with plenty of traditional options and great and reasonably priced combo options...especially per SF standards.

The sushi is good.  I ordered the Omakase which is a roll and 8 pieces of nigiri.  It came with miso soup and afford prawn.  I was impressed by the variety: cuddle fish, sea urchin, porgy and the usual suspects.  It was all pretty good, but a little on the chewy side.

The service was good.  I don't have a single complaint.
author: Farrah F.

description: Good, fresh sushi. i had some rolls and some Nigiri and all was well. service was good and sitting at the bar watching the chefs was cool. i'm sure there are trendier places around, but sushi was all that i wanted.
author: Darragh M.

description:
Great sushi! Great service! You can get a spicy scallop roll, super california roll, sake roll, and a bunch of others for around $5 each. The fish is fresh and the service is great. It's one of my favorite sushi places in the city :) 

Notes:
- you have to ask for low-sodium soy sauce if you prefer it
author: Kimberly S.

description: We try to hit up this sushi joint every time we're in Union Square area. Delicious, fresh fish and excellent service. I highly recommend reservations since it's a very small restaurant.
author: Christine B.

description: Sakana was great, although having been to Akiko's the night before, the bar was set extremely high.  The sushi bar had fantastic service, but it was a bit crowded.  I ordered the omakase, and enjoyed everything.  The spicy tuna roll was fantastic, as was the house salad.  They also have wonderful sakes.  A very enjoyable experience, and I would happily return.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Going to split this review on good and bad and be as objective as possible:

ordered: fried oysters, 49ers roll, spicy tuna, salmon,  cali roll and teriyaki dinner 

the good:
 - fried oysters
- we were given a table right away
- miso soup was tastier than other places..

the bad
- house salad was mixed greens  with italian dressing.. wtf
- the salad on my dinner  was also soaked on the teriyaki sauce
- spicy tuna was  tasteless
- they gave us 1 water refill and then the waitress disappeared for the night
- no specialty rolls,  ( ie : baked, deep fried etc etc)

Tab : 50 + 14 tip = $64

bottom line: if you are looking for good miso and fried oysters, this is your place but if you are looking for tasty sushli and  specialty rolls go else
author: Fran M.

description: Great little sushi place - the seafood was very fresh; the service was great, and the prices were very reasonable.
author: Chuck O.

description:
Sakana has all the right ingredients: decent Japanese food, reasonable prices, a cute comfy location with nice windows and sushi bar, and (with just one exception) friendly kindhearted staff. I even heard a rumor that a certain famous Japanese baseball player sometimes comes here when he's in town. So why only two stars?

As some other reviewers have noted, there's one waiter there who has an attitude problem. He's often working, so not easy to avoid. I forgave it the first couple of times, figuring it was just some misunderstanding, but after a few more times, I just couldn't reward them with more business. There's other good options for Japanese in that area.

Shame, the rest of the staff is cool! If they get rid of the jerk, I'd be happy to give them more business.
author: David M.

description: Katsu too dry, miso too salty.
author: Michael E.

description: Incredibly mediocre. I'm honestly not sure how people give this place such good ratings. The rolls were bland and some of the fish was extra "fishy". The miso soup was amazing though and became the saving grace of not giving the place fewer stars. Service was solid.
author: Maggie Z.

description: We ordered the teriyaki beef and chicken plates, along side some sushi.  The sushi was above average.  However, I could not believe they actually served us the meal that they did.  By far the worst Teriyaki beef I have ever had.  Extremely tuff cut of meet that tasted like it was just boiled in water with absolutely no seasoning.  Teriyaki being of Japanese origin is somewhat of a disgrace to screw it up at a Japanese restaurant.  A wasted meal in a city with such amazing food.
author: G. M.

description:
Being an out-of-towner, my friend recommended we have dinner here since we were going to be in the neighborhood. Great choice!

The sushi is decently priced and the staff was great. I'm not sure what went on based on prior reviews but maybe they're just finally getting their act together.

The soft shell crab roll was really great.

If you don't want to spend an arm and a leg on sushi in a cozy environment, Sakana Sushi & Grill is the way to go.
author: Alyssa A.

description: I certainly haven't been to every sushi restaurant in SF. (Life is just too short for a visitor). But this is a solid 4. Always tasty, staff are attentive and pleasant without being over-bearing and it's always full including many from the neighborhood. The menu is standard and strong but consider venturing off menus for a few treats from the blackboard. A great place for standard sushi and pushing out boundaries. Ill be back!
author: Island Kritic s.

description:
Sakana has been my go-to Japanese restaurant for the past year. It's sad that I no longer live a block away, downhill at that. Besides Oyaji or Sushi on North Beach, Sakana has been a favorite of mine in the city. 

Ambiance: demure, calm, intimate, and elegant without being uncomfortable and stuffy

Food: simple, yet beautiful presentation, the sushi is always fresh and delicious, tender and crispy katsu, agadashi tofu is sizable and perfectly cooked, and I love the mixed greens salad with that yummy light dresssing (not the usual miso)

Service: food always comes out with great timing, servers are always respectful and mindful of what I like to call "unlawful acts of server-intrusion"

Price: spot on; a perfect medium---the prices you expect to pay for quality, without leaving the feeling of being raped

+1: they have bonito (katsuo)!

Go, so I can live vicariously through you...
author: Kristine W.

description: Great, small sushi joint. Enjoyed my food and had no problem with the price. Get the futo! Delicious. Authentic sushi restaurant.
author: Jack F.

description: Food overall is fine, I love their rice very much, and lunch specials are good deal, but beside, nothing is really remarkable for me. There's only one thing ''astonishing'' us very much: the service. There is a japanese waiter with long hair usually serves ppl with bad attitude, sometimes VERY VERY rude. Most of my friends had bad experience at this restaurant because of him. If he is not there, we may go to Sakana more often definitely!
author: Alice H.

description: I have been to Sakana over a half-dozen times and my experiences have been uniformly outstanding! Perhaps this has been due to being in the company of 'The Duchess' but I think it also had something to do with the super-fresh and meaty salmon rolls, dragon rolls, and other delights and the friendly and accomodating staff--particularly the helpful and efficient Hiro who seems to magically make beautifully prepared and delicious sushi and cold beverages appear with the greatest of ease! I love Sakana and I hope to see you there!
author: Lou S.

description:
My wife and I found this place on Yelp before a business trip to San Fran.  We made a reservation a few days in advance, and I'm sure glad we did!

It was the night of the Chinese New Year, and their location was just a few block away from the parade route.  We walked right in, and there was a table waiting for us.  

A small place, but comfortable.  Our food came out very quickly, so we decided to order a second round a little while later. 

Pros: Food, Friendliness, Reservations a MUST (they were turning people away)

Cons: Small Location, Food was a B+
author: Kevin C.

description:
I think Sakana gets sloppy seconds of customers who didn't want to wait for Ryokos.

Good sushi, good selection of sake, good service.  Enjoyable experience - eaten here twice.
author: Erik R.

description: Great food served fast and eaten just as quickly. So Good! Great service too.
author: Christine B.

description: My go to sushi spot! I use to live and work in the area so Sakana was always walking distance. I always make sure to be seated in Hiro's section. I moved to LA for a few years and came back. Even after a few years, Hiro still remembered my exact order!
author: Jessica F.

description:
This is one of the first Japanese restaurants I noticed during my first day in SF, about one year ago. Ironically enough, it is probably going to be last Sushi spot I will have tried in the city before moving back to Europe (three more days to go). I know, this sounds and is kinda sad :-(

Anyway,  great discovery. Excellent sashimi: three huge chunks of salmon, yellowtail, albacore, red tuna. And tonight winner is ... snare drum roll ... Mr. Melting-In-Mouth Albacore! gorgeous! 
In order to be a bit adventurous, I have also tried some of the a-la-carte nigiri straight from Japan: rock porgy, blue "I-don't-remember",  "I-don't-remember" bream ... sorry, but my culinary memory is more about taste than about names, I'll work on that. Taste-wise and texture-wise, the three fishes were quite comparable and they all look pretty similar, except the rock porgy, which included some skin. Good stuff ... times three. And dulcis-in-fundo, two tiny excellent homemade green tea flans (I would recommend not to pour caramel sauce over them not to kill the fine green tea flavour, though).  The consistency of the flan was the best I could think of. Attentive service. Excellent fish.
author: Andrea L.

description:
If you love nigiri or sashimi, this is the place for you. Fish was fresh and delicious.

I recently went with a friend that liked sushi, but never really loved it. After eating here, he has cravings for sushi all the time.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Sakana just means "fish" in Japanese. It's a no-frills place like its name.

Went here a few weeks ago and since then have been trying my best to find an excuse to get down to Union Square. Definitely the freshest and best sushi I've had in San Francisco... and relatively inexpensive (for the city, at least) to boot. Though there's not much on the menu in the way of froo froo Americanized rolls, there are sashimi/nigiri combination platters that are excellent, reasonably priced, and don't try to sneak in the octopus/shrimp/other-weird-seacreature that I don't like! As for the rolls, I liked everything and especially liked the 49ers roll (thin slice of sour lemon on it is awesome).

I've noticed a lot of negativity for the non-sushi menu items. I haven't tried any of the teriyaki dishes, but it seems a waste on those reviewers' parts to judge on the non-sushi dishes. It's called Sakana, not Teriyaki.
author: Sylvia L.

description: Happy sushi loving girl after a trip to Sakana! Great service, location and menu. The fish was amazingly fresh and I couldn't get enough. I woke up the next morning still thinking about the perfect sushi from the night before.
author: Katie M.

description: Fresh fish, just as good as the place a block down but cheaper.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I would always walk by Sakana on my way to Ryoko...thinking to myself "I've got to try this place eventually...but I don't want to take a risk." 

So finally on a night when I was way too hungry to stand in line for Ryoko, I took the risk of dining at Sakana and to my surprise, was not disappointed. 

The fish selection was vast and flown in from Japan. Their hot food selection consisted of some unique dishes on top of the traditional teriyaki, tempura, ramen, etc. 

I wouldn't mind trying this place again...it's definitely not just for tourists.
author: Alice H.

description: Very experienced and creative sushi chefs. Let them lead the way.
author: Katie A.

description: A wonderful restaurant. Most of the rolls are excellent, but the taste of the sukiyaki is weird to me.
author: Ariel X.

description:
I'm not a tourist and generally I don't eat around here, but my friend and I were wandering well past prime dinner time and were craving sushi.  

Immediately upon arrival, I noticed that it was a very small, cramped restaurant.  That's cool...a little cozy, but if you have good food and service, that's all that matters.  But I was immediately pissed off at the beginning and it left a bitter taste in my mouth the rest of the meal.

There were 2 larger tables (large for this restaurant means putting 2 small tables together - seating 4 each) and still the man wouldn't let us sit at a table, claiming they were "reserved."  Mind you this was past 9pm and to top it off, my friend had a torn tendon in his foot and had limited mobility so it made it very difficult to sit in a cramped corner at the sushi bar...

We had spicy scallop roll, king california (addition of tobiko), caterpillar roll, and the philly roll.  I would have to say that the fish was pretty fresh and though the rolls were not cut in even slices, they were pretty tasty.

WIth that said, the attitude/service we received at the beginning made it difficult for the food to raise my review... Also, in case you were wondering, the one of the two "reserved" tables came with only 2 persons, so we totally could have had a table and avoided the inconvenience it caused my friend and his huge boot.  

2.5 stars.
author: Alvina W.

description: Excellent sushi.  Great prices. Good ambience, not too quiet and not too loud.  Service was find for me altho reading these reviews people complain about it.  they must have fired the person they were referring to in previous reviews becuase service was great and it was pretty crowded.  Sushi very fresh and tasty.  I recommend the Rainbow roll  - It's a California Roll with a great variety of such on top of the roll -  Maguro sushi was excellent - (ask for real snow crab legs instead of their usual which is 50% dungeness and 50% pollack/imitation).  high quality and very reasonable price.  Fried octopus and tuna tataki looked good too although I didn't order this.
author: Michael C.

description:
Yes! Finally a Sushi place that I like in SF.

This place has a nice variety of options for people who may actually like fish without tempura batter or heavy sweet brown sauce. I had the Yellow Tail Sashimi which was fresh and in generous portion as well as salmon sushi. The prices were a steal compared to other places I have been in the city.

I also enjoyed the NIGORI  which came in a interesting bamboo carafe. The staff was super attentive quick to bring things out.

This is a nice casual option for sushi.
author: Eric G.

description: Great food and wide selection.  Average service. Its difficult to keep your glass filled and you always have to ask for it.  Location is very touristy but servers should know that better service will keep locals coming back consistently.
author: Darius A.

description: Mediocre Japanese restaurant. From sushi to appetizers to noodles, nothing is bad, or good. Definitely overpriced given the taste. And the owner/waiter are not particularly welcoming. Had a cold face all the time we were there.
author: X L.

description: Simply put....rolls very small....fish not as fresh as it should be...service was fine...no attitude. Wont be back
author: david b.

description:
This place is great for first timers or people who enjoy simplicity with their sushi. They have your great basic nigiri and familiar rolls (cali, spicy tuna, etc). They have about 6 specialty rolls (spider, 49er, dragon to name a few).  PRICES ARE GREAT!!! 

4 STARS for the food: loved the spider roll (fried soft shell crab), hamachi roll was pretty bland, but the spicy tuna was bomb

3 STARS for the restaurant: nothing too fancy, but spacious enough
author: Cnn F.

description:
Finding good sushi in Union Square is an interesting experience.  There are a lot of sushi places, but none that really blew my mind.  Looking at the 4 star review of this place, I decided to check this place out.  The decor was spartan, food seems fresh, service was OK, and pricing wasn't bad.  

Nothing to hurry back to, but definitely an acceptable experience.
author: Leo C.

description: The sushi was good but comparing with other places in the bay area (specially Palo Alto and SJ areas) it is a little expensive for what you get.
author: P C.

description: The food is really good and the service as well. The teriyaki chicken was super. Loved the sushi. Ate there twice in my three day stay. Would recommend it to anyone in the area.
author: April W.

description:
Popped in because it seemed small and homey.

Waiter person - sat me, handed menu, vanished.
I ordered one roll.  waiting waiting waiting

He asked if I wanted more, I said, yes, probably.
What does waiter person do?
He takes the menu.

I cheerfully said, no, don't, I'd like to keep looking at it.

Waiter person tells me he must take it because they don't have very many menus.

WTF?

I wait
I wait
FINALLY my roll arrives.

ho hum
Worse - the avocado was BROWN!   Wrong Wrong and Wrong

Did waiter person ever come back to ask me if I wanted more?
No.

Was the roll (spider roll) all that great. Hella no.  Again, brown avocado!

In fact I had a funky after taste for hours later.

Waiter person got paid the fee for my roll and about 20 cents extra for a tip.  I'm a person who tips MINIMUM 20%.

NOTE:  Owner was at sushi bar, paid zero attention to me.

Why go back?  No reason at all.  Go up the hill to Sanraku.  This joint isn't not interested in you/me.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
Update after Friday's dinner:

- They recently raised the price for ankimo from $6 to $7.50! Portion is still big and it's still tasty but I thought we were in a recession?!

- They take reservations for any party and this particular Friday was especially busy!!! Recommend you make one so you won't have to wait an extra 45 minutes for an open table like us :(

- We had our usual order but this time, I thought the tempura udon was a little bland. Or maybe it was because I was so full and couldn't even finish it!

- I tried giving their sushi rice another chance but seriously, their sushi rice sucks! If anything, stick with sashimi and avoid the rolls.

- Great place for drinks and beer food -- think izakaya! I just wish it had more options.

Still a 4 star place for me because I love their small plates!
author: T L.

description:
I've heard mixed reviews of Sakana so I was glad I was finally able to come here to make my own conclusions.  

The food was just decent.  The sashimi was fresh and the presentation was nice.  I came here with a party of  7 and we over ordered (as usual) so we got to try a huge chunk of the menu, which was a plus.  The rolls were just pretty average and simple to me, but still good I guess, as was the sake.  Still, nothing special though.

My only big complaint was the service.  Our waiter was rude and wasn't very helpful either and frankly seemed very impatient with us.  We also had to ask for refills of water and tea almost each time it ran low or completely out.  

Maybe cause there's an automatic 20% service fee to the bill for parties of 5 or more so he figured he can just slack off?  Perhaps, but who knows.  All I know was that the service was not up to par and for that experience, I don't really care to come back.
author: Carmen Y.

description:
Small place with a 45 minute wait?  Sounds like a good idea for sushi.  As long as there's a dive bar next door in which I can consume a hot tottie while I wait for my turn.  Oh, there is?  Well thanks Sakana.  It'll be three for Mari C.

Sushi was pretty good - we had mostly nigiri and a few rolls.  It wasn't too expensive, but definitely not cheap either.  I'd say you get about what you pay for.  Ashley S. swears by this place.  I would go again for sure.
author: Mari C.

description: This is a small place in the heart of the Tenderloin, so watch your environment when and if you walk there.  It is small and not very physically impressive.  But boy is the sushi ever good.  I ordered omakase, which means chef's choice and diner's surprise.  I love surprises and I was not disappointed.  Outstanding sushi in a simple setting.  Great for foodies, not so much for jet setters.  Recommended.
author: Bob G.

description:
Eh, the menu here includes your typical sushi, donburi (though not oyako don, chicken and egg, my favorite), teriyaki and udon options.

The sushi was mostly fresh, although the tuna tasted a little fishy to me.  We shared the $25 sushi combo plate, which was not worth it at all.  It includes several pieces of very fresh nigiri and then a "deluxe chef's choice" roll.  That roll was the fishy tuna, which I did not think was all that deluxe.  We probably should have just ordered the sushi a la carte.

The udon was tasty though nothing special.  All in all, a decent spot for downtown, but don't expect any surprises.
author: Pearl L.

description: If you're in Union Sq./Lower Nob/TL and are craving incredibly fresh sushi in a cozy environment, come here! It's unassuming in the best way. Service is very prompt. Prices are extremely reasonable. The last time I went I had the yellowtail, and it was the freshest yellowtail I've ever had. I love that they have ume and shiso items as well. My new favorite sushi place!
author: Anita S.

description: Excellent culinary artistry in a modest environment.  My wife and I agree that the kani-su (crab with cucumber salad) is the best we've had in ages.  Only in San Francisco is the crab - Dungeness  Crab and only at Sakana do you get several whole claw meat pieces.  We ate our fill of sushi and yakitori and did not break the bank.   Hiro and his staff provide great service.
author: Arthur N.

description:
I will start gentle by pronouncing their Sushi the worst I have ever tried in my life (yes, that includes the semi-frozen sushi packages you could get in gas stations).

From the moment I walked in, I knew I was in for an unforgettable experience. The stained walls, the gritty interior, the relaxed waiters and the despondent cook.

Still, it opens until 1 AM on weekends, so it seemed like our last opportunity for food in the area.

I made a wise call and chose a Dragon roll for my self and a Scorpion roll for my guest that night. (On a place were hygiene is lacking, raw fish may not be the wisest choice).

Yes... The dragon roll was grayish in color. All of it. The avocado was not green, was gray. The eel was not golden brown, it was gray,. Heck, even the side ginger was yellowish gray instead of pink. It was all a colorless mess. The slices were three times the usual thickness, no doubt not maintain the soggy rice from suspiciously falling apart, but alas, making it not suitable for any mouth (Not a gentle one anyways). On the side, a careless squirt of mysterious sauces was laid the way a hot dog would have mustard and ketchup. No elegant patterns,, no discrete amount. Lots of it, so to make the flavor at least defined in one direction.

My companion's Scorpion roll did not fare much better. The slices again huge... The tempura deep-fried crab was soggy  instead of crunchy.

I really should have stand up up and left when facing such unforgivable fare (will not do the favor of calling it "sushi")... But in a masochistic way, I wanted to confirm it tasted as bad as it looked.

I was not disappointed.

Yes, I can not have a framework of reference on how sushi is not mean to be... A barometer for the lowest of the low.

Now that i experimented such depths in your behalf, save yourself the trouble. Have a boiled burger instead. Tastes the same and it will be much cheaper.
author: David G.

description:
We stopped here for dinner, around 6:30-7pm and maybe because it was couple days after Christmas, this place was pretty empty. We were seated right away, ate $100 worth sushi between 2 of us, and out of here within 45 minutes. That was my quickest sushi eating experience ever.

I usually don't like Maguro but they had really good ones. Hamachi, Shiro Maguro, Katsuo and Toro were my favorite. Order from "today's special" menu to have their freshest fish brought directly from Japan.

We ordered steamed clams (asari no saka mushi) as an appetizer and I really liked it.  Big and plump clams steamed in garlicky salty soup... Aww, I could have just have that and a bowl of rice as my dinner :)

Overall, not a bad place but not the killer sushi joint that you must go. I'd give 3.5 stars.
author: Tomomi S.

description: Its as good as oyjai restaurant and i love SUNTORY beer! its as good as german beer fresh frm the brewery!
author: Linda A.

description:
Giving this 2 *s since the food was pretty decent. Not great, but not bad either, and the location in convenient.
But ooooh my goodness the slow slow slowness, even on a fairly quiet night!
What really impressed me, however, was the little incident that happened with the first roll we got. 3 people ordered a little of this and that and were going to share, so no one realized none of us had ordered this roll. Had a piece each. Then the waitress dove in with uncharacteristic swiftness, grabbed the plate and put it on another table.
Hahaha!
Not going there again.
author: Kat B.

description:
I wish I could give this 3.5 stars. 

I came here with my dad while he was in SF on business. 

We all ordered soup. I got the regular miso and my dad got the mushroom soup. He couldn't stop talking about it, he thought it was so good. 

The menu is simple, with a few very simple rolls, for the right price.  The fish is good quality, but the menu is not that exciting. I would come back if I wanted a simple fish dinner.
author: Kealie G.

description: We had the tempura, rainbow roll and dragon roll. Washed them down with some beer. Orders came out pretty quick as it was pretty early in the evening and it wasn't crowded. The sushi chefs were nice and chatted with us. Service was pleasant and our food was good. Nothing exceptional, but can't go wrong here either.
author: Jenny C.

description: Came here at the recommendation of the Hilton concierge, and he was right! Delicious! A hidden treasure and my wife and I are so glad to have found it. The rolls were delicious, as was the chicken teriyaki. The tuna bomb roll was one of the best I've eaten.
author: Fred P.

description:
Be fair, this restaurant is 3.5 star to my taste.

The brightest spot is nigiri sushi with Alfonsino. It is like smoke bacon born in a fish body with a firm texture.
Sea bream, threadfin bream, and black opal are okay. I think they could have removed the parts with fishy taste.
No complaint for nigiri sushi with toro and salmon.
Salmon skin salad was alright, but salmon skin wasn't crispy enough.
Burdock root salad was simple and refreshing.
Scallop carpaccio is so-so, and I am not fond of mayonnaise accompanied with the scallop.

This place is not exceptionally great, but I wasn't disappointed with it either. I may go back for second time to try out their grill plates.
author: Edmund L.

description:
Fresh and unusual fish from Japan.   Had some fish there that  I have never heard nor tried.  Good ambiance,  tasty fish, and good service. 

Glad I went there before TEPCO started dumping radioactive Fukishima water in the sea surrounding Japan. Sadly, fish from Japan does not sound as appealing.  I hope the amnesia sets in soon so I can sample so more Japanese fish at this lovely place.
author: Hillary L.

description: Food was decent. We were 3 adults and 2 infants. Waitress added 20% service fee. HOW  rude she was. It's not like we received good service. We will never go back!
author: Mii L.

description:
I wasn't lucky enough to win the Mega Million, but I was lucky enough to get a piece of hair in my food.  Funny thing is the very first review I read about this place before coming mentioned finding a piece of hair in their food.

Hair aside, this place blows! They do have fresh sashimi but that's about it.  Chicken skewers...WOW! It's been a while since I tasted such horrible chicken skewers!  If you are going to serve something that taste like utter garbage, why bother putting it on the menu?  Especially for the price, there are sooo many other places you can go.
author: Peter S.

description:
Wow I'm glad we didn't read these reviews or we probably would haven't ventured into Sakana and then we would have missed out on a tasty and enjoyable meal. The staff were lovely and helpful (they even provided a perfect description of mountain potato which I assure you is tricky to describe); and the restaurant was a calm escape from a blustery San Francisco evening.

Good basic sushi and a few more interesting options.
author: Susan W.

description:
Sakana is my favorite sushi restaurant in Union square.  It is not a fancy place, no frills.  But Hiro always takes great care of myself and my guests.  The owners of sakana are actually japanese, unlike some other sushi restaurants in union Square....they have excellent creative rolls, wonderful tasty Nigiri, yummy japenese items like chicken katsu...delicious Miso with mushrooms (mmm country style my favorite) and most importantly the sake selection is very impressive for a restaurant of their size.  And they have rice beer!  
Dont forget to order the tuna bomb when you go, tuna plus jalepenos= bliss.
author: Michele K.

description:
This place is cute.. went here after watching SATC2 with the gfs. :) 

The ankimo was good.. the sushi/sashimi combo I felt was a little pricey for what it was.. (1 cali roll, and like 5 pieces of nigiri and 6 pieces of Sashimi) it was $25. Maybe eating at the bar will give me a diff experience.. but i'll just say this place is a-ok. There are other places I think are better in terms of freshness and price.. I.e. Oyajis, Murasake...
author: Kristina L.

description: Everything was fresh, good quality and the service was great. I'd go for the sushi over rolls. Rolls are good, not great. But sushi quality is excellent.
author: Alex G.

description: Very expensive. Ordered salmon and crab sashimi, two Miso soups and a seaweed salad. The sashimi entrees were so tiny they were in a single roll container. Spent $46 and definitely hangry!
author: Sylvia K.

description:
Went here for dinner. The restaurant is pretty small but nice. Their menu is pretty simple. If you are here for rolls, it's not the place. Ended ordering different type of fishes, qualify was pretty good. It's around $5 each. Try their Uni, very good!!!

Their beef carpaccio was good too also. Overall, not too bad.
author: Nhung T.

description:
Came here for lunch last week with my mom while she was visiting. When I walked in the restaurant was only about a quarter full. The server was nowhere to be seen and the sushi chef looked up at me but then continued working. After standing by the door for about a minute waiting to be seated, I gave up and just sat down at the nearest table and grabbed a menu. Then, finally, the server finally came out to greet me. He returned to the back and came back out with two glasses of water. 

Wait. 

WATER? I was surprised to not get tea automatically at a Japanese restaurant run by Japanese people. When I asked for tea instead he took back the water. Another bummer... I wanted both :(

We ordered 11 items but he didn't write any of it down. I'm not a big fan of that practice because I always worry they'll forget something. And sure enough, he did. But it was ok because I got a free roll out of it!

The highlights were definitely all the cooked items from their Appetizer section. The rolls were decent but nothing you can't find elsewhere, same goes for the sushi (except for the uni - it tasted fishy. Blech!)

- ANKIMO (steamed monkfish liver with ponzu) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?userid=5bmpGbzPd-gfcUl6o5j7FQ): DELICIOUS! I love, love, love liver! Very good flavour and creamy texture. The ponzu paired really well with it too and helped cut the richness. Loved the shiso leaf garnish too.
- TSUKUNE (skewer of ground chicken balls with shiso leaves) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=XHMZ9lDQMJSpMykaA1AD9g): more shiso, yay!
- YAMAIMO MENTAIKO (sliced mountain potato with spicy cod roe) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=svxHezlVzIoq3YB2o6wZ6A): this was unexpected, but good. The potatoes are raw so they gave a nice crunch. Not much flavour to them but that's what the cod roe was for. Very generous portion of roe too, which was awesome!
- GINDARA MISOYAKI (grilled silver cod marinated in miso) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=ucB7oXB666lySmNXHWgnnQ): also very good and a generous portion. Can't go wrong with miso cod :)
- GESO FRY (fried squid legs) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=4QO_kHhubVrk1GlgzqdSXA): good.
- NIGIRI (salmon, uni, kanpachi, ikura) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=HCmjSofKflsyeRqBo4lvLw, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=kLDJTAGJ5dCeqYqNvvZzQw): salmon and kanpachi tasted fresh. Uni did not. Blech! Which sucked even more at $7 an order. Ikura wasn't that great either.
- ROLLS (California, spicy tuna, Rock N Roll) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=8FOCxXKaC194jhNWGARESA, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/shGrK3zfITUUY4SsqKk_Bg?select=wOYVz_MIaJojZQZWJtkRoQ): decent. Nothing more to say, really.

Check out their website; they have their full menu posted, which I found to be very helpful!
author: Steph L.

description: To start with this place is everything you want and need out of a sushi place. It does not try to be more than it is. It not trendy. It does not play annoying club music. The servers don't try to be your friend while giving you bad service. The just make good sushi and at a great price! I wish they might have more of a selection but I left totally happy. So other sushi places in the neighborhood you might learn something and try to get the first part right. Good food and good service. I mean who does not like eating like a fat kid with a friend for $65.
author: Michael T.

description:
i've been to this restaurant a few times and i will be honest i did always like their sashimi(and the only thing i really order). it was good quality at a reasonable price.

however, i never liked the service. well occasionally when there was this girl waitress, it was alright but a few times we had this guy waiting on us, and we always felt like he hated us or something. he never had a smile, actually always looked quite unhappy, never said 'you are welcome' when we say lots of thank you to him, and seemed very displeased when i wanted a water and a tea at the same time. long story short. i was happy with the food, but not the service. so we would give a between a 8-12% tip depending on the day. and apparently, that is not enough.

when i went back last time, the person at the door told us that, we have been giving small tips, so we are not welcome. we are welcome to order take out if we want. lol. never had that happen to me before. i thought it was lame that they didnt even ask, why we didnt give a higher tip, never came to us and asked if there is anything we weren't satisfied with

actually, now that i read some other 1 star reviews, it seems quite commonly known this restaurant's got some pretty questionable service. so at least its not just me.
author: Danielle A.

description: Very good local place that was recommended to us by our hotel bartender!  This is a very small place so we had to wait about 20 minutes to be seated.  We ordered a bunch of sushi/sashimi.  Everything was fresh & excellent!   The California Roll ( not usually one of my faves) was so good with real crab....not that imitation stuff!  The service was excellent as well.  Definitely suggest this place if you are nearby!!!
author: Cathie D.

description:
Great place, genuine staff. No BS place for nigiri. 

A little pricey, but you get what you pay for.
author: Eddie C.

description:
By far one of the biggest hidden gems for sushi in the city.  In my experience, SF has not had great japanese restaurants, but Sakana really steps up to the plate.

Everything is well proportioned, fresh, and properly prepared.  The california rolls are made with real crab and definitely the best california rolls I've experienced in the Bay Area.  The sashimi pieces are thick and fresh, and the different appetizers are all unique and authentic.

The prices aren't bad, especially for the quality of the food.  One recommendation I would make is to make a reservation before you get there, especially on a popular night, because the space is small and tables tend to fill up quickly.
author: Tara L.

description:
I'm still riding on the high of my experience here earlier tonight, but I've been to Sakana enough times to know that the elation is well-deserved and consistent. And when I say "enough times" I mean that I work in the neighborhood and eat here 2-4 times a month. So much so that they know my voice on the phone. 

And it's ALWAYS good, no matter whether I'm eating in or taking out. I've tried a handful of things on the menu and it's delicious across the board. I have my favorites when it comes to sushi and tend to stick them. What can I say, it's a comfort food kind of thing. But I do tend to judge places on their hamachi. And the hamachi negi roll is at Sakana is my absolute favorite. It has a fresh and beautifully balanced flavor. I also love the spicy tuna roll - a wonderful bite without being too spicy to layer some wasabi flavor in there. 

Tonight in particular, was such a wonderful experience that I thought to myself "the world needs to know..." Now it's one thing to have delicious food and fantastically reasonable prices (the main reason that I am always recommending Sakana to anyone I know in the area) but it's the service that really pushed it to the top. The staff is always friendly, calm and attentive even during busy times. Tonight I walked in and decided to sit down during my 30 minute break instead of calling ahead for take out. Already knowing what I wanted (and would love), I ordered as I sat down at the counter, thinking that it would take 5-10 minutes to make, giving me enough time to eat, pay and walk back to work. I settled into watching the sushi chef in his zone, rolling, slicing, plating. And then, to my surprise he handed me the plate. He must have heard me order as I sat down. The food was delicious, as always, and I had time to savor it instead of rushing through. Then, as I finished and started to gather my things together to get going, the server was there with my bill. The best part? Everyone said good-bye as I headed out the door. I'll admit, I was a little jealous of the people who had just sat down around me because I was leaving and their meal was just beginning. 

But that's okay, because I know it's only a matter of time until I'm back.
author: Maggie F.

description:
This is my very first Yelp review (woo hoo!). My hubby and I just returned from a wonderful Northern CA trip. Started off in SF, then road-tripped to Napa, and finally trekked to Lake Tahoe. Sakana was a perfect "hole-in-the-wall" spot - nothing fancy - just what we wanted. I commend the server for really taking care of us. I wish I got his name (note to self) especially since I plan to do these reviews more often. He was very attentive, but non-invasive and seemed to really care about our dining experience. I wanted a variety of fish so I ordered the Chirashi (or as a friend calls it "the dog bowl of sashimi") - I mentioned that I loved unagi and maguro, so the server noted to the chef that I was "eel-and-tuna-friendly." I had never heard that before, so when I received my dish, I was pleasantly surprised with the extra eel and excellent quality tuna! The same deal for my hubby too - he wanted albacore instead of maguro, so the server checked with the chef and said "no problem." Jotted down "shiro-maguro-friendly" and sure enough, he got albacore instead of maguro. It was wonderful! Another nice surprise was the complimentary green tea at the end of our meal. I often have tea after I eat at home, so that was a nice bonus. 

The only reason I gave them 4 out of 5 (really it's a 4.5) is the sushi rice was not the best I've had. It was good, but not top notch. The texture was ok, but it could have used a bit more flavor. Of course, just my opinion.

So that's it! Hope my review helps you make a more informed dining decision.
:-)
author: Lauren C.

description: Came here as part of my quest to find the best chirashi in SF.  Sakana's version, at $16.95 (if I remember correctly) is decent, with well-seasoned chirashi rice and a dozen sizeable slices of good-quality fish.  On the flipside, however, I prefer my chirashi with a little more variety of fish and some veggie content, of which Sakana's version only has the standard shredded daikon.  Also, this one had a little too much tamago (omelet).
author: Zain K.

description: Just what we were looking for, and within walking distance of our hotel!
author: Brian N.

description:
A friend and I decided to leave without ordering a full meal because of the rude-to-the-max server.

We had decided to get some mochi ice cream as an appetizer but didn't have a chance to explain our plan to the guy before he yanked our menus away irritated. not sure why he was angry? because he thought we weren't going to order a full dinner? we explained that we'd like to order dinner. after this he literally threw the menus back down onto the table and demanded our order. when we told him we weren't ready to order he huffed and ran away. we decided that things probably weren't going to get any better and told our server we'd just go. he showed us our mochi, so we stayed for that. IT WAS PERFECT MOCHI. 
but it was strawberry. as i recall there were two flavors on the menu and my friend and i would have ordered both of them if he had bothered to ask which flavor we had wanted. 

geez. they could at least try to be nice to the people they sat right next to the restrooms. 

other than that, price seemed reasonable too but not worth the treatment.
we ran to akiko's around the corner, excellent service, out-of-this-world cheap.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Simple sushi and sashimi menu. Don't come here if you want the baked/sauced rolls (you can go to hana sushi or sanraku for that).  

I come here to get my regular sushi fix quite often. What we often order:
- Hamachi sashimi (always fresh, buttery)
- Hamachi kama (sometimes a bit more charred than I like, but still very good)
- Chirashi (solid pieces of fish, tamago, and it's slightly cheaper than Sanraku. They also do substitutions if you ask.)
- Ankimo (standard fare, in ponzu and topped with scallions, just very good price to me)
- Beef tataki (standard fare, but very good!)

You have to ask for low sodium soy sauce. Call ahead to get a table.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
OMFG I AM GOING TO RIP MY EFFN HEAD OFF!

If I won the lottery tomorrow, I would eat here every single effn day! 
The fish at Sakana is probably the freshest fish I have stuffed into my watering mouth in all of San Francisco. 

You got to try the Salmon Skin Salad, the tuna, and the saba shioyaki.
author: emily g.

description: Another disappointing sushi joint in SF. Got the lunch special sushi combo with Unagi and Sake (Salmon). The quality of the fish and the rice was just not very good. The rolls were falling apart before they even got into my mouth. I left with a stomach ache too. I think I'm allergic to bad sushi. boo!
author: Debbie C.

description: Best sushi in SF hands down--fresh fish, none of the fake dishes you see at other so-called Japanese restaurants that you would never see in Japan (spider roll, etc.). This is the real deal and it's good value as well.
author: M B.

description: Absolutely Fantastic!!   Sushi is excellent. Service and atmosphere is also great.   This is not a fancy restaurant. It is a place you go if you want great food.   Prices are low for what you get.
author: Greg R.

description: Hands down one of my favorite sushi spots in the city.. always fresh fish, great specials by the chef (just let him decide for you) and a fun place for a group of friends to relax and enjoy some Saki.
author: Brian C.

description: Why so negative people?   I had a really lovely meal here and look forward to taking my spouse when we are in San Francisco next month.   Nothing fancy.  Just really good food and pleasant service.
author: Brenda S.

description:
Barracuda sushi apparently exists!

There's a guy I met at the Owl Tree bar next door that told me about his *amazing experience* with barracuda sushi at Sakana.  He described it as a 'waterfall of flavor'.  

Intrigued by such a unique description, my friend and I began our Holy Grail quest for this fine sushi. On our first visit, my friend and I were a bit disappointed it wasn't on the menu ~ I thought the guy had told us a tall tale, albeit an amusing one.  

I went again upon the suggestion of another friend.  This time I asked the server about this infamous Barracuda Sushi.  He said it's a seasonal item offered occasionally during the summer.  Still elusive, but I am getting closer to this mysterious experience.

***

The other dishes are delicious.  I especially enjoyed the Agedashi Tofu appetizer.  It was a stand out for me.
author: Cathy K.

description: Loved it!! All aspects of this restaurant is great. Love the spicy tuna and the hamachi rolls. Will go back anytime i can.
author: Jack H.

description:
You know what really grinds my gears? When it takes 20+ minutes just to get initial beers. That rhymed.

Food is not remarkably good or bad, I ate there within the last few months and barely remember it. Probably not a good sign. The slowness of the service was really what stood out most. We were there to take our time and hang out, no real schedule for the night, and by the time we were ready for the check three of my most laid back friends were in full WTF mode. It wasn't even crowded either, you could have played a game of racquetball in there without worrying about hitting anyone.

I live across the street  from this place and probably won't go back when Ryoko is just around the corner.

The atmosphere is kind of weird, too. I felt more like I was in a shitty coffee shop than a sushi bar. And I don't even drink coffee.
author: Trav W.

description: Another late dinner in the city and I came across this restaurant on my way back to the hotel. I was seated immediately at the sushi bar.  I was pleasantly surprised and impressed at the quality and variety of sushi.  I had the sashimi combo and uni sushi (okay uni). I can't rate the rolls since I didn't order.  The service was great and I would definitely return to Sakana for a late sushi dinner! Bonus - the restaurant offers you complimentary hot green tea after your meal!
author: Lyd N.

description:
While our food was really good, I had to dock Sakana a couple of stars for rough service. I came with a group of eight, and while I know that is a challenge, our waitress was stressed out and when we would wave her over to request more food for several of the group, she'd listen to one person and run off without seeing whether anyone else needed something. Grr!

But I'm still getting used to sashimi and the sashimi I had here (tuna and a couple others) didn't taste fishy at all and seemed very fresh (and tasty!). We ordered a few other rolls that arrived a bit on the small side (spicy tuna, crunch roll, rainbow roll) and were hard to get enough food for every body at the table. I ended up getting some tempura which was freshly fried and yummy.

I would probably go again with a smaller group to get a better experience, but if service doesn't bother you, the place has great food and is highly recommended.
author: Tracy O.

description: The sushi was very good.  We had tekka rolls, hamachi rolls, and vegetarian rolls.  All were consumed heartily.  The teriyaki beef was good.  The udon was good.  The tempura was good.  And the teriyaki chicken was a little below average.  Meat was dried out.  but teriyaki sauce was decent.  Also the salad and miso soup were good.  So to sum it up, overall this place was good, but definitely not great.  However, I will come back because the sushi was worth it.
author: Lewis C.

description:
Ok, I worked in a sushi restaurant for 3 years and learned a little something about it.  This is hands down the best sushi I've ever had, and it's some of the least expensive sushi I can imagine.  I've eaten to the point of getting full for $20.  I've also taken BF and sat at the bar and asked Vance (the super cool sushi dude) to keep it coming with all the good stuff till we said stop--that cost about $45/head with beers and sake.

When you read my rating of 5 stars, let me clarify that it is all about the food.  The ambiance isn't memorable by any means, and it's one of those places you could probably wear sweatpants to and get away with it.  The music is played at a pretty low volume, so it's really just enough to dull out the sound of passing cars.

That being said, though, the food is to die for.  Every single piece of fish is rich, delicious, melt in your mouth yumminess.  The fish is cut perfectly, so you can take a bite of your sashimi and it doesn't get all stringy on you.

This place doesn't have a big selection of rolls aside from basic staples like the rainbow roll or caterpillar roll, but when you have fish as amazing as Sakana does, it seems criminal to adulterate it with mayonnaise-y sauces, gunky additions, tempura this or that, just too much STUFF.  If you do like rolls, the crispy roll is quite delicious.  For me, sushi is all about the quality of fish (I've grown to be a big fan of straight up sashimi and nigiri), so the lack of a roll selection doesn't bother me a bit.

The service is great, regardless of whether you sit at the sushi bar or at a table (I prefer the bar, honestly, but that goes for any sushi place).

If you have a special occasion but want to celebrate it casually, this is your spot.  I've only been living in the city about 4 months now, and I've already gone 4 times.  I can't wait for my next visit...
author: Ashley S.

description:
It's always great to find a place for late night dining, Sakana Sushi Bar and Grill serves delicious food until 1 a.m. on Friday and Saturday nights. 

With the assorted boutique hotels and hostels in this area (now known as the Tendernob) there always seems to be a buzz with lots of people on the streets. And nice that it's located a couple blocks from Union Square, between Taylor and Jones Streets. 

We settled in to a couple of the Sushi and Sashimi Combos, and they were delicious. Top those off with a couple big Asahi beers.....there's nothing better than Japanese food to start out or wind down your evening.

And even though the place can get pretty crazy busy, our server Edo kept on top of things and made us all very happy.
author: Mickey A.

description:
The food was overpriced but great! 

The first thing we noticed when we walked in was the overwhelming stench in this place. We were pretty hungry and decided to deal with the stench as opposed to finding sushi elsewhere. Certainly not a good first impression. 

As we were trying to figure out if we would stay or go elsewhere we were rudely herded into their waiting area - that's fine but please STFU as we decide if we're staying or not. Don't herd us like sheep.

The food and the sake were great. Their website menu and their actual menu really have nothing in common except for the restaurant name so don't bother with their website menu.

We ordered sake and the waitress couldn't answer basic questions about the quantity of sake. Whether it was a small carafe, a bottle or a large carafe. She tried to answer our question but left us only more confused. This should have been a sign. When we got our bill there was a charge for "3 Sake" when we clearly had 2. This is not a big deal as mistakes like this happen from time to time. When we brought it to their attention they argued and argued about the point that they brought us 3 carafes. We only had 2 and they were both still on the table. The fact that we had to argue repeatedly about this was the last nail in the coffin. STAY AWAY FROM THESE RUDE PEOPLE.
author: Sam B.

description: The fish was perfectly brilliant; the rice was great; ad the tab was smaller than many other sushi places. This place had me barking like a harbor seal, in a very good way. I'll be back, for sure.
author: Mark W.

description: Great sushi place! Limited seating, so reservations might be a good idea.  Authentic japanese food.  We tried the beef tataki, which was cooked medium rare.  The meat was a little tough though. Also tried the mirugai kushiyaki (long neck clam skewers)... these were surprisingly really good! Then we tried the sashimi combo and a roll.  The sashimi/sushi was extremely fresh.  This place seems pretty authentic relative to other places, and is somewhere i will def come back.  They also had fish imported straight from Japan on their signs, although we didn't get a chance to try any.
author: Tramy V.

description:
*Decent sushi with decent prices
*Good service--waitress was not annoying, refilled tea, etc. 
*They moved locations from the last time I was there. This place is smaller than the old location
*Nice that it is close to Union Square, pretty centrally located
*Noticed a lot of Japanese tourists/business men dining
*Good for a small group, maybe 4-5, no more than that
*Perfect place for catching up with my girlfriends from college!!
author: Caroline C.

description:
This is not my favorite sushi place in the city. (Would give it 3.5 stars if possible)

BUT - it's conveniently located if you're downtown.

The fact that there are a lot of Japanese businessmen/tourists that come here justifies my being there. (Yo, I'm part Japanese...they're my peeps!!)

They know how to make a seaweed salad (a MUST to get 3 stars or above for a Japanese restaurant).

And who can resist bacon wrapped scallops.  Holy Mary Mother of God, they were tasty!!  That's really what pushed this place from 3 stars to 3.5.

My only negative experience here was that my friend forced me to taste mackerel and I blame it on getting sick that night.  But she didn't get sick, so I guess I can't blame it solely on the fish.  But I blame it partially on the fact that it was one of the most disgusting things I've eaten.  But as the French say, chacun a son gout.....erm, I don't know what the Japanese say...it probably doesn't sound as cool as that.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Sakana has wonderful appetizers (try their beef tataki and agedashi tofu), along with a great daily selection of fish.  I usually get the sashimi dinner combo with tempura and saba (such a good deal at ~$16!).  Another reason I like this place?  I'm always surrounded by Japanese locals and tourists.  I feel "in-the-know".  :)
