The rolls are ok - they're simple; just not their specialty.  They always look a bit underwhelming when they arrive to the table...and personally, I find their seaweed to be a bit too stringy.
author: Cathy S.

description:
Sakana is what-you-see-is-what-you-get as far as sushi goes.

Very simple, traditional menu.   Sushi, sashimi, and some basic rolls.  This is a place to eat simple, good, raw fish.

It is priced reasonably, and service is efficient and polite.  The standard items are always of high quality and they'll usually have a couple of good special sushi items as well.

This is very simple and low key, a good place to go with people who just want a comfortable and simple environment with good sushi.
author: Deva H.

description:
A great place to grab sushi near Union Sq. Really convenient to the Westin, if you're staying there or have a friend in town there. Made a reservation over the phone and changed it once with no problem. Would be nice if they were on OpenTable.

We started with bacon wrapped scallops (two skewers, with two on each skewer) and hamachi kama. Delicious! You really can't go wrong if you wrap *anything* with bacon and grill it. Seriously so good. The hamachi kama was also grilled to perfection.

For dinner, I had the tuna bomb (spicy tuna with jalapenos), an eel roll w/ cucumber, cuttlefish nigiri, and opal eye nigiri. The rolls were both really good. Don't worry about the japapenos, they weren't that spicy, but did add nice flavor, texture, and color. I was really bummed they didn't have any toro, so I decided to try some new things that aren't usually on the menu at other sushi places. The cuttlefish was interesting, but kinda rubbery. A bit like calimari, but a sheet of it. I asked the waiter about the opal eye and he said it was similar to yellowtail. Not too bad, but certainly not as good as nice FAT piece of toro. oh well, next time.

My friend got strawberry mochi for dessert and I tried a piece. Pretty good! Service was excellent, and we stayed a bit late after we were done eating just to chat.

Frequented by lots of Japanese people and recommended by a friend's sister in law who used to live in Japan. You really can't go wrong coming here.
author: Kenny J.

description:
I read some of the other reviews and it seems like this place is inconsistent, at best.  Luckily for Lacey and I, they were spot on when we were there.  The service was excellent, the prices amazed me (especially considering it's location), and the food was good.  

My bacon-wrapped scallops were fantastic and my favorite of the night was the tempura asparagus roll.  Very few foods can't be improved by a tempura coating and a quick trip to the fryer.

Could have been 3 stars... but the very affordable prices landed this one solidly in the 4 region.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Udon!!!!  Udon is quickly becoming my favorite noodle as oppose to Soba. Soba is the Frank to Udon's Sylvester Stallone, the Ray J to Udon's Brandy. The Brian Grant to Udon's Horace. Well you get the idea.

Sakana's lunch specials have fully removed themselves from both the hook and the chain. 

That means they are off the hook, I fully recommend the Udon/ Tekka Don lunch special. It is delicious, filling, and not too oil-y at all.

With restaurants like Sakana in the hood, I am quickly moving away from Union Square as a culinary dead end for tourists. 
It is in fact, a multi-cultural mecca of lunch options. 

Adding to my Surviving Union Square List now.....
author: Gabe b.

description:
Great sushi, including daily fish flown in from japan.

The only criticism that comes to mind is the size of the sashimi pieces: they left me wanting.
author: joe b.

description:
They had a lot of fresh fish specials, but I was watching my budget, so I just went with the standard sushi plate.

The quality was slightly above average.  The price was also a little above average, but nothing crazy for sure.  The interior of the place is pretty bland.

I liked the sushi, and I want to go back sometime to try some of the food from the kitchen too!

They're open till 1AM thurs-sat!
author: Rocco B.

description:
sushi is always good. i think ryokos may be a little better (but definitely a little more in price also..) 

i think its weird that they always have the same list of 'fresh from japan' but whatever, everything tastes fresh to me! =)
author: Lisa N.

description: Hands down best sushi bar in Union Square area.  Eaten here twice now and can't wait to go back.  This is sushi the way it is suppose to be served - no fake crab rolls with mayonnaise and lots of sweet sauce on top.  Glad I finally found a great sushi bar in this area, although Sanraku at the Metreon is the next best thing.
author: Jayne H.

description:
I have it on good authority that this is one of the finest sushi establishments in the city. That authority, is me. I've never had a bad meal here. The fish are fresh, the appetizers are delectable (agedashi tofu!), the service is good, and the price is not bad at all for sushi. I usually ask for omakase (Basically chef's choice) when I try a new place, but it's omakase all the way in this place.

This is a sushi eater's place, not for people who want to hide the flavors of the fish inside all the junk they're making rolls out of these days. Rolls are fine, but when you want real sushi made as our creator Amaterasu-omikami intended, you should head to Sakana.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Extremely expensive if you want sashimi.  Service was uneventful. The sushi chef was more into reading his book then serving his customers with even the slightest bit of engagement.  The sashimi portions were small and before you know if you may be paying a $150 bill for 3 people.  For $35 I can go to Koryo sushi in Berkeley with my son and eat the same I ate at Sakana.  Koryo is fresh, friendly, and open until 1 am.  Sakana left A LOT to be desired.

I read someone say that this restaurant is in all of the Japanese guide books -- for some reason I am thinking that it wasn't because the food was reasonable...it was good but lacking so much more.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Clean, ambient no-nonsense atmosphere with minimal, well chosen art adorning the walls.  Agreed with a previous review - efficient staff (I don't need the fake smiles and constant checking-in, so I'm happy here).  And most importantly, the fish is heavenly, the freshest and most delicious I've had in SF yet.  I usually don't waste my time with rolls and just dive in to the chirashi sushi -- a bed of sushi rice with various sashimi on top -- highly recommended.  Last time I went they were very generous with the fish, and included some of the spanish mackerel from the special menu -- beautifully buttery and delicious!  

Wakamesu, my usual starter, is tasty and satisfying without going overboard on the vinegar.

I always see people walking by on the street, checking out the menu, and then walking on, when they really ought to just get in there and get in on the delicious, delicious fishes.
author: Jack G.

description:
I stumbled upon this joint after our reservation got canceled at another restaurant because we were fifteen minutes late...which was actually a blessing in disguise! Although the place was pretty packed, our server managed to seat our party (there were 8 of us) in a flash by asking some people to move - for you know, more happy people. Smart. 

The food, plus the presentation was awesome. I got the Kaki (fried oysters) for my appetizer and it was very delicately cooked, thus making it super-delicioso. My cousin got the soft shell crab legs and he was very, very satisfied. The young-ins' orders were very predictable as they got the chicken teriyaki, chicken katsu, unagi and beef teriyaki dinners; I had a bite of each one (of course) and they were equally good. Me and Joan happily indulged on spider rolls, fresh salmon and scallops, crispy rolls, philly rolls and some more nigiris. 

For a restaurant with this good sushi, 8 people and less than $200 as the check, I'd say this place is off the hook!

Word to the Wise: Fresh, fresh sushi. Oh and don't forget to ask for extra spicy mayo.
author: Pia C.

description: We had a family reunion in SF and needed to change dinner plans at the last minutes on a weekend. The owner was extremely accommodating and even though this is a small restaurant, we got a reservation at six. They made good sushi and offered good sake at reasonable prices. On top of that, we brought in a birthday cake that they brought out at the end of the meal without asking an outlandish per plate service charge! When we are back in SF, this will be our "go to" restaurant.
author: J T.

description:
The sushi here is tasty and reasonable. For two people we ordered barbeque eel rolls (6), crispy rolls (6), spicy salmon rolls, philly cheese rolls, and edadame for appetizers.

The crispy rolls were my favorite. Who knew that just sprinkling some tempura batter would make such a huge difference in taste and texture? Next favorite was the barbeque eel rolls.

The philly rolls had a very interesting creamy and mushy (but in a good way) feeling - the salmon, cream cheese, and avocado, seemed to mix into a single taste gasm inside my mouth.

The place has sushi bar seating (always cool to see it prepared!) and table seating, but is not that large...about the size of a starbucks or a little less.

We went on a Thursday night around 7:00pm and it was surprisingly easy to find seating, but on a busy night I could certainly envision a wait.

Overall, a great sushi place within a few blocks of my new apartment....awesome!
author: Varun ..

description:
After preventable wasted time, I was fuming around Union Square today, and I needed instant gratification to put out the forest fire coming out of my head. A Japanese meal suffices. I head to Ryoko, but the sushi restaurant had another 45-minutes to welcome their first customer of the evening. Fine. I spot Sakana opened for business. The menu prices looked decent, and my sushi hooker was the ume offering.

The nigiri or sashimi specials are flown in from Japan, and the ootoro is from Europe. I ordered the saury/sanma in the nigiri form, but the chef mistakenly gave me several slices of sashimi. No problem because the light fish was moist and delicious. I then ordered the fresh scallop carpaccio. And instead of succumbing to the deal-breaking ume maki, I found an appetizer made of 2 of my most favorite Japanese veggie options: slimy mountain root potato and ume. I nabbed the shiso leaf that came with the sanma sashimi and wrapped several chopped sticks of the mountain root potato, dowsed in ume, and savored every bite. To top off the stomach like you used to top off your tank at the gas pump, I ordered a roll of the spicy tuna. No mayo required because they roll slices of jalapeno for that spicy kick. Yum.

And what is this I spy in the fish bar? Half open face baby abalone from Santa Barbara. Wholly moley! I immediately text my friend about this wonderful find because he still has to make up for that time for being so oblivious to the available fresh abalone at Domo. 

(This one time at Domo, my friend was wallowing in his overly dramatic girlfriend sorrows, and I was watching the chef cut open this huge Farallon Island abalone, caught hours prior by his adventurous diver friend. The chef had no intentions of selling it. I was thinking, "OMG, we may just get a bite of that abalone expensive sucker for free." At the time, my friend was in no mood and wanted to go home ASAP. I begrudgingly obliged. When we left, I mumbled how we missed an opportunity of a lifetime. And all this time, he was oblivious to the abalone in front of him.) Well, I stumbled upon the holy abalone shrine. My friend better make it up to me at Sakana by shoving abalone down my throat. Just typing this story out on Yelp makes me so excited! I think the springs on my desk chair are about to bounce off too!

The restaurant appears rather new, as it moved a few buildings down from its original location, not too long ago. The ambient and hip music selection is pleasing to the ear. The wine list, though...is pretty dismal. A single glass of Chardonnay from Beringer for $6. The Chardonnay obviously did no justice to the fresh fish. I will not ding them for the lack of wine options. Next time, I will try the heavily promoted Koshihikari Echigo beer, a fine rice microbrew direct from Japan, so says the cardboard promoter. Of course it helps that the sushi chefs are Japanese.

After a delectable, self-indulgent meal, I asked myself, "What fumes? I don't see any smoke spewing out of my ears anymore."
author: Cathy H.

description:
In this place they make the sushi right in front of you. The staff is really nice, kind and aren't afraid to make a nice little conversation. 

I highly recommend the asparagus sushi! jummmie!

Enjoy it!
author: Lyle C.

description:
It was a weird evening last night.  When I walked in, that wonderful distinct fishy smell hit my nose and I thought, time to go. But I was with other people, so I stayed. Make no mistake, I said "fishy" not the pleasant smell of fresh fish, but rather the "fishy" smell of old fish. 

We left work to join some friends here for dinner and the waiter would not seat us with our friends, even though there was plenty of room.  I asked if that particular table was reserved and he said no, but he still refused to seat us with our friends and would not tell us why. Interesting. So one of our friends joined their table and we sat at another table across the room. I don't really understand it. Your current patrons invited more people to join them (yes, this means more money for you!) and you reward that behavior by not letting them sit together. Right... Also, to make things more perplexing, the friend that joined their table said that the waiter would not take his order. Even more interesting. 

We didn't have that problem at our table. The waiter took our orders right away and the food came out fairly quickly. 

The good: veggie tempura, edamame (hard to screw up, agreed, but still...), service at our table (lucky us!)

The not-so-good: tuna sashimi - fishy fishy fishy in the not-so-good way, service at our friends' table

The mixed: we all ordered fancy rolls - not bad, but not great either, sake - sort of good, sort of not...

Just my two cents...
author: Melissa G.

description:
My favorite Japanese restaurant in SF: relaxed, down-to-earth, lots of authentic Japanese home-style cooking. I was very impressed with the crab croquettes, drizzled with mayo and Bull Dog sauce. 

The sushi is always very fresh and they have a great selection of fish past the typical maguro, sake, etc.  We tried the grunt and it was taste-y. 

Also, the waiters are super friendly and polite. And one dude wears a killer belt buckle.
author: Macheeks ..

description:
I recommend this place for the sushi counter and think the Omakase is very resonable for the price.  This is one of the better sushi restaurants in the bay area.  Not to sound like a snob, but I miss eating Sushi in Japan and this place is about as close as it gets.

Kanpai!
author: Frank F.

description: Yes, I am updating my 5 star review with another 5 star review.  Why?  Cuz this place is consistently good.  And consistency is pretty darned important for a sushi bar.
author: Erin S.

description:
A friend from Japan used to live in San Francisco and recommended this place to us. According to him, this is where Ichiro eats when he's in town. 

As others have stated, there's never a wait here, which is perfect when you're looking for a bite to eat before a show at the Post Street Theatre. We were seated at 7:00, out the door at 7:50 and in our theatre seats before 8:00. Our favorites.

Shiro Maguro
Toro
Aji no Tataki (not on the menu, but ask for it)
Scallops wrapped in Bacon

They will ask you if you'd like the fish body (part of the Aji no Tataki presentation) fried. Say yes! It's crispy goodness.

Perhaps this is a model of Japanese efficiency and presentation in action: all our food arrived quickly with a pretty and simple presentation.
author: Theda E.

description: Chose this restaurant over Ryoko's and Sanraku in the area, and I'm glad I did. Food is extremely fresh and service was fast. You know the restaurant is authentic when the chefs and customers are Japanese. This is not your typical California sushi roll kind of place so be adventurous and order something interesting. You won't be disappointed.
author: Sohiroshi C.

description:
Nice~! Seriously, It Is A Nice Place~

The combination of the setting and lighting, it is a great place to rest your soul after a brutal day in the cubical world. 

It is also a perfect selection for a quality DATE! With great serivces, great selection of JP food AND, if you think your date is worth the effort and you would LOVE to carry on later into the night, the price of this place is so decent that you will be able to pull out your wallet without an oz. hesitation to complete this perfect meal as a Gentlement~ 

Just make sure, your date truly appreciates your generious offer~

It is a Japanese Restaurent, so never challange the language skill of the services personnel at this place. I was just showing off couple greeting words that I knew in Japanese, the white boy who was serving us, he came back with awesome Japanese in respond~

Anyways, The overall experience was so great, I truly wish I can bring a date along when I come visit next time.
author: Andrew W.

description: Amazing sushi and fair priced.  It get's packed so show up early to get on the list and grab a drink next door
author: Mike P.

description:
Sakana's my favorite sushi bar in Union Square/Tender-whatever. The service has always been great, but whatever... that's not really why I come here. No, I want the freshest, most delicious fish I can find. *That's* why I eat here.

The sushi itself is always excellent, but even the other dinner fare (teriyaki chicken, scallops wrapped in bacon OMG) is tasty and worth a shot. But yeah, give me a spicy tuna roll and some veggie tempura and I'm a happy diner.

And for a sushi bar, it's pretty cheap. For SF and this area, it's an even better deal.

It gets crowded some nights and I'll typically put in a reservation beforehand, but it's also open until 1am or whenever on weekends, so even the reservation-less/nighttime sushi fiends can have their fill.
author: Chris M.

description:
Every city has its must-have connections: 1) A precise tailor. 2) An honest mechanic. 3) An asocial plumber. 4) A trusted sushi chef.  For San Francisco, I am bestowing my trust in the hands of the sushi chefs at Sakana.  

If it weren't for my Japanese from the native Island friends,  I-know-d*mn-good-sushi-if-my-life-depended-on-it, I never would have given Sakana a second glance.  

For the price, Sakana easily deserves my 4 stars.  The slices of fish in the omakase sushi, sashimi combo, and chirashisushi definitely proves this place is not afraid to be authentic, generous in portion, and  superbly fresh.  But what sealed the deal for me was their pickled ginger - absolutely delish!
author: A W.

description:
Had the king roll, salmon skin roll, salmon roll, fish egg roll, etc. Also the flan for desert. Everything was decent, and the flan was unusually good, albeit small.

Originally found two strands of hair on a sushi. We reported, and they replaced EVERYTHING free of charge. Didn't quite expect that, but the gesture was definitely appreciated and more than made up for their mistake.

It ended up being $21.5/person post-tax. We tipped up so the total was $30/person.

Would revisit.

Price: $30/person
Food: king roll, salmon skin roll, salmon roll, fish egg roll
author: Jack W.

description:
Yeah, I love this place, and wind up here all the time since it's in my nabe. It's my default sushi spot, if I'm not going upscale. 

I haven't ordered many of the nigiri, mainly because there are a couple of other dishes that are so good that I order them almost every time I go. The gomo maguro tataki is effing fantastic - as is the seaweed-cucumber salad with crab. Rolls are really good as well. 

If you buy a bottle of Soju they'll keep it there for ya with your name on it - my gf and I were there last night and had a nice meal and two sock-ya-in-the-jaw drinks from my soju stash for $40, including 20% tip.

They also have some interesting, unfamiliar dishes that I prolly wouldn't have experimented with in a pricier place. Fried whole mackerel, I think it was - mine was full of roe! Yum! And leetle silver-dollar-sized flash-fried crabs - not soft-shelled - it's what HR Geiger eats at the movies instead of popcorn!
author: Beverage Appreciato R.

description:
Fresh.  Menu selection was just excellent on a Friday night.  Big fan of mirugai (giant/long-neck clam) and awabi (abalone) and usually it's not common for most sushi restaurants that serve these in the city!  I was never a big fan of Uni (sea urchin) - it normally tastes too fishy!!  But here, it must have been "mad fresh" because it didn't have any smell.  Now, I'm a believer.  They have a unique selection of fishes from Japan so its not the same boring menu each time.

Damn enjoyable.
author: mardou o.

description: I have to say the sushi grade and freshness is going downhill. I wasn't impressed with the service asking me to move after I was half way into my meal to fit a reguluar at the sushi bar. Very rude. I was a reguluar but not anymore. The sushi is way over priced for quality.
author: Jennie M.

description:
dinner after 9 on a sunday? that's hard to find in this town. Well, especially for sushi.

And yeah, while they say sushi isn't the freshest on a sunday it was pretty damn good at this place.
They were even kind to their overly boisterous customers (that'd be us).
Not cheap. At least not when you order 2 of everything that looks good. Hella good, though.
author: Margie L.

description: Customer service very very bad. Will never ever go back to this resturant. The staff don't smile and very rude toward you. There no thank you for coming.
author: Jeff T.

description: I have enjoyed going there several times. I have had the sashimi combo, sushi combo and udon noodles w/mini don and they all were great. The lunch time sushi chef is personable and will chat when he can, without being a bother.
author: Tom A.

description:
My girlfriend and I came in around 8pm last night (Tuesday) to be promptly seated in the small but open Japanese restaurant.  Neutral colors and high ceilings give this space a clean and spacious feeling.  

At first glance, the menu carried a lot of small plates, your standard Teriyaki/Tonkatsu combos, and nigiri and rolls at end.  The small plates were good; the bacon wrapped scallops were by far the tastiest item we tried.  The yakitori however was dry and cold.  We also tried the yamaimo (mountain potato) salad with ume dressing (good), shiromaguro tataki with a garlic ponzu sauce served over baby lettuce (eh, mediocre), ohitashi (standard), and the dragon roll (temp shrimp on the inside topped with eel and avocado).  

In all reality, the experience would have been fine but the server butchered our order (we didn't order the shiromaguro tataki; and the katuo tataki we had ordered never came) and the dragon roll took 1 hour (seriously) to arrive at our table.  The server nanchalantly pointed out (but never apologized) for the tataki mistake and brought the dragon roll out AFTER I had asked for the bill (no apology or acknoledgement that we had been sitting there for half an hour with NOTHING in front of us).  

I suppose for the price, it would be hard to find a place that offers good Japanese 'izakaya' style items but I highly suggest avoiding this place during peak hours.  Perfect place if you're low on dough and need a Japanese fix.
author: William R.

description:
For the economically minded reader:  This sushi place gets a C for space/staff and an F for pretty much everything else.  

For the equivalent of Trader Joe's sushi in a take away container that's been sitting out for several days, you can pay Trader Joe's prices or Nob Hill prices.  

Granted, we found ourselves here on a Monday, and lord knows you take a chance on fish on a Monday.  The food here is absolutely nothing more than grocery store sushi.  

An Omikase plate brought imitation crab meat california roll with 6 pieces of either Wasabi overwhelmed Nigiri, or a rather bland eel.  I didn't try the raw shrinp because it looked a little slimy, and therefore sketchy....not to mention a recent raw shellfish experience that caused a wicked day after.  All that I can say about the fish, therefore is that it was so bland, it needed to be drowned in wasabi to hide the apparent lack of flavor.  

The Miso soup was bland and poorly made, with a lot of filtrate and no flavor, heavy on the supersoft tofu.  And the seaweed salad was a pasable but nothing extraordinary dyed green out of a bag variety.

The only plus was a beer allegedly from a Japanese microbrewery that wasn't terrible (but it also came in a bottle) and a decent unfiltered Sake.   The wait staff was also nothing special, but pleasant.

But even a little tipsy, i wasn't fooled by this place.
Don't you be.  See my other recommendations for a better choice in the immediate area and the surroundings.
author: Andrea C.

description:
Great atmosphere, freshness was awesome.

Service was great.
Will definitely make this a place to go to.

If anything, it's small, but i think it's great cuz it doesn't make it seem like a chain or anything that it's not.
author: Lance L.

description:
So far, this is my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco.  It is super reliable, inexpensive, traditional, and the service is great.

I have never been unhappy eating here.  It is a very traditional place that many native Japanese frequent.  No fancy bistro here.  Just good food.

Lunch time specials are super cheap.

It really is a 3 star restaurant, but it is a really good one, so I had to give it an extra star.

Here's a video review:
http://www.kyte.tv/channels/view.html?name=Restaurant_Reviews#uri=channels/18416/65229
author: Oren F.

description:
The first time I came here, i was taking a girl out to see a musical. She loves sushi so I was trying to find a place close by the Curran. Sakana was close by, and the quality of the fish didn't disappoint. That time, we got the omakase, and couple rolls. If i remember correctly, the young hamachi nigiri was excellent and so were the uni and ikura. 

Recently, I walked past this place unintentionally and since it was a little past 12, I decided to grab food here for old times sake. I ordered the sushi combination and everything was still excellent. 

If you come by for lunch, the sushi lunch options are a good deal. They don't come with any special varieties of fish, but quality is still good and portions are adequate. 

If you come for dinner, try the omakase plus some special nigiris on the side. I don't think you'll be disappointed. Service is also efficient and friendly.
author: Jim Y.

description:
This place is amazing!!  These people know their fish.  If you like bonanza rolls with bbq sauce, chicken nuggets inside and cheese melted over the top this sushi is not for you.  If you like delicious fish, especially uni, this is the place to eat.  
     I came in here when it was packed and the place just kept moving.  The service was great considering there's only 2 of them trying to keep up with a consistent flow of fish orders.  I took a minute to ask my server, the only non-japanese in the joint, for some recommendations and I'm sure glad I did.  He hooked me up with jack mackerel, some delicious seared tuna, and long neck clam.  
     If you're downtown and craving sushi Sakana is the place to satisfy that itch.
author: J M.

description: Loved all kinds of rolls i tried... You can't go wrong with any sort of fish roll. Try the crispy, delicious. A little bit pricy place though.
author: Saad A.

description:
Sevice: 4
Food: 5
Decor: 3

Simple reasonably priced sushi with good friendly service.  This place flies under the radar because the decor is simple. I especially like this place because they import different fish straight from japan giving me options I don't see at other restaurants.  This place really focuses on sushi so my advice is to stick to that and pass on the other stuff.
author: Roger H.

description: All about vibe and the vibe here the night we enjoyed awesome sushi was perfect. Our friendly waiter was helpful in making some great choices as well.  Great spot.
author: Matthew S.

description: Had dinner here last night. I shared the mackerel and spicy tuna rolls. The food was very very yummy. This was a small place, but it served its purpose. I would recommend this place to everyone who happens to be in that part of the town. The only bad thing is finding parking in SF. But I guess that is a problem everyone in SF huh.
author: Kim l.

description: I asked the famous Steve Jobs question: What would I do/eat if it was the last day of my life?   That's exactly what I did: I went to enjoy a nice meal at Sakana Sushi in Downtown Union Square.   I tried Tsukune with skewer chicken & YAMAIMO UME-AE (sliced mountain potato in plum sauce), loved them!
author: Linda L.

description:
WOW!!!  This is what mah Mama made!  This place hits the spot.  Granted I haven't been to too many J-restaurants that serve other foods besides sushi, chicken teriyaki and tonkatsu.  The Saba Shioyaki was just how I like it - grilled slightly burnt for taste with juices oozing out all over the plate.  Don't go there for the sushi or sashimi, but for their kitchen food.

Yamaimo-ume: Plum sauce on mountain yam which slithers in your mouth
Misonasu: Grilled eggplant smothered with mildly flavored miso
Yakitori: Salted chicken skewers with a zest of lemon

We ordered a sashimi plate, but their izakaya style food definitely rocked our meal.  I wish we ordered more appetizers and skipped the sashimi.  The best part of it all was the waiter.  He was so attentive about our green tea and never left an empty cup.  THAT is so Nihonjin.  Topped off with Matcha Ice Cream and my friend paying the bill, can't ask for anything more!
author: Yoko H.

description:
I'm sad to see that the service has gone down since I have eaten here...

This is another place i used to frequent weekly. Great Fresh fish, service was good, and the Maguro Goma Tataki is so good.... yummy. I have only had dinner.
author: nadia w.

description: One of my favorite sushi restaurants.  The fish was always really fresh and expertly prepared.  Have to recommend the special nigiri menu and asparagus rolls
author: C S.

description: Best udon I've ever had.  The broth was really tasty and they actually put in "mountain vegetables" (i.e. not just some sliced carrots and broccoli...blah).  I think it was burdock, wild mushrooms, dark greens - totally unique.  I'm craving some now.
author: Priscilla T.

description: An amazing sushi spot- the fish was incredibly fresh and well prepared. Excellent service as well. Highly recommend!!
author: Matt P.

description: I really liked this place.  I went on a Wednesday night and it was packed.  The sushi was fresh and very good.  I ate at several other sushi places while visiting San Fransico and this was the best place.  I would go back again.
author: Doug V.

description:
The place is quite good, small but lively.  The ambiance is good, it is a place where you want to come with casual friends on a Saturday night.  We tried few items from the appetizer, 3 sushi rolls and hot tea.  The service was good, the food arrived quickly.  However the seaweed salad with cucumber was a little boring, the acidity was quite strong, made my stomach battling with itself the whole night.
Overall the experience was good, I definitely will come back if i come to the city again.
author: Ting R.

description:
Tuesday afternoon, beautiful day to be running errands in downtown, when myself and my best friend are suddenly starving, and we're in the mall. I suggest we grab something quick from Bristol farms before we pass out and are subject to the hands of the unforgiving mall kiosk workers and all their low price scams, when it hits us like a ton of bricks - let's get sushi! As we all know, or you should know, Tuesday is the best day for sushi. Why? Fresh delivery. Please, people, do not eat sushi on a Sunday and then proceed to write a bad review for the restaurant, it's not their fault! No fresh deliveries!
So here we are in the dungeon of the Westfield shopping center, and I bust out the phone and Yelp sushi places around us. Sakana pops up, and highlights reviews for their lunch specials. Let's go! We walk up past Union Square and find our lovely little hole in the wall restaurant completely devoid of any customers. Bad sign? Nah, it's 2:30pm on a Tuesday, we just missed the lunch crowd and no one's eating dinner yet. We seat ourselves at the sushi bar, take a quick glance at the menu, I order a beer and we each order the $9 roll combo (your choice of two rolls plus miso soup). Simple and quick, salmon and spicy tuna for me, spicy tuna and rock n roll for my friend. 
BEST tasting raw fish I have ever eaten. 
Like butta. 
The tuna was marinated nicely, the salmon was so smooth, and I was so jealous I didn't order the eel roll for myself, because hot damn it was delicious.
The chef was nice and holding conversation with us while we ate, waiter checked up on us, but really we didn't need anything outside of what was put in front of us already. Hold on, I take that back. We did have to ask the waiter to come back and tell us what music we were listening to! It was awesome! It was a mix that one of the night servers made, she moon-lights as a DJ I guess... ?
End of story, walked out spending $24 with tip, and with full and happy stomachs.
I have been to many a sushi joint, from hole in the wall family owned to Blowfish in San Jose, and while I love the imagination and inspiration that some chefs put in their rolls, sometimes you just want simple, good tasting fish to satisfy your Omega-3 cravings.
author: Claudia F.

description:
I often go there just grab beer or small Sushi plate.
Because I go there I know the owner and server.

But even though I know pretty much everyone there, often server service is so not friendly no smile almost like they going to die kinda mean face they always putting on. 

Seems those servers have no passion in their life.
They are there because of the minimum wage plus tips.

Yah everyone have to survive. I understand. 

But the fact  wage not always  give the best  enthusiasm for life.
.
Why don't you quit that  job then get your true passion out there??
Then I don't have to see the sad dead face while I try to enjyo food.

Owner is good guy but he give too much comment regarding sex and my figure.

I not really enjoy his comment at all.
He try to be funny and sarcastic.  
But he don' have much skill for talking.

He made comment regading my body figure.

Why I pay money to make my self feel bad????

sushi is just too average. Nothing special.
The atmosphere is so plan. I guess people work there not able to make a good energy  over there.

That is main reason I stop go to Sakana.

They try to be hip and urban but not able to catch up so  far.

This place use to be much better joint before they move. 


So sad.
author: Faith I.

description: I have been coming up to SF for business for many weeks now.  I try to squeeze in a sushi dinner each week.  This was the best so far.  I usually order chef's selection because I can never decide.  And when you do that, the results are fairly typical.  You get some tuna, some yellow tail, some salmon.  You get the picture.  Not here.  My order came with sea urchin, fresh shrimp (not the cheap cooked one), something chewy that was really good but I can't figure out what.  Everything was fresh and delicious.  YUM!  I will be back for sure!
author: M. K.

description: Good atmosphere, good sushi and affordable.  I would suggest the spicy bob (spicy tuna with jalapeno).
author: Matt B.

description:
Sushi is something I couldn't eat it for two months on doc's orders. Tonight was my come back tour. T'was quaint, small and intimate. Although, the service was negligible, but maybe I just haven't got any patience for not refilling/leaving the tea pot when there literally is no one else to wait on at 5:15pm. He just wouldn't leave the pot-o-tea... I digress. 

Sushi is one of my favorite things. Food came quickly; presentation was pleasing; everything tasted excellent; my dinner companion concurred that the food was indeed good. I am going back. 

Also, it's nice to fill two stomachs with a healthy amount of sushi for a few bucks over 40... I'm going back, and I may bring my crew next time.

-LemonadeKing hijacks the Honorable Son's username
author: tim y.

description: Small place, great to go for a quick, but authentic and tasty, bite to eat. Reasonably priced. Will be back soon.
author: Sam D.

description:
This was a delightful but small restaurant for an early dinner for someone still on Central Time.  I had the sushi and sashimi and thought it was above average in quality (the unagi was especially good) and the price was reasonable.  Our server was very friendly and attentive, and it's hard to beat seating at the bar and watching the two sushi chefs at their craft.  They clearly enjoy what they're doing.  The restaurant got full by 7PM on a Monday night - I think in part due to theater-goers eating early.  

The restroom was very clean, always a good sign for a restaurant.  Like so many other restaurants in San Francisco, though, this one does not take Discover or American Express.
author: Ken H.

description:
Sakana is tasty and close to my apartment, so that never equals a bad thing in my book. The rolls aren't outrageously priced and sitting at the bar you can see that the fish is fresh and yummy looking. 

Also, I love sitting at sushi bars to watch the chefs at work, and it seems like the ones here know what they are doing (not that I would really be a good judge, but it makes for a fun dining experience).

Get yourself a beer and sit at the bar for a relaxed and tasty dinner :)
author: Tara O.

description:
Pros: Bacon wrapped hotate...I honestly believe bacon makes everything better; everything.

Cons: Katsuo tataki left something to be desired.  Seemed a bit too seared, and the Katsuo was a bit tough/gamier than I'm used to.  I'll have to give it another try.

Service was good though.
author: Al K.

description:
The fish was very good, but pretty comparable to most good places around the city. Nothing especially notable here that I saw. Prices maybe were a bit high, we managed to drop more than 40 bones each between 4 of us. Although we did eat a whole lot, so I can't complain too much. 

Probably the best part about this place is that its open on Sunday and Monday. I dont know what it is, but come Monday its rare for me not to have a craving for fish.
author: Dan M.

description:
A very nice surprise across from the hotels my parents frequent when they visit SF.  The food here is fresh, tasty, and served in a friendly atmosphere.  I had udon, which was hearty and not too salty.  My mom had tonkatsu that was superb.  My dad had grilled mackerel which he loved, but I declined to try.  We finished the meal by stuffing ourselves with friend banana and green tea ice cream.  Yum.

The prices were reasonable, too!  A great place for before or after a show, within easy walking distance to the Masonic and other theaters.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Scenario: Craving sushi for a nice dinner out. Picked this place out of all the four stars thanks to it's malleable name, and glad we did!

Product: Miso soup was delicious and well-priced. The fried oysters are okay but the sauce with them, kind of an A1 flavor, was good. The least dry sake was a little sweet and smooth. I liked it and recommend a carafe for two people. Philly roll needs a tad more cream cheese, rainbow roll was good, but dragon roll was best with savory eel and ripe avocado with a good mix of hot sauce and creamy sauce.  All that was about $60 after tax.  A bit pricey to me, but I'm used to sushi buffets in Davis.

Service: The waiters were friendly and attentive, as well as helpful about the sake choices. The chefs were indifferent, maybe just bored at a slow Monday night.

Atmosphere: Decor was nothing special.  Actually the drapes at the front door were annoying. Very slow on a Monday night, which was actually nice.  Music was just background noise. Neighborhood seemed okay and a swank bar was next door if you're into that.  Seating was not too crowded and being at the bar is always best!

Uniquity: It was a comfy place and anything involving the avocado or eel will be a sure bet.
author: Robert R.

description: I'm surprised by the ratings for this place.  I tried my friend's salmon and unagi rolls and they were awful.  The rice didn't taste right, and worse, the fish was fishy in a bad way.  To top it off, they were rolled very poorly and falling apart.  I had the temperu udon which was as expected, but too small of a portion.  I left still hungry.
author: Christine L.

description:
After perusing many of the other reviews listed here, we decided to forego our usual Sanraku sushi stop and try something new. How glad we are that we did!
The service was very prompt and friendly, the music was terrific, and the fish was some of the best we've had in the city.
The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is because the decor and lighting made the place feel a lot like a supermarket. But by no means will that prevent us from going again... and again... and again...
author: Justin M.

description:
No nonsense menu....The wait staff was not to enthusiastic, but cool.  
Prices are fair to the quality
The Fish is clearly fresh
Good atmosphere
*Smoked tuna is a MUST
Tastes a lot like what you'd find in the homeland.
author: Jubei K.

description:
GREAT fish.
the place is quaint and fun. it isnt' a ridiculous sushi place that sometimes feels like a cafeteria. This place has great sashimi and less selection of rolls. but rolls aficionados will be converted to how great the fish is. Order the catepillar. wait.. was it the catepillar?  it's the one with the unagi and avocado. it was awesome. the avocado was chill and the eel was still warm and the rice. as ashley would explain it.. it's like dessert in your mouth.
author: Do K.

description: Seaweed salad was a little dry.  Octopus salad was good.  My husband had two different sushi rolls (both with salmon) which he enjoyed.  I had two vegetarian rolls which were also good.
author: Megan M.

description: Some of the freshest sushi I've had. Great service and great hot food as well!
author: Keanu L.

description:
I can totally say that the food is reasonably priced and the fish was really fresh, arguably the best sushi I have eaten so far in SF.

But maybe because I had been spoiled by other Japanese restaurants around the bay, I do have the take away two stars from you Sakana, first of all, I had two other Japanese speaking patrons with me and yet you refuse to speak Japanese to them, and to them, that was rude to begin with. I was pretty much rushed into making my decision to either return or not because you don't have a table ready for me at the time, that was okay, but it would be a little hard for me to understand your situation when you had to say that "you have to tell me now that you are returning or not" when I was still trying to consider my option - please understand that ..... if first time customers walked in, they are either - interested to try your place, or they are just hungry - please be more courteous to them. 

Service other than that was OK, it wasn't bad but wasn't as attentive as I would like either.

The quest for that perfect restaurant in SF continues.
author: David C.

description: Good sushi for a hole on the wall joint. Cheap lunch. Saw the chef coughing near/on the food which upset me.
author: Ron O.

description: They do a great job for lunch and prices are very reasonable.  Awesome agedashi tofu and seaweed/cucumber salad.  Rolls look good and service is fast.  They take amex too!
author: K W.

description:
i feel like such an idiot for having subjected myself to eating at sushi rock on pine all these years, when i could have walked a few blocks further to get the real deal at sakana instead! the bf and i snagged the last two bar seats left on a saturday night, and ordered the spicy scallop roll ($4.75?? what a steal!), caterpillar roll, and the sashimi/yakitori/tempura combo to share.

it's always fun watching the chefs prepare your food in front of you, and in due time our food was presented to us to indulge. i love the fact that their spicy scallop roll wasn't drenched in spicy mayo so that you could actually taste and feel the texture of the scallop. the caterpillar roll was also very good and very reasonably priced compared to other sushi joints that aren't even as high quality. and the combo came with tuna/yellowtail sashimi, two sticks of yakitori, and a perfectly battered and fried side of tempura... delicious!

*sigh* i'm so happy we finally tried it here, and will be back again when i'm feeling the crave for sushi!!
author: Andrey C.

description: Good quality ingredients.  Service was ok but not great.  Very good sushi place though, definitely worth going to.
author: Vern G.

description: This is an easy one. Simply the best sushi I've had outside of japan. So fresh it melts in your mouth. Friendly service and a good, laid back atmosphere. They were playing some cool techno when we were there. I love this place and I wish Boston had this level of quality sushi.
author: Morgan T.

description:
It started innocently enough.
A Friday night here, a Friday night there.
But then all of a sudden I realized it had been weeks since I had my weekly visits with Sakana.
Something had to change.

It was date night with my newly elite best friend (now taking apps for a new plus one) and the ladies were craving sushi. Downtown you say? I typed up a list (cus that's how I roll) of three of my favorite spots...Sakana, of course, at the top of the cut.

Sakana it was.

We ordered a couple glasses of chardonnay, manguro sashimi (like butta), and four of my favorite rolls (crispy, spicy scallop, rock n' roll & 49'er). The meal couldn't be better! My favorite waiter & waitress were both there, and I was so happy to show off my favorite, usual spot to my friend. :)

I believe I have now successfully converted her not only to elitedom but to Sakanadom as well. :)
author: A W.

description: Enjoy Sakana!  Great value for its sushi. My colleague loves this place as he lives a few blocks away. We used to go here once a week. Fresh fish and they've good noodles. Here's a link to more info:  http://tinyurl.com/yav5cx5.  I trust you'll enjoy it.
author: Captain G.

description: Great service quiet and quaint ans sushi melts in your mouth will come again!
author: Jacky I.

description: The Unagi-Don and Nigiri practically melted in my mouth. Simple yet delicious! Quick service as well.
author: Dawn C.

description:
No major complaints.
The service was a bit rushed and they kept on taking away my dishes when I wasn't finished with them.  Reasonably priced.  The food was a OK with a decent selection on Roll.  Decent place to hit up if you are in the area.
author: Po L.

description: This place was good, but nothing mind blowing.  The ceviche had a good mixture of quite a few fishies and was yummy.  We had a couple rolls (spicy scallop roll and tuni with jalapeno's) that were tastey and fresh.  Salmon sashimi melted in your mouth.  All in all a great dinner - I would go back.
author: Megan H.

description: In a word: awful.  Not only did I think the service was horrendous (attitude and speed-wise), the pricing overt, and the fish not quite fresh looking...but I got food poisoning and stayed up the entire night as a result.  Talk about adding insult to injury. I was staying at the Westin, wanted to find a sushi spot, walked around a bit, came upon this place, it seemed fairly crowded, checked my yelp on my phone, 4 stars, OK, good to go...walked in..."Sir, sushi bar only, tables are taken with reservations."  OK no problem...10 minutes later I finally get a waiter, order through the disgruntled sushi chefs, and get my food 30 minutes later...small portion sizes and dry/uninspired roles.  So the experience sucked and then I got food poisoning and violent stomach pains...would not have recommended anyways, but now I can definitely say DO NOT GO HERE...EVER!
author: Logan A.

description:
Excellent food, great service. It's our new favorite Japanese restaurant in the Nob Hill area.
The sushi, the rolls and the main entrees are all delicious and we had quick and courteous service.
author: Maria S.

description: I was iffy about this place as soon as we walked into the cramped space. They have a Small menu & there is Not a lot of variety so I decided to go with the teriyaki chicken. What I got was far from it- I got 6 pieces of dry, salty chicken, it tasted NOTHING like teriyaki. The entree came with a large spinach salad that took up the whole plate.  I spent 35 ( I  treated my bf) to eat spinach basically.
author: E M.

description: I must have gone on a bad day, but everything I ordered had that not-so-fresh feeling.  In fact, I chose not to eat most of it, it was hard to get down made me feel a bit concerned.  I love sushi, but my experience here kept me away from it for a few weeks.  I'm glad to say I'm back in the saddle, but I'll not be riding this horse again.  There are plenty of other places in the area and around town.
author: Joann M.

description:
This place is on the decline after being moderately popular for a while, thus some of the older good reviews. We used to go there around bi-weekly and even knew the staff, but crossed it off our list. The sushi is not fresh, cut sliver thin like those you find at Safeway, yet overpriced. Unfortunately service has declined to a point where there is no point going there anymore.

There are much better and safer places for sushi...
author: Hakan K.

description: We eat at Sakana almost once a week. Sushi is very good - go for the non-fancy stuff, perfect california roll, spicy tuna and ebi tempura rolls are also awesome. Staff is always very kind and friendly, but not pretentious. Overall probably best sushi place in nob hill/tenderloin/union sq area.
author: Eren N.

description: The sashimi was good, but the rolls were just okay. The server was kind of weird with us. I wasn't impressed. There are so many amazing sushi places in this city, and in this hood, it just doesn't make sense to spend so much for something that isn't superior.
author: Monika M.

description: If you need a protein kick for lunch or dinner while in the Union Square area - I recommend Sakana. Sure, there are supreme spots in the Sunset where many authentic japanese spots are, but if you are shopping or working in the Union Square area, I suggest Sakana. We had Hamachi Sashimi, albacore, ikura and unagi - all very fresh. The service is simple and sweet. The bathrooms are pristine.
author: Amy E.

description: The best I've had in this town. I recommend all the things you probably haven't heard of before and the sweet shrimp. If you're slightly adventurous or love all things fried, just say 'yes' when the server asks if you want the head.
author: eric b.

description: I had a wonderful dinner here last Thursday. I remember walking by this cozy little restaurant once and looking through the large windows to witness the bustling scene inside, but I couldn't remember where it was located until I came across it again one day after dinner at Ryoko. The next time I was in the area, I decided to give it a try instead of going to Ryoko. We walked in and were seated by the window. Everything I ordered was a treat for my tastebuds.  I had the tsukune (ground chicken with shiso leaf) which did not disappoint this shiso leaf-fiend! I also got the bacon wrapped scallops recommended by the server which was a great choice (hard to go wrong with bacon and scallops!). Ok, I'm more of a tofu fiend so I also had the agedashi tofu which was tasty until I mixed in the horseradish. From their specials, I tried the amberjack fish from japan which was fresh and only $4.80 for two nigiri pieces. My boyfriend ordered the tonkatsu dinner which was perfectly fried and came with yummy ponzu sauce. I can't wait to come back to try the yamaimo sengiri (sliced mountain potato) and the carpaccio. Also, since it was Thursday night, we headed up half a block to Le Colonial after dinner for the awesome live band.
author: Diana B.

description: Was far and away the best Sushi I had while in SF, the service was good and the food was great, full support.
author: C S.

description: Great little gem near Union Square. The waiter was cool and the food was good. Get the Dragon Roll.
author: Chris D.

description:
i was staying in nob hill for business , and realized that i had never really ventured this part of the city in all of my past visits to san francisco.

around dinner time, i asked the concierge about any restaurants close by, with more of an asian influence - there were plenty to choose from he said... but then the young japanese lady from behind the front desk interjected and said that SAKANA was just down the hill - and was probably a safe bet for what i was looking for - was she right, yes.

the GRUB: 
- authentic japanese food made by authentic japanese staff - awesome.
- i had a spider roll, spicy tuna, and a dragon roll (between two people of course) and the sushi was pretty jammin.
- i also order the Combo Bento dinner - rice, soup, yakitori chicken (BBQ chicken skewers), sashimi (maguro and toro), and mixed tenpura - all delicious.
- a side of Karaage chicken with lime rounded out my dinner feast - yum.
- finished with a bowl of green tea ice cream with a bit of red bean paste on top - great.

the JOINT:
- small and very busy
- on a busy street, im assuming no or limited parking 
- no reservations

the SQUEEZE:
- i wasnt surprised by the bill - its what you expect to pay for in the city for decent to good sushi and service
- they took my amex corp card - awesome.

FINAL WORD:
umai!
author: Ferdi E.

description: Union square isn't replete with amazing sushi, but this place rises well above the theatre district boat places.  Good fresh nigiri and a pretty awesome dragon roll.
author: L W.

description: Lovely little restaurant and have been noticing that it was always packed hence to give it a try. Great sushi and very fresh everything. Bf had the teriyaki salmon - ample serving (2 pieces of salmon) and I ordered the Dinner Combo - sashimi, skewered chicken and tempura. Good serving and both entrees were in the range of $13 - $15. Unagi sushi was fantastic as well.....noticed 2 tables filled with Japanese businessmen and also possibly some Jap students sitting at the counter/bar...I guess that's a good sign.  Very delectable dining experience although the server wasn't very friendly. She simply gestered if we ready to order, hence when we were done, we just hand-signaled for the check. I guess it's not so much for the service, it's simply for the food!  Oh well...
author: Yan M.

description: Great sushi place that happened to be right by my friend's hotel.  Thanks Yelp for the recommendation!  Fish was very fresh, I had the omakase meal which was very tasty.  My friends had a sushi don bowl and a sashimi combo and all commented on the quality of the fish.  Didn't try anything out of the ordinary, had some simple apps of edamame and tofu salad so not sure how the rolls would be.  Overall, solid pick for sushi.
author: Allen S.

description: Sakana is my go-to place for the freshest, high-quality sushi in the city.  It's not trendy, but it is a simple and charming establishment that always serves amazing rolls and the best sashimi.  They have a great variety of local fish and fish they fly in from Japan.  I especially love their dragon and caterpillar rolls because the avocado is always super creamy.  I like sampling their sake selection and I always finish off a meal with their fried bananas and green tea ice cream.
author: Kimberly J.

description: If you're craving raw fish, this is the place to hit up. Authentic Japanses cuisine; ask for the special 'menu' --- it's all in Japanese but if you're adventurous, it's worth experimenting with.
author: T.K. I.

description: Really fresh sushi - the hamachi melts in your mouth - very simple setting. They just moved down the street, their old lease expired.
author: Nish N.

description: food was pretty good, but the server's attitude made it very difficult to enjoy our meal. my dining partner and i arrived 30 minutes before they closed, and received nothing but negative vibing from being seated, to ordering our food, to asking questions and receiving super sharky remarks.... (there was only one other person in the restaurant besides us) definitely won't return here....so many great japanese restaurants in SF and the bay area... i'll get my saba shioyaki somewhere else, thanks. the chef was nice, too bad he wasn't running the restaurant on his own without the smart ass server.
author: Aimee F.

description: Service was fast but the sushi kinda sucked.  The salmon nigiri had brown spots on it and waaaaay too much wasabi.  The halibut was mad dry and not even cut properly (the slice of fish had a freaking hole in the middle).  Although the butterfish nigiri special was pretty good.  The spicy tuna roll was good too.  The service was prompt, I'll give em that.  So yeah, I have no idea what to think of this place so I'll give it 2 stars.
author: Shyam P.

description: This place rocks the sashimi!! Everyone who lives in SF has an opinion on the best sushi place. This place is 5 stars for sashimi. I gave it a 4 because their rolls are not creative or special. Let's be clear, you come here for the sashimi. When you order the chef's special you should just say the $ amount you want in sashimi, and mention whichever kinds you don't like. If you're lucky you'll get a entire fish bone displayed in the middle of your plate. Here's what you do (you may want to take notes): ask the server to fry the fish skeleton for you- head, tail, and all. This is the most delicious part of the meal; it's crunchy, salty, and full of calcium. It may seem obvious to some folks, but Americans just aren't used to it. Trust me, it's delish!!
author: Kathy M.

description: I went on a date with a foodie, and we had the chef's sashimi plate, along with soft shell crab, and maguro.  Everything was so fresh and tasty!  The uni was to die for.  The tobiko shrimp was fantastic.  Even the seaweed salad was tasty.  Make sure you try the dry cold sake too.   I would go back in a heart beat.  -1 star for the price.  It was $170 for 2 people with drinks.
author: Vinh N.

description: This place does have better fish than most places downtown and the new dining room is soothing and spare. The service is efficient if a little cool. Not a lot of smiles here.
author: patrick g.

description: This was a surprising find on a walk to a friend's when hunger and the desire for my fav. food genre took over.  I saw a few people inside and decided it couldn't kill us all now could it?  Not only did I survive my initial dining experience, I've been back and thoroughly enjoyed it both times.  Fresh fish, great service and good prices.  A winning combo in my book.
author: Chard M.

description: Sakana was surprisingly delightful!  You get some great value for the bento box combo, like the sashimi/yakitori/tempura or sashimi/saba/tempura combo, etc.  One of the most reasonable meals we had in San Francisco.  The sushi was really fresh and we liked the spicy scallop roll.  It's a small place so going with a large group is not ideal.  If you're in the area and looking for some quick Japanese food in Union Square area, this place will satisfy the hunger.
author: Tare P.

description: Looking through the other reviews here, I wonder if I came here on an off night. The fish itself was delicious - the hamachi was perfect, the salmon was tasty - we even had a cooked appetizer (scallops wrapped in bacon) that was great. So what is my problem? The rice. The rice was a tad bit undercooked and really had an odd texture. I'm willing to give this place another chance since the fish was excellent. Next time I really hope they fix their rice malfunction!
author: Neil K.

description:
i love sushi anytime, any place, anywhere! i thought this place was pretty good and enjoyed the 4 rolls that we ordered: 

-crispy roll (asparagus, shrimp & tempura bits) 
-spicy tuna roll (spicy tuna, avocado, lettuce)
-dragon roll (tempura shrimp, avocado, eel)
-rainbow roll (avocado, 6 kinds of fish)

we polished it off and i probably could have ate more (you know that feeling where your stomach is full but your mouth wants to keep muching on something tasty) but thank goodness i didn't cause after awhile i felt full! but of course, we walked down to a cafe so my friend could get some coffee but ended up with 2 capps and 2 desserts. go figure!

**ps. there were a lot of japanese people eating here which they say is a good sign!
author: Jane Y.

description: Great place for no frills, no muss, no fuss, yummy tasty fresh sushi. Clean, no waiting, quick, friendly service, lots of great deals on the combo menus. I usually avoid those cause they never have all my fave nigiri, but this one did! I was elated. The 11-pc. regular sushi combo includes miso, 6-pc. California (which they will happily switch or a spicy tuna i found) and one each, tuna, salmon, albacore, unagi, yellowtail (my favorite!) for $14.50. Doesn't have the "cool" atmosphere of Ryoko across the street, which I also like, but at those times when you just want to eat some sushi right NOW damn it, Sakana is a great choice.
author: Sara W.

description:
There are many good sushi restaurants in the bay area. This is the "NOT Korean NOR Chinese"  Japanese restaurant (

Worked with Korean production companies. Lived in Japan. And being a Chinese (or Taiwanes, whatever), I give Sakana a five star in terms of sashimi.. and 3.5 stars for the service.  I only care about the food... doesn't care about good service (well.. i am a Chinese after all)
author: T L.

description: If Im ever craving sushi for lunch,  this is the place to go.   The fish is very fresh and very good!  I always order the chirashi ( raw fish over rice) and they give you a healthy portion of different types of fish and other delicacies.  Yummy!
author: Jeremy V.

description: Great sushi place---probably the best place for sushi around the union square / downtown area.  Place is a little small and service can sometimes be slow when they're busy, but the fish is fresh and the place is very clean.  Nothing like going on a shopping spree and the grabbing a nice quiet dinner at this hidden gem. Wait, on second thought this place is terrible, don't go here.
author: Ed C.

description: Hands down my favorite sushi joint in SF! Hiro is my #1 guy there!  I go there at least once a week and if I don't go there at least once I week, I make up for it the following week. YES, I'm a fan!  The sashimi is fresh and delicious! You can't go wrong. I always order the Sashim/Sushi special during lunch and sometimes change it up to the mackerel dish with salad.  I dont know why people go to Sanraku unless they don't want authentic Japanese food. When did sesame chicken become a Japanese dish? Okay, I really dont know if that's a Chinese dish or Japanese but I sure as heck dont go to Sanraku for real Japanese food. Anyhoo, back to Sanraku. Hiro knows me by name and knows exactly what I want when I walk in or call in. I change it up every once in awhile and even though it's not my "special" order that day, it's still pretty darn good. The chef even noticed my shoes. Apparently, I always wear a different pair and he really likes them all. haha.  LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: Bren L.

description: This is a special little place.  Few tables, helpful staff, reasonable prices.  The fish was good, the menu was extensive.  Decent sake selection, too.
author: ben y.

description: Simple sushi with a large selection of fresh Japanese imports for a very reasonable price.
author: Alicia J.

description: Came here on a whim having never even heard of it before.  We were pleasantly suprised by the friendly staff and great food.  The fish was all super tender and tasted amazing.  It's a very traditional place amidst a sea of overpriced tourist traps which helps its cause a lot.  And given its location I can understand the pricing.  It's a little steep for the portions but everything is overpriced near Union Square.  And since the quality is there I can't complain.  I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to eat here but I would definitely make a point of it if I was downtown and hungry.
author: M M.

description: I been going there for years. This is probably one of the few restaurants that I have seen that Japanese people go to often.  The food always fresh and their dragon roll is to die for.   Their chirashi is one of the best and probably one of the few places who makes their miso soup differently.
author: Chris C.

description:
I was sick so I didn't have the sushi here. 

But the teriyaki steak was perfect and the side salad was solid (even though I hate salad). Miso soup was good.

My friend had a bunch of sushi pieces that looked good, and he said it was delicious.

People have mentioned problems with the service, but we didn't have anyt. All around cordial to the dudes probably violating a dozen rules on how to use chopsticks properly.
author: Jackson H.

description: Best sushi for your $ that you will find in the bay. That isn't to say the food is low quality, it is just affordable for sushi.
author: Ted B.

description: Wonderful intimate refuge. Great sushi, nice music. A place I always visit when in SF.
author: Chick F.

description:
3.5 stars.  you know it's an authentic japanese place when the chefs are japanese and japanese tourists book this place.  

the fresh sashimi here is $$.  4 slices of toro set me back $20.  yelp!!  =(   my favorite is the dragon roll.  so good!!
author: Dorothy L.

description: My go-to sushi place, since it's so near to where I earn my keep. The fact that Japanese people pack this place in has a lot to say for it. Great for dates, taking the parents or an apres work bite. Skip the rolls and have the nigiri or sashimi because the fish here is f*cking top notch. And their wasabi, the freshest I've ever had.
author: Andre L.

description: This place had very solid sushi and great prices.  I'm not much of a sushi expert, so I'll just say that it satisfied my simple needs in terms of the menu and the quality of the food.  The reason I'll probably go back is because I didn't feel like I had to compromise because of the price.  It was affordable enough that I was able to feel free getting whatever rolls I wanted.
author: Tyler K.

description: This is place where I had sushi for the very first time. The first delicious item I tried was the seared tuna - I was immediately hooked. Everything else was excellent. A fine establishment to splurge in and bring happy to the belly.
author: Judy R.

description: Had sushi there the other night and it was the best I have had in the city in the 2 years that I have lived here... and I eat lots of sushi.  You should go there.
author: Justin J.

description:
My dad told me to go to this place (he works for a J import food company and knows which restaurants use quality ingredients, and have good chefs), and he was right. 
The quality of food is top notch, and the price is very, very reasonable. 
Authentic and standard menu. The spinach goma-ae (sesame sause) is one of the best I've ever had, and you get so much for a little money. I was very happy with the fried oysters too - they were freshly made (some restaurants use frozen stuff and you can tell when they do that!), plump, juicy and we got 6 fat pieces for a mere $5.50! 
When the bill came we were like, "that's it?"
I found a new favorite place in downtown! 
Actually, one thing on the con side...I think they need to carry more variety of beer...maybe they are on the special menu, which we didn't ask for. Next time!
author: M K.

description: Let's face it....San Francisco is loaded with sushi joints. But one of my favorites has to be Sakana. The fish is really fresh and delicious. I especially love the tuna tataki. I will come here again and again for their yummy rolls and sashimi. Great service. The staff is extremely friendly too! I plan on coming back to try everything else on the menu. I'm pretty adventurous when it comes to food....but the salmon skin salad just ain't my cup of tea. That one's going on my "at least I tried it" list.
author: Anne E.

description: I'm a big fan of SAKANA.  I don't go there to eat sushi rolls, I mainly order sushi or sashimi.  Most of the time, the owner takes care of my sushi and recommend what's fresh.  Last time I went to Sakana was on Valentine's Day, we had a great dinner and time.  We ordered: mirugai, maguro, hirame, uni, amaebi, chutoro, aji, saba, ikura, hotate, ika, and appetizers.  And Japanese BEER!  Spent over $220 with tip & tax but it's worth it.   The reason Sakana didn't get a 5 stars is that they usually run out of FISH.  Where's the FISH?
author: Maki M.

description: Close to the Union Square area - this narrow sushi place in not for a large dinner group but perfect for 4 or less people.  The sushi is delish and the sake strong - what more could you ask for?
author: Annabel G.

description: inexpensive but delicious and HUGE bowl of ramen.  House Sake and pot stickers were also a hit.
author: Eran B.

description: Through the first 4-5 items that our group ordered, it definitely seemed like Sakana was destined for a 3-star rating. Everything tasted fine and the service was good but nothing seemed to stand out. But being such a big fan of fried calamari, I had to add on an order of the Fried Squid. That most definitely deserves another star. No need to dip these into any sauce as they come fully loaded in flavor. They were so good that I accidentally spilt sake on my lap. ok, I admit it... I was just too stupid to figure out why the sake came in 2 glasses. I should've heeded the warnings.
author: James C.

description: Took the Japanese inlaws there. The dad works by the district in Tokyo known as the sushi mecca, Tsukiji. He had no complaints. Is it as good as Tsukiji in Japan... NO! But it's pretty damn good and the best I've had so far in SF. The dual style specials feature fish both from Japan and from the US. Very Fresh!
author: Jay N.

description:
I like going to Sakana not just for its food but also its genuine Japanese atmosphere.  Half of its customers are Japanese.  Staffs are all (except one who speaks Japanese fluently) Japanese.  I don't know why but this place makes me feel like I am back in Japan.  I had better Sushi at a few other restaurants in SF but Sakana serves the best sushi for its price.  And their sake selection is pretty good.  Stay away from warm and cheap Sakes!!!  Warm Sakes in Japanese restaurants are similar grade to cooking Sake (Sho-Chiku-Bai).  FYI, We (I am Japanese) drink hot Sakes ONLY in winter.  If you want to know more about Sake, I suggest you to visit True Sake at Hays Valley.  Anyway, I recommend "Mushouhai" or Kubota"  from their sake list at Sakana.  

One time I met a Seattle Mariner's pitcher (I can't remember his name) at Sakana.  He told me that Ichiro mentioned about Sakana to him.  

Both Ichiro and I recommend Sakana!
author: Bobra K.

description: Excellent cuts of fish, great service, affordable, and most importantly, shiro maguro that melts in your mouth like butter. The seating is limited, but we just hung out at the Owl until a table was ready.
author: Sonya Y.

description: Nice place with a small comfortable feel.  I sat at the sushi bar and ordered a few rolls and some miso soup.  Nice fresh taste, but the portion of fish in the rolls knocked this pleasant dining experience from four stars to three.  They also have a list of fresh specials with lots of stuff I have never had (or seen) so if you are an aficionado you might want to give this place a try.
author: John T.

description:
Lovely place for fresh sushi and some quiet dining. A Japanese friend  who is a regular Sakana customer brought me here, so that should count for something.

Oh, I finally caved and tried the uni.... It's fresh... and I like it. Never thought I would. "It tastes like the uni in Japan," my friend said. That should count for something too, I suppose!

Service was excellent. Obviously, it helps when your friend knows the owner and staff.

So if you're in Union Square and craving for some Japanese food, this may be a good place to go.
author: S V.

description: I went here after reading good reviews on yelp.  The seating inside is better than Akiko's, but there is better sushi over there.  Sakana's sushi was freshly made, but it tasted meh, like store bought sushi.  The fish was fresh, but everything was so bland, it was nothing special.  Oh well.
author: Lizzy G.

description: Not sure what previous bad reviews were about. The salad did not have Italian dressing and the service was great. Fish is fresh, food comes fast. Will come back for sure.
author: Laura w.

description: Great sushi.  Simple and small space.  Service was very friendly.  Pick off the daily specials menu.  This is the place to go when you're in the mood for some really fresh, high quality fish.
author: Rudro S.

description: Took a nap and next thing I knew it was 11PM. Hungry and craving sushi, I didn't know where to go. By the time I got ready and out the door, it was close to mid-night. Sakana was one of the few places open. Not expecting much, I got a menu with nigiri offerings I haven't seen anywhere else - stuff flown in straight from japan! i had flatfish and barracuda. both were good. also got young hamachi and jack makerel, both were fresh as well. the crunch roll was good, and service was good. overall, recommended.
author: Anderson L.

description: Deeelish! Never a wait in this great sushi place. Always great service in the Tender-Nob area. Rolls, sashimi and nigiri are fresh. One of my fav sushi places in SF.
author: Alyssa C.

description: I've been coming here for 10+ years and the owner, Michael, still maintains the same level of quality. Great staff and best sashimi in town - I have tried to find better and keep coming back to Sakana. They won't admit it because it's not polite to name drop but Japanese athletes and actors - not to mention the Japanese businesspeople - come here to get their fishy grub on. If the Yankees are in town, Godzilla may have the place to himself. The space they are in now was the original location, they moved for a few years a few doors down but was overlooked so they got their old location back. I do miss the longer sushi bar but when you come and there is a wait just tell them you'll be at the Owl Tree.
author: James T.

description: I recently ate here and had the sushi combo which came with one of each  of the following: ebi(shrimp), maguro(tuna), sake(salmon), unagi(eel), I think the other one was a mackerel, and it also came with 6 pieces of Cali roll, which ehhh not really my favorite...I must admit the sushi was fresh, but it was a little on the salty side. neverthess still good...came here around dinner time and the place was empty, which was a shock after all the great reviews I thought this place would be packed, but no...this place was good, but nothing to brag about.
author: murs.one ..

description: I thought nobody knew about this place, it was never in Zagat and rarely would anyone believe me that there was an amazing sushi spot in this 'hood. I can only go to Sakana with friends who aren't willing to eat what I consider to be frightening parts of our friends from the sea. I am unfortunately not as adventuruous as the guys who took me here the first few times. But if you are that way with your sushi, this is the best place to sit down and ask the chef to just send out what he thinks is best. Me, I prefer to come in and have top quality sushi that I like and enjoy all the excellent sake options they offer. One day I will perhaps be less of a sushi novice....
author: Colleen B.

description: Had some friends in town from Utah craving sushi, but they landed at 10:15 PM.  All my usual sushi spots were closed.  Pleasantly surprised by Sakana.  Not much in the way of atmosphere, but the fish was really fresh.  Staff was friendly, and Sakana was open until midnight on a Thursday!  I would definitely go back for a late-night sushi fix.
author: Ben M.

description: Holy fresh fish!  I tried this place sort of by accident, since a friend lives close and was already dining there when I stopped by.  I was so impressed by my nigiri snack, that I'd been trying to drag someone with me to suss out if it was a one hit wonder for a few weeks before I got back there last weekend.  The friend had suggested the tempura was not so good, so my dining partner and I stayed with nigiri and sashimi, and I was as impressed as I had been the first time.  Super yum!
author: Susan L.

description: Sakana is for sushi purists--it has some of the best-quality fish in the Union Square area but a fairly uninteresting atmosphere, except for the bustling (usually Japanese) clientele.  Don't come here if your're looking for exotic rolls; the fare tends to be more traditional Japanese nigiri and sashimi.  I'd suggest going on a Friday or Saturday night, when the quality of the fish seems to be at its peak.  The prices are quite reasonable.
author: MScott S.

description: Had some friends in town from Cincinnati.  They are recent transplants from coastal cities and were jonesing for some good sushi.  5 of us showed up at this tiny little shop on Post St and took over a couple tables to hold us all.  Then we dug into some excellent sushi and udon and katsu-don.  So much yummy goodness!  The friends were super happy about the fresh fish and we were all super happy about the price!  5 of us ate for about $75 including tip! (please note it was lunch time and we ordered off their specials so your price may vary!)
author: Suzanne G.

description: This restaurant was wonderful!  The sushi was extremely fresh and very tasty!  I thought the tuna sashimi was the best part, but the rolls we had were wonderful too!
author: Kat C.

description: Simply. Good. Sushi.  Over a dozen special catch sashimi and tight, tight rolls.  I love being able to select from three kinds of snapper.  The rolls don't fall apart as you pick them up.  Sake menu is what I wold define as SELECT.  Great options, best of among flavor profiles.  I will be back.
author: Doug A.

description: A great raw fish discovey amongst all the tourist traps in the downtown area. Get the spanish mackerel sashimi (Aji) and your tummy will thank you. Very fresh selections. Also try the grilled scallops with bacon - YUM.
author: Tami Y.

description: Very fresh, delicious dishes. Sometimes the quality varies based on who is behind the counter. But for the most part I have had very pleasant experiences there. If you are in the mood for sushi, this is definitely the place to go. Try their chirashi, its delicious.
