author: alisa o.

description:
omg so good! I  actually was dreaming about it and salivatiting right now

This worked for me

- Order the PLUM WINE. 
(Yes it's a sweet drink)

-Order  Sushi only.  (fresh)
author: blah k.

description: My favorite Japanese resturant in the city if your not looking for a trendy spot and reasonable prices.  I always order the maguro goma !!!!  My favorite.  Their spicy tuna is one of the best too.  When I was living in the city, I used to come here at least 2-3 times a week.  Sigh... At least I have Shogun in Newark.  My new fave place.
author: E C.

description: One of the best sushi places in the area. Sushi is always fresh and tasty. The selection of rolls is pretty simple, nothing too crazy or unique. Decent prices. It's a little small but usually isn't packed.
author: Bruce D.

description: Ok, I'm on an iPhone so please forgive my formatting, and spelling, and content...but, this place was great!! Very casual, authentic, and affordable. Highly recommend the echigo beer an the Mushouhai sake. Also, get the Baracuda and the young Yellowtail...and hotate and others, it's all good.There, you got us I the moment... Good stuff, eh? Ask for Kiranjaro (sp?)
author: Armand R.

description:
Yipee! an affordable and wonderful service in Union Square area, Working in the area, the choices are not abundant for diversity in cuisine .

I was looking for a NEW and healthy choice, they have grilled fish with miso soup and green salad for under $7.95 ! 

The food was amazingly delish, fish was fresh and awesome! Service outstanding..can't wait to return to try the other selections.
author: Liz D.

description: Great lunch special!  Sashimi or Sushi lunch specials are both great.  The staff are really nice, the fish is good, the rice is always perfect and yeah, I go here a lot.
author: Heidi P.

description: This is THE place to go for real sushi. I've never yet been disappointed by their fresh sushi and very authentic appetizers. Check out their specials and try something new!
author: Makoto S.

description:
A solid sushi restaurant with real Japanese staff and customers.

I can't give it five stars since nothing stood out as really extraordinary, but at least the focus was on nigiri instead of a lots of Americanized rolls.  Everything was good and I would be happy to return when I am in the Union Square area.

One annoying thing is that their nigiri menu showed the Japanese name of fish in hiragana or kanji and then the English name of the fish rather than the romanji version (like "uni" for sea urchin).  I can't be happy without romanji names of fish since (my personal opinion) is that romanji should be the primary form of Japanese written language (General Macarthur wasn't doing a good job when Japan surrendered in 1945 or he would have imposed romanji once and for all).
author: Richard P.

description: Great food for the price. Flavors are delicate and balanced instead of overly salty. Friendly service.
author: D F.

description: Definitely better than your average take-out sushi restaurant, and they don't make the mistake of serving the sushi too cold. But beyond that I can't say the quality was worth the price-tag. Certainly nothing to write home about.
author: Kerim F.

description:
We usually stop by once a month to have their chirashi. They change the toppings for the chirashi depending on what is fresh that day/season which is welcome. I prefer to order it without the sesame seeds that they sprinkle on the rice by default - I don't find that the sesame goes with raw fish.

All their appetizers are typical izakaya food so they go well with beer. Make sure to check out their daily special menu on the whiteboard. Sometimes not all of the items on the whiteboard have English translations so ask the waiter for the full list if this is the case. I wish the special menu had the prices listed though.

They never seem to have the bonito, although it's on their appetizer menu.
author: Keisuke O.

description: I tried Sakana yesterday for the first time and I was very happy with it , maybe that was the sake !!!!!! No seriously I loved the crispy roll and the asparagus tempura was heaven. We sat at the counter and it was great to see everything being prepared for us. They have a specials board with some funkier items on it but I decided to check out the regular menu on my first visit and then work my way up to the more adventurous items on my future visits. It worked out to be pretty reasonable also which is always a welcome treat at a sushi restaurant .
author: joanne t.

description: My favorite place to go for a rest diner up to now. I like the ambiance, sweet old fashion music, quiet, unusual crowd compare to other restaurant in the neighborhood. The quality of the fish is awesome here. The taste of all of kind of fish is tiny,precious and worth to go. You can ask the waitress for any combination or special ingredient in your sushi sashimi, you will feel very comfortable in that place, if you are more than 4 you should call to book.
author: afura a.

description: Deep fried sushi is delicious.  Guess that shouldn't surprise.
author: Kathy M.

description: The sushi here is on the better side. I go here about once a week or so. A little pricey at times when you buy alcohol but well worth it. The service is great!
author: Matt L.

description: This review is solely with respect to the service. Specifically the Asian guy who works nights. Let me prefix this by saying I NEVER complain about bad service and have no other Yelp reviews criticizing service. Also, I I always think restaurant owners should never fire people based on a random bad Yelp review - but dozens of people have written about this idiot. This guy - alone - - is reason enough  not to patronize Sakana. Dismissive, and outright rude, disrespectful, and just plain stupid. He has it all! I came is one other person and there was already a couple in line before us who had been waiting a while. So four people - two groups. Easy math. We waited 30 minutes and the other couple had been there longer. There were two tables - each with two seats - right next two each other. A while later 4 people came in together and he sat them immediately at the two tables (pushed together) . I asked what was going on - the two tables could have just been split to separately seat the two parties already waiting for a LONG time. No explanation. He simply said "I can do what I want please leave the restaurant"! Completely psycho off the wall attack for no reason other than me politely questioning his logic or lack thereof. What are these business owners thinking? He has lots of bad reviews. It is disrespectful to customers and society in general to keep this dumb a#@ employed. My guess is he is either elated to the owners or they don't know English and can't read Yelp.
author: Dirk G.

description: I'm in my first week in SF and this restaurant saved me as they are open after 10pm for late dinner. Anyway, the food is really great and the place is very relaxed. I ordered a misu soup a combination of sushi with a nice asahi beer. All in all, great food, great place to go to. I will definitely go there again.
author: Erez E.

description:
ray and i went here last weekend, friday night actually. i called the night before and got a reservation for 6:30. we walked a few blocks here from our hotel and there were just a few tables. our cute reserved table was right in the front window and it was great, especially since it was pretty warm outside and in there, we got a good breeze. 

when we sat down, i jokingly said to ray that i guess we didnt need to get a reservation, but i soon realized that i was glad we did! by 6:45, the place was filling up very quickly and they had reached capacity in no time! meanwhile ray and i were eating our veggie tempura appetizer (very good and light, not too oily). for dinner, ray ordered salmon teriyaki that looked really good but i didnt try any. i had an order of tekka maki and crispy roll, both which were very good. the asparagus in the crispy roll was tender enough to bite through without pulling it out of the roll, but was also crisp and very fresh.

i would certainly come back here next time we are in the city and looking for sushi. my only complaint is that they didnt fill up our waters very often, and since that was all we were drinking that was a little of a let down. but not even close to being a reason not to go back!

i forgot to mention the price, so i am editing my post! we paid a little over $40 with tip, which is LESS than what we pay for a similar meal at our favorite sushi place here in santa clara, so i would say for the great quality, this is more than worth the price!
author: jenny s.

description: I tried the omakase menu, very good, great selection of nigiris. I also asked for an uni nigiri, the sea urching was smooth and creamy, its a must.
author: Pablo R.

description: Sono tabemono wa hontoni oishikatta desu yo.  Ankimo wa yokatta desu.
author: Rich N.

description: okay japanese, simple sushi and dry teriyaki.
author: Cass M.

description: i really enjoyed my unfiltered sake, and the fish was pretty good overall, but it was really the fried squid that won me over.  convenient, non-pretentious place, though the waiter needs some japanese pronunciation lessons!  (not knee-geary, ni-gee-ri!)
author: Jill k.

description: After wandering in the cold, trying to find a restaurant, me and two girlfriends stumbled upon this cozy little place. It was filled with people, which is a good sign in my book. The prices were reasonable, so we went in. Service was prompt and friendly, and the whole place had a warm feeling... good vibe. The menu was sushi/sashimi heavy, but I was in the mood for some hot food, and settled on the Unagi-Don. My friends got a Chirashi and a sashimi + grilled mackerel + tempura combo. The unagi bowl was pretty good, with a generous portion of unagi. I wasn't blown away... it was just good. I think it was missing some punchier flavor. I tried some of my friends' sashimi, and it was very fresh tasting. They both liked what they got. The tempura wasn't the best I tasted, as the batter was too dense. The restaurant had a constant flow of people, and got downright crowded at points, despite being at a somewhat out of the way location. It's a super convenient walk from Union Square, has good service, and decent food. I'll have to try their sushi next time... when the weather is a bit warmer!
author: Joy C.

description: great quality fish but i think it's a little on the pricey side (probably  because it's so close to union square with all of the tourists).  the cooked saba was amazing though.
author: michelle k.

description: Not recommended. Food was mediocre and though the server was nice, that was as far as it went. We had to wait almost 20 min for our bill. Reasonable price.
author: Danielle S.

description: the best thing about this place, was that it was open late. so awesome. my friends and i had finished watching watchmen in imax and was roaming around the city just wondering what to do next. my sister said she could go for sushi and the two friends who lived in the city guided us to this area. it was about 11PM i think. i think they're open until like 2AM. i hate it when you go do something in the city and the only thing open are bars and clubs. egh. so we ordered a few rolls and nigiri. the spider roll was just OK. i think my sister liked her maguro nigiri. we also had some other tuna dishes - which were a bit TOO flavourful - masking the taste of the yummy raw tuna. haha. like i said, the best thing about this place is that it's open late. i'd go back again if i was in the city and was looking for a place to eat at midnight.
author: Karen K.

description: It's always a good sign when you walk into a Japanese restaurant or sushi bar, and the first thing you notice is that nearly all the customers are Japanese. That impression was proved correct. It's a little hole-in-the-wall space with a sushi bar and a few tables, and a menu that's half sushi, half basics (some noodles, tempura, that sort of thing). My first suggestion is that whatever the day's specials are, try them. Toro was listed as a special, and it ranked up there on par with the best I've ever had - the fish just melted in the mouth, and had a magnificently rich flavor halfway between tuna and butter. Prices are reasonable for sushi (most nigiri runs $4.25). My only complaint was that the tempura had too much batter. It was light and crisp, but there was a bit more on my veggie tempura appetizer, and on the spider roll crab, than there should have been. But it was neither greasy, nor thick and heavy.
author: Don H.

description: yum. so good, never a wait. chill atmosphere. did I say yum yet?
author: Dave R.

description: Great sushi and sake! Super fresh...'nough said.
author: J M.

description: After spending the night tossing and turning at the local Hilton, agonizing over missed sushi opportunities from the night before, I set out determined to let my yelp-compass guide me yet again through the undulating streets of San Francisco to sushi heaven. It took a short 5 minutes with a swift turn here, a quick dash there to beat the approaching yellow checkered Visigoths, and i was knocking on Sakana's door. The place was sparsely populated and I was quickly ushered to a window side table where I brushed aside the menu and honed in on  the rolls.. After a moment's pause to survey the options, my stomach urged me to consider a rainbow roll and a spider roll (though I would have loved to sample the species" imported from Japan" as listed on the board) I eventually gave in to my regular cravings and ordered a rainbow and spider roll. Both were quite gratifying  to a sushi starved tongue, but I'm afraid my moment of passion might have been colored by the sushi drought of the last couple of months. All said though, it was a pleasant fishing experience.. hai!
author: Getafix O.
